I. SUMMARY OF THE PROSPECTUS

Summaries are made up of disclosure requirements known as elements ("Elements"). These Elements are
numbered in Sections A – E (A.1 – E.7). This summary contains all the Elements required to be included in a
summary for this type of security and issuer. Because some Elements are not required to be addressed, there may
be gaps in the numbering sequence of the Elements. Even though an Element may be required to be inserted in
the summary because of the type of security and issuer, it is possible that no relevant information can be given
regarding the Element. In such cases, the summary includes a short description of the Element with the words
"not applicable".
SECTION A - INTRODUCTION AND WARNINGS

This summary should be read as an introduction to this prospectus
thereto (the "Prospectus"). Any decision to invest in the relevant
securities should be based on a consideration of this Prospectus as a
whole by the investor.
Warnings.

Where a claim relating to information contained in this Prospectus is
brought before a court, the plaintiff investor might, under the national
legislation of the member states of the European Economic Area (the
"Member States"), have to bear the costs of translating this Prospectus
before legal proceedings are initiated.

together with its consolidated subsidiaries, the "Group" or the "NFON

or if it does not provide, when read together with the other parts of this

activities and     we provided our services to more than 15 thousand business customers (includ-
principal          ing end customers of our wholesale partners) with more than 250 thousand seats.
markets in which   Our flagship service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, is a public multi-
the issuer         tenant PBX delivering its services from the cloud. As such, it is designed to
competes.          enable convenient and effective location-independent communication for our
                   customers and their employees, all the time, on multiple devices, including
                   smartphones, tablets, personal computers ("PCs") and desk phones.

Traditionally, businesses have exclusively used on-premise PBX. These systems
generally require expensive hardware that must be deployed at every business
location of the customer and are primarily designed for employees working only
at that location and using only their desk phones. In addition, these systems
generally require significant upfront investment and ongoing maintenance and
support costs. In contrast, public multi-tenant PBX, such as the NFON Cloud
Telephone System, are easy to deploy, have increased functionality, are highly
flexible and scalable and are updated automatically. Normally, public multi-
tenant PBX also provide for lower total costs of ownership than on-premise and
other off-premise PBX. The market development is expected to be clearly in
favour of Hosted/Cloud PBX1: While as at 31 December 2017, just over 10 % of
all PBX systems deployed in the market for business PBX in Europe were esti-
mated to be Hosted/Cloud PBX, this portion is expected to increase to more than
25 % by the end of 2022. (Source: MZA).

Over the last ten years we have developed a highly reliable, enterprise grade
cloud service platform that is horizontally scalable, meaning that we can quickly
and cost-effectively expand the capacity of our infrastructure and delivery plat-
form by connecting additional hardware or software components and that relies
almost exclusively on infrastructure operated in Germany and complying with
the strict European data privacy requirements. To ensure short reaction times
and high quality in both development and services, almost all of our solutions
and processes were developed in-house and are operated by ourselves. The
NFON Cloud Telephone System is highly reliable and provides for more than
150 core features that are constantly updated at no additional cost to our custom-
ers. It can be used for up to several thousand seats per customer. Due to our self-
developed zero-touch provisioning process, the deployment of the NFON Cloud
Telephone System is easy and intuitive. When used with a mobile device it uses
GSM/UMTS2 voice technology to transport the call in case of insufficient data
connectivity while still offering most PBX features.

We offer the NFON Cloud Telephone System to companies of all sizes. Our
customer base ranges from small office/home office customers ("SoHos") to
large businesses. We address them with a multi-channel distribution strategy.
Besides our direct distribution, we have a network of more than 1,100 (as at
31 March 2018) dedicated distributors and dealers. In addition, our wholesale
partners, such as Deutsche Telekom (including its subsidiary T-Systems), Chess
Communication, Telefónica Germany and Sunrise, distribute our cloud tele-
phone system on a white label and co-branded basis to their customers.

1
  Off-premise PBX can be categorised into private single-instance (sometimes also referred to as "Hosted PBX") and public single-instance
systems as well as public multi-instance and public multi-tenant systems (public single-instance, public multi-instance and public multi-
tenant systems together also referred to as "Cloud PBX", and together with the Hosted PBX, the "Hosted/Cloud PBX").

2
    Global System for Mobile Communications/ Universal Mobile Telecommunications System.

With offices in Berlin, Greven, Madrid, Mainz, Munich, St. Pölten and Ux-
bridge, we are active in 13 European markets, including Austria, Germany, the
Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom. In 2017, we
generated 72 % of our revenue in our IFRS segment Germany, 14 % in our IFRS
segment United Kingdom and 12 % in our IFRS segment Austria (including
Eastern Europe), before reconciliation. With our core service, the NFON Cloud
Telephone System, tailored to the needs of European customers, we intend to
leverage on our proven market entry strategy to enter additional European mar-
kets with a particular focus on France, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg and
expand our business in the Netherlands.

We have experienced significant growth in recent periods, with total revenue of
EUR 20,951 thousand, EUR 30,388 thousand (including an extraordinary effect
of non-recurring service revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand generated in
connection with setting up a wholesale partnership) and EUR 35,654 thousand
in the financial years 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively, representing year-over-
year increases of 45.04 % and 17.33 %, respectively, and were awarded the
Frost & Sullivan Growth Excellence Leadership Award 2017 for Hosted IP3
Telephony and UCaaS4 Industry in Europe.

We recorded net losses of EUR 6,054 thousand, EUR 1,548 thousand and
EUR 2,021 thousand in the financial years 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively.

The market for business PBX (the "PBX Market") in Europe is steadily shifting
towards Hosted/Cloud PBX (Source: MZA). We believe that one of the main
drivers of this development is the transition from integrated service digital
network ("ISDN") to All-IP networks by the European telecom carriers, such as
Deutsche Telekom which intends to switch off its ISDN network (Source:
Deutsche Telekom, Die 10 wichtigsten Fragen und Antworten zur Umstellung
auf den IP-Anschluss, 27 February 2015, ("Deutsche Telekom")). We believe
that the essential motive for switching to All-IP networks is cost efficiency by
merging two separate infrastructures (Internet and dedicated public switched
telephone networks ("PSTN") equipment) into one IP/Voice over IP ("VoIP")
based technology. Additional motives include faster time to market for new
services, technologies and service attributes and the simplified implementation

2017 compared to 2016
We principally generate revenue from telephone services. Most of our contracts
relate to telephone services with or without hardware sales and other services. In
2017, revenue increased by 17.33 %, from EUR 30,388 thousand in 2016 to
EUR 35,654 thousand in 2017. The increase in revenue was due primarily to the
acquisition of new customers and an increase in the number of users within our
existing customer base, in particular, in Germany, the United Kingdom and
Austria. Management believes the overall growth in our customer base reflects
both our own distribution and marketing efforts as well as an overarching
market trend towards multi-tenant PBX. The total number of seats increased
from 191,977 seats in 2016 to 253,360 seats in 2017, which corresponds to an
increase by 31.97 %. This reflects the fact that the number of seats we lost was
more than offset by the number of seats we gained from new customers and
customers that were already customers at the beginning of the year. Recurring
revenue accounted for 77.87 % of our total revenue in 2017, compared with
71.10 % in 2016, whereas non-recurring revenue accounted for 22.13 % in 2017
compared with 28.90 % in 2016. In 2016, non-recurring revenue included
service revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand generated in connection with setting up
a wholesale partnership. Disregarding this extraordinary effect, recurring

In 2017, our EBITDA amounted to EUR -1,028 thousand compared to EUR -
718 thousand in 2016 mainly due to costs related to the preparation of the
Offering and one-off expenses related to tax and social security matters5. These
cost items did not occur in 2016. Without these cost effects our EBITDA would
have been EUR 173 thousand in 2017.
2016 compared to 2015

Revenue increased significantly by 45.04 %, from EUR 20,951 thousand in
2015 to EUR 30,388 thousand in 2016. Recurring revenue accounted for
72.50 % of the total revenue in 2015, compared with 71.10 % in 2016, whereas
non-recurring revenue accounted for 27.50 % in 2015 and 28.90 % in 2016. The
slight decrease in recurring revenue as a percentage of revenue reflects the
impact of the extraordinary effect of non-recurring service revenue of
EUR 1,500 thousand generated in connection, with setting up a wholesale
partnership in 2016. Disregarding this effect, recurring revenue as a percentage
of total revenue would have been 74.79 %. This reflects the fact that the average
number of seats per customer went up.

In 2016, our EBITDA amounted to EUR -718 thousand compared to
EUR -5,606 thousand in 2015. This improvement is due to a proportionately
stronger increase in revenue than our most significant cost and expense items.
Recent Developments

By resolution of the Company's general shareholders' meeting held on 22 Febru-
ary 2018 the Company's share capital was increased from capital reserves from
EUR 370,775.00 by EUR 9,269,375.00 to EUR 9,640,150.00.

In November 2017, the Supervisory Board (as defined below in C.1) appointed
Mr César Flores Rodríguez as a new member of the Management Board (as
defined below in C.1). Mr Flores Rodríguez took up his activity for us in March
2018.
In the three-month period ended 31 March 2018, our business and revenue de-
veloped in line with our expectations. We expect the positive momentum of our
business to be reflected in our revenue and number of seats, but, in line with our
strategic focus on growth, not in our net income, as of and for the three month
period ended 31 March 2018. The positive momentum in our business is contin-
uing in April 2018.

SECTION E - OFFER

The Company will only receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the
sale of the New Shares. The Company will not receive any proceeds from the
sale of the Sale Shares from the holdings of the Selling Shareholders or Over-
Allotment Shares from the holdings of the Lending Shareholders.

proceeds.

The Company is targeting gross proceeds of EUR 50 million from the sale of
the New Shares and, consequently, will issue the number of New Shares
required to arrive at such amount of gross proceeds. Accordingly, assuming a
price at which the Offer Shares are sold to investors (the "Offer Price") at the
high end of the price range of EUR 15.60 to EUR 19.60 per Offer Share within
which purchase orders may be placed (the "Price Range"), the Company would
issue 2,551,020 New Shares, assuming an Offer Price at the mid-point of the
Price Range, the Company would issue 2,840,909 New Shares, and assuming an
Offer Price at the low end of the Price Range, the Company would issue
3,205,128 New Shares.

The Selling Shareholders are targeting gross proceeds of EUR 70 million from
the sale of the Sale Shares and, consequently, will sell the number of Sale
Shares required to arrive at such amount of gross proceeds. Accordingly,
assuming an Offer Price at the high end of the Price Range, the Selling
Shareholders would sell 3,571,428 Sale Shares, assuming an Offer Price at the
mid-point of the Price Range, the Selling Shareholders would sell 3,977,272
Sale Shares, and assuming an Offer Price at the low end of the Price Range, the
Selling Shareholders would sell 4,487,179 Sale Shares.

Assuming gross proceeds to the Company of EUR 50 million, the costs of the
Offering to be borne by the Company would amount to approximately
EUR 2.72 million, and the net proceeds to the Company would amount to
approximately EUR 47.3 million.

Assuming gross proceeds to the Selling Shareholders of EUR 70 million the
costs of the Offering to be borne by the Selling Shareholders would amount to
approximately EUR 6.86 million (assuming an exit-bonus payable to the
members of the Management Board in the amount of approximately EUR 3.42
million calculated on the basis of an Offer Price at the mid-point of the Price
Range), and the net proceeds to the Selling Shareholders would amount to
approximately EUR 63.14 million.

The Company estimates that the gross proceeds to the Lending Shareholders
(assuming placement of a number of Over-Allotment Shares corresponding to
15 % of the aggregate number of the New Shares and the Sale Shares sold in the
Offering and exercise of the Greenshoe Option (as defined below in E.3) for a
corresponding number of Shares) would amount to EUR 18 million, the costs of
the Offering to be borne by the Lending Shareholders would amount to
approximately EUR 0.89 million and the net proceeds to the Lending
Shareholders would amount to approximately EUR 17.11 million.

Assuming gross proceeds to the Company of EUR 50 million, to the Selling
Shareholders of EUR 70 million and to the Lending Shareholders of EUR 18
million, the Company estimates that the total gross proceeds of the Offering

would amount to approximately EUR 138 million, the total costs of the Offering
would amount to approximately EUR 10.47 million and the total net proceeds
of the Offering would amount to approximately EUR 127.53 million.

The costs of the Company, the Selling Shareholders and the Lending
Shareholders related to the Offering and listing of the Company's entire share
capital are expected to total approximately EUR 10.47 million (assuming gross
proceeds to the Company of EUR 50 million, to the Selling Shareholders of
EUR 70 million and to the Lending Shareholders of EUR 18 million).

Reasons f
offering.

The Selling Shareholders intend to pursue the Offering to partially divest their
stake in the Company and to ensure sufficient free float and trading liquidity in
the Shares.

Moreover, the Lending Shareholders intend to make part of their Shares
available as securities loans to the Stabilisation Manager (as defined below in
E.3), for the account of the Underwriters, to facilitate stabilisation measures. To
the extent that the Greenshoe Option (as defined below in E.3) is exercised, the
Lending Shareholders will partially divest their shareholdings in the Company.

The Company currently intends to use the net proceeds of the Offering attribut-
able to the Company as follows:
Use of proceeds.

   approximately EUR 15 million to 20 million on the regional expansion of
    our business to leverage on our proven market entry strategy to enter addi-
    tional European markets with a particular focus on France, Italy, Belgium
    and Luxembourg and expand our business in the Netherlands;
   approximately EUR 10 million to 15 million for R&D activities pertaining
    to product development with the aim of rolling-out additional services and
    solutions and developing open application programming interfaces
    ("APIs") to allow for broad access to third party solutions;
   approximately EUR 10 million to 15 million for marketing activities aimed
    at increasing the penetration of existing customers and attracting new cus-
    tomers in the markets in which we are already present; and
   approximately EUR 5 million to 10 million for possible mergers and acqui-

are not fully consumed for the above purposes, the Company intends to use any

net proceeds from the Offering to the Company of approximately EUR 47.3
million.

the terms and

The Offering consists of (i) public offerings of the Offer Shares in Germany and
the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg ("Luxembourg") and (ii) private placements
of the Offer Shares in certain jurisdictions outside Germany and Luxembourg.
In the United States of America (the "United States") the Offer Shares will be
offered for sale only to qualified institutional buyers ("Qualified Institutional
Buyers" or "QIBs") as defined in, and in reliance on, Rule 144A ("Rule 144A")
under the United States Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the "Securities
Act"). Outside the United States, the Offer Shares are being offered in offshore
transactions in compliance with Regulation S under the Securities Act
("Regulation S"). The Offer Shares have not been and will not be registered
under the Securities Act, or with any securities regulatory authority of any state
or other jurisdiction in the United States.
conditions of the
offer.
Offer period

The period during which investors may submit purchase orders for the Offer
Shares is expected to begin on 25 April 2018, and is expected to end on 8 May
2018 (the "Offer Period"). On the last day of the Offer Period, offers to
purchase may be submitted (i) until 12:00 noon (Central European Summer
Time) ("CEST") by retail investors and (ii) until 14:00 (CEST) by institutional
investors.
Price Range

The Price Range set for the Offering of the Offer Shares within which purchase
orders may be placed is EUR 15.60 to EUR 19.60 per Offer Share.
Offer Price

Once the Offer Period has expired, the Offer Price, the final number of New
Shares and the final number of Offer Shares will be determined jointly by the
Company, the Selling Shareholders and the Sole Global Coordinator, acting on
behalf of the Underwriters, using the order book prepared during the
bookbuilding process. This is expected to take place on or about 8 May 2018.

The final number of New Shares, the final number of Offer Shares and the Offer
Price are expected to be published on or about 8 May 2018 by means of ad-hoc
announcements in various media distributed across the entire European
Economic Area ("EEA") (Medienbündel) and on the Company's website
(ir.nfon.com).
Amendments to the terms of the Offering

The Company and the Sole Global Coordinator, acting on behalf of the
Underwriters, reserve the right to increase or decrease the total number of Offer
Shares, to increase or decrease the upper limit and/or the lower limit of the Price
Range and/or to extend or shorten the Offer Period. Changes in the number of
Offer Shares, changes to the Price Range or the extension or shortening of the
Offer Period will not invalidate any offers to purchase that have already been
submitted. If the number of Offer Shares, the Price Range and/or the Offering
Period (collectively the "Offering Terms") is or are, as the case may be,
changed, the change will be announced on the website of the Company
1s

(ir.nfon.com) and be published via various media distributed across the entire
EEA (Medienbündel). To the extent required under the German Securities
Prospectus Act (Wertpapierprospektgesetz), a supplement to the Prospectus will
be submitted to the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority
(Bundesanstalt für Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht – "BaFin") and published after
being approved by the BaFin on the website of the Company (ir.nfon.com). Any
changes of the Offering Terms will also be published by way of an ad-hoc
announcement via an electronic dissemination system, if required under Article
17 of the Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 of the European Parliament and of the
Council of 16 April 2014 on market abuse (market abuse regulation) ("MAR").
Investors will not be notified individually. Under the German Securities
Prospectus Act (Wertpapierprospektgesetz), investors that have submitted a
purchase order before a supplement is published have the right to revoke their
purchase order within two business days after publication of the supplement.
The revocation does not require any statement of grounds and is to be declared
in text form to the person designated in the supplement as recipient of the
revocation. Alternatively, investors that have submitted purchase orders prior to
the publication of the supplement may, within two days after the publication of
the supplement, change their purchase orders or submit new limited or
unlimited purchase orders. Under certain conditions, the Sole Global
Coordinator, acting on behalf of the Underwriters, may terminate the
underwriting agreement, dated 24 April 2018, among the Company, the Selling
Shareholders, the Lending Shareholders and the Underwriters (the
"Underwriting Agreement"), even after commencement of trading (Aufnahme
des Handels) of the Shares on the regulated market segment (regulierter Markt)
of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse).
Delivery and Payment

The delivery of the Offer Shares against payment of the Offer Price and
customary securities commissions (Effektenprovisionen) payable to the
depositary banks is expected to take place on 8 May 2018. The Offer Shares
will be made available to the shareholders as co-ownership interests
(Miteigentumsanteile) in the respective global share certificate deposited with
Clearstream.
Stabilisation Measures, Over Allotments and Greenshoe Option

In connection with the placement of the Offer Shares, Berenberg, acting for the
account of the Underwriters, will act as the stabilisation manager (the "Stabili-
sation Manager") and may, as Stabilisation Manager, and acting in accordance
with legal requirements (Article 5 para. 4 and 5 MAR in conjunction with Arti-
cles 5 through 8 of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1052),
make over-allotments and take stabilisation measures to support the market
price of the Shares and thereby counteract any selling pressure.

The Stabilisation Manager is under no obligation to take any stabilisation
measures. Therefore, stabilisation may not necessarily occur and may cease at
any time without prior notice. Such measures may be taken on the Frankfurt
Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) from the date when trading in
the shares of the Company is commenced on the regulated market segment
(regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpa-
pierbörse) and must be terminated no later than 30 calendar days after this date
(the "Stabilisation Period").

Stabilisation transactions aim at supporting the market price of the Shares dur-
ing the Stabilisation Period. These measures may result in the market price of
the Shares being higher than would otherwise have been the case. Moreover, the
market price may temporarily be at an unsustainable level.

Under the possible stabilisation measures, investors may, in addition to the New
Shares and the Sale Shares, be allocated up to 1,153,846 Over-Allotment Shares
as part of the allocation of the Offer Shares (the "Over-Allotment"). For the
purpose of such a potential Over-Allotment, the Stabilisation Manager, for the

account of the Underwriters, will be provided with 1,153,846 existing shares
from the holdings of the Lending Shareholders in the form of a securities loans.
The total number of Over-Allotment Shares will not exceed 15 % of the sum of
the final number of placed New Shares and Sale Shares. In connection with the
Over-Allotment, the Lending Shareholders will grant the Underwriters an op-
tion to acquire up to 1,153,846 additional Shares from the Lending Shareholders
at the Offer Price less agreed commissions, costs and expenses (the "Greenshoe
Option"), for the sole purpose of enabling the Stabilisation Manager to perform
the Underwriters' redelivery obligations under the securities loans concluded
with the Lending Shareholders. The Greenshoe Option may be exercised only
during the Stabilisation Period.

The Stabilisation Manager, for the account of the Underwriters, is entitled to
exercise the Greenshoe Option to the extent Over-Allotments were initially
made; the number of shares is to be reduced by the number of shares held by the
Stabilisation Manager as of the date on which the Greenshoe Option is exer-
cised and that were acquired by the Stabilisation Manager in the context of
stabilisation measures.

Within one week of the end of the Stabilisation Period, the Stabilisation Manag-
er will ensure adequate public disclosure as to whether stabilisation was under-
taken, the date on which stabilisation started and last occurred, and the price
range within which stabilisation was carried out (for each of the dates during
which stabilisation transactions were carried out) and the trading venue(s) on
which the stabilisation transactions were carried out, where applicable.

Exercise of the Greenshoe Option will be disclosed to the public promptly,
together with all appropriate details, including in particular the date of exercise
of the Greenshoe Option and the number and nature of securities involved in
accordance with Article 8 of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU)
2016/1052.

Zusammenfassungen bestehen aus den geforderten Offenlegungspflichten, den sogenannten Punkten ("Punkte").

enthält alle Punkte, die in eine Zusammenfassung für diese Art von Wertpapier und Emittentin aufzunehmen
sind. Da einige Punkte nicht aufgenommen werden müssen, kann es Lücken in der Reihenfolge der Nummerie-
rung der Punkte geben. Auch wenn ein Punkt aufgrund der Art des Wertpapiers und der Emittentin möglicher-
weise in die Zusammenfassung aufzunehmen ist, besteht die Möglichkeit, dass zu diesem Punkt keine relevanten
Angaben gemacht werden können. In diesem Fall wird eine kurze Beschreibung des Punktes mit dem Hinweis
"entfällt" aufgenommen.

Wir bieten die NFON-Cloud-Telefonanlage für Unternehmen jeder Größe an.
Unser Kundenstamm reicht von Kunden mit kleinen Büros/Home Offices (small
office/home office; "SoHos") bis zu großen Unternehmen. Wir treten mit einer
Mehrkanalvertriebsstrategie an sie heran. Neben unserem Direktvertrieb verfügen
wir über ein Netzwerk von mehr als 1.100 (Stand 31. März 2018) Distributoren
und Handelspartner. Darüber hinaus vertreiben unsere Großhandelspartner, wie
die Deutsche Telekom (einschließlich ihres Tochterunternehmens T-Systems),
Chess Communication, Telefónica Deutschland und Sunrise, unsere Cloud-
Telefonanlage als White Label-Produkt oder auf der Grundlage eines gemein-
schaftlichen Markenauftritts.

Mit Büros in Berlin, Greven, Madrid, Mainz, München, St. Pölten und Uxbridge
agieren wir auf 13 europäischen Märkten. Dazu zählen. Österreich, Deutschland,
die Niederlande, Polen, Portugal, Spanien und das Vereinigte Königreich. Im
Jahre 2017 haben wir 72 % unserer Umsatzerlöse auf unserem IFRS Segment
Deutschland, 14 % im IFRS Segment Vereinigtes Königreich und 12 % in unse-
rem IFRS Segment Österreich (einschließlich Osteuropa), vor Überleitung erwirt-
schaftet. Wir haben die Absicht, mit unserem Kernprodukt, der auf die Bedürfnis-
se europäischer Kunden zugeschnittenen NFON-Cloud-Telefonanlage, und unse-
rer bewährten Markteintrittsstrategie erfolgreich in weitere europäische Märkte
vorzudringen, wobei ein besonderer Schwerpunkt auf Frankreich, Italien, Belgien,
und Luxemburg sowie der Ausweitung der Geschäfte in den Niederlanden liegt.

Mit Umsatzerlösen von TEUR 20.951, TEUR 30.388 (einschließlich eines Son-
dereffekts durch einmalige Dienstleistungsumsätze von TEUR 1.500, die im Zu-
sammenhang mit dem Eingehen einer Großhandelspartnerschaft generiert wur-
den) und TEUR 35.654 in den Geschäftsjahren 2015, 2016 und 2017 haben wir in
jüngster Zeit ein erhebliches Wachstum von 45,04 % bzw. 17,33 % gegenüber
dem Vorjahr verzeichnen können und wurden mit dem Frost & Sullivan Growth
Excellence Leadership Award 2017 für den Sektor gehostete IP3-Telefonie und
UCaaS4 Industrie in Europa ausgezeichnet.

Wir verzeichneten Jahresfehlbeträge in Höhe von TEUR 6.054, TEUR 1.548 und
TEUR 2.021 jeweils in den Geschäftsjahren 2015, 2016 und 2017.

                      rung von neuen Plattformen.

                  Grundsätzlich erzielen wir Umsatzerlöse mit der Erbringung von Telefoniedienst-
Finanzlage und
                  leistungen. Die meisten unserer Verträge beziehen sich auf Telefoniedienstleis-
des Betriebser-
                  tungen mit oder ohne Verkauf von Hardware und anderen Dienstleistungen. Im
gebnisses   der
                  Jahr 2017 stiegen unsere Umsatzerlöse um 17.33 % von TEUR 30.388 im Jahr
Emittentin.
                  2016 auf TEUR 35.654 im Jahr 2017. Der Anstieg der Umsatzerlöse beruhte
                  vorwiegend auf der Akquise neuer Kunden und einem Anstieg der Zahl der An-
                  schlüsse unseres bestehenden Kundenstamms, insbesondere in Deutschland, dem
                  Vereinigten Königreich und Österreich. Der Vorstand ist der Auffassung, dass das
                  Wachstum unserer Kundenbasis sowohl auf unsere eigenen Vertriebs- und Mar-
                  ketinganstrengungen, wie auch auf einen Markttrend hin zu sog. "Multi-Tenant"
                  Telefonanlagen zurückzuführen ist. Die Gesamtanzahl an Nebenstellen, wuchs
                  von 191.977 Nebenstellen im Jahr 2016 auf 253.360 Nebenstellen in 2017, was
                  einem Anstieg um 31,97 % entspricht. Dies bringt zum Ausdruck, dass die An-
                  zahl der Nebenstellen, die wir verloren haben, durch die Nebenstellen neuer Kun-
                  den und die neuen Nebenstellen von Kunden, die bereits zu Beginn des Jahres
                  Kunden waren, mehr als ausgeglichen wurden. Wiederkehrende Umsatzerlöse
                  betrugen 77,87 % unserer gesamten Umsatzerlöse im Jahr 2017, im Vergleich zu
                  71,10 % in 2016, wohingegen die nicht wiederkehrenden Umsatzerlöse 22,13 %
                  im Jahr 2017 betrugen, im Vergleich zu 28,90 % im Jahr 2016. Im Jahr 2016
                  wurden, im Zusammenhang mit dem Aufbau einer Partnerschaft mit einem Groß-
                  händler, TEUR 1.500 nicht wiederkehrende Umsatzerlöse einschließlich Dienst-
                  leistungsumsätze generiert. Ohne diesen außerordentlichen Effekt, hätten wieder-
                  kehrende Umsatzerlöse 74,79 % der gesamten Umsätze im Jahr 2016 betragen.
                  Diese Umsatzsteigerung im Jahr 2017 spiegelt das erfolgreiche Wachstum unse-
                  res Geschäfts mit unseren bestehenden Kunden wieder.

Im Jahr 2017 belief sich unser EBITDA auf TEUR -1.028 im Vergleich zu
TEUR -718 im Jahr 2016, hauptsächlich aufgrund von Kosten, die zur Vorberei-
tung des Angebots eingegangen wurden, und einmaliger Aufwendungen für Steu-
er- und Sozialversicherungsangelegenheiten5. Entsprechende Kosten fielen im
Jahr 2016 nicht an. Ohne diese Kosteneffekte beliefe sich unser EBITDA im Jahr
2017 auf TEUR 173.
2016 im Vergleich zu 2015

Die Umsatzerlöse stiegen deutlich um 45,04 % von TEUR 20.951 im Jahr 2015
auf TEUR 30.388 im Jahr 2016. Der Anteil der wiederkehrenden Umsatzerlöse an
den gesamten Umsatzerlösen betrug 72,50 % im Jahr 2015, verglichen mit
71,10 % im Jahr 2016, während der Anteil nicht wiederkehrenden Umsatzerlöse
27,50 % im Jahr 2015 und 28,90 % im Jahr 2016 betrug. Der leichte Rückgang
des prozentualen Anteils der wiederkehrenden Umsatzerlöse an den gesamten
Umsatzerlösen resultiert aus den außerordentlichen Auswirkungen der nicht wie-
derkehrenden Umsatzerlöse aus Dienstleistungen in Höhe von TEUR 1.500, wel-
cher im Zusammenhang mit dem Aufbau einer Partnerschaft mit einem Groß-
händler im Jahr 2016 generiert worden ist. Ohne diesen Effekt hätte der prozentu-
ale Anteil der wiederkehrenden Umsatzerlöse an den gesamten Umsatzerlösen
74,79 % betragen. Dies ist auf die Zunahme der durchschnittlichen Anzahl an
Nebenstellen pro Kunde zurückzuführen.
Im Jahr 2016 belief sich unser EBITDA auf TEUR -718 im Vergleich zu TEUR -
5.606 im Jahr 2015. Dieser Verbesserung liegt eine proportional höhere Steige-

Regulatorische und rechtliche Risiken

Wir unterliegen umfassender Regulierung, die unser Geschäft weiterhin
beeinflussen wird.
Das europäische Regelwerk zum Datenschutz wird sich erheblich ändern,
was nachteilige Auswirkungen auf unseren Geschäftsbetrieb haben könnte.
Rechtliche, gerichtliche oder verwaltungstechnische Änderungen im Be-
reich der Datenspeicherung könnten zu erheblichen Zusatzkosten für uns
führen.
Der vorgeschlagene neue europäische Kommunikationskodex hat mög-
licherweise nachteilige Auswirkungen auf unseren Geschäftsbetrieb.
Anfragen von Strafverfolgungsbehörden nachzukommen und Gesetze zu
Datenoffenlegung und rechtmäßiger Telekommunikationsüberwachung
einzuhalten, ist kostspielig und schwierig und könnte uns widersprüchliche
Verpflichtungen auferlegen und zu einer unangemessenen Auslegung und
Anwendung komplexer Gesetze führen.

ktien und dem Angebot

pieren eigen sind

der Gesellschaft höhere Kosten entstehen und ihre Geschäftsleitung wird
viel Zeit für zusätzliche Maßnahmen zur Einhaltung von Rechtsvorschrif-
ten und für die Erfüllung zusätzlicher rechtlicher, aufsichtsrechtlicher und
verwaltungstechnischer Vorgaben aufwenden müssen. Eine Nichterfüllung
dieser Vorgaben durch die Gesellschaft schädigt möglicherweise unseren
Ruf und kann eine Investition in die Angebotsaktien beeinträchtigen.
Der Aktienkurs könnte erheblich schwanken und Anleger könnten die
Gesamtheit oder einen Teil ihrer Anlage verlieren.
Künftige Angebote von Eigenkapitalinstrumenten der Gesellschaft könn-
ten nachteilige Auswirkungen auf den Börsenkurs der Aktien haben und
künftige Kapitalmaßnahmen könnten die Beteiligungen der bestehenden
Aktionäre der Gesellschaft erheblich verwässern.
Möglicherweise findet das Angebot nicht statt und Anleger könnten bereits
gezahlte Wertpapierkommissionen verlieren und tragen das Risiko, Leer-
verkäufe von Aktien nicht eindecken zu können.
Eine Investition in die Aktien durch einen Anleger, dessen Hauptwährung
nicht der Euro ist, wird möglicherweise durch Wechselkursschwankungen
beeinträchtigt.
ABSCHNITT E - ANGEBOT
Gesamtnet-

Die Gesellschaft erhält nur die Erlöse, die aus der Veräußerung der Neuen Aktien
im Rahmen des Angebots erzielt werden. Die Gesellschaft erhält keine Erlöse aus
der Veräußerung der Verkaufsaktien aus dem Bestand der Verkaufenden Aktionä-
re oder der Mehrzuteilungsaktien aus dem Bestand der Verleihenden Aktionäre.
toerlöse

Die Gesellschaft strebt durch den Verkauf der Neuen Aktien einen Bruttoerlös
von EUR 50 Mio. an und wird folglich die Anzahl an Neuen Aktien, die erforder-
lich ist, um einen entsprechenden Bruttoerlös zu erreichen, ausgeben. Unter der
Annahme eines Preises zu dem die Angebotsaktien an die Investoren veräußert
werden (der "Angebotspreis") am oberen Ende der Preisspanne, innerhalb derer
Kaufangebote platziert werden können, von EUR 15,60 bis EUR 19,60 je Ange-
botsaktie (die "Preisspanne"), würde die Gesellschaft daher 2.551.020 Neue
Aktien, zum Mittelwert der Preisspanne 2.840.909 Neue Aktien und am unteren
Ende der Preisspanne 3.205.128 Neue Aktien ausgeben.

Die Verkaufenden Aktionäre streben durch den Verkauf der Verkaufsaktien einen
Bruttoerlös von EUR 70 Mio. an und werden folglich die Anzahl an Verkaufsak-
tien, die erforderlich ist, um einen entsprechenden Bruttoerlös zu erreichen, ver-
kaufen. Unter der Annahme eines Angebotspreises am oberen Ende der Preis-
spanne, würden die Verkaufenden Aktionäre daher 3.571.428 Verkaufsaktien,
zum Mittelwert der Preisspanne 3.977.272 Verkaufsaktien und am unteren Ende
der Preisspanne 4.487.179 Verkaufsaktien verkaufen.

Unter der Annahme von der Gesellschaft zufließenden Bruttoerlöse in Höhe von
EUR 50 Mio., würden die von der Gesellschaft zu tragenden Kosten des Ange-
bots rund EUR 2,72 Mio. und die Nettoerlöse rund EUR 47,3 Mio. betragen.

Unter der Annahme, dass den Verkaufenden Aktionären Bruttoerlöse in Höhe von
EUR 70 Mio. zufließen, würden die von den Verkaufenden Aktionären zu tragen-
den Kosten des Angebots (basierend auf der Annahme eines an die Mitglieder des
Vorstands zu zahlenden Exit-Bonus in Höhe von rund EUR 3,42 Mio., der auf der
Basis eines Angebotspreises zum Mittelwert der Preisspanne errechnet wurde)
rund EUR 6,86 Mio., und die den Verkaufenden Aktionären zufließenden Netto-
erlöse rund EUR 63,14 Mio. betragen.

spricht und der Ausübung der Greenshoe-Option (wie unten unter E.3 definiert) in

Das Angebot besteht (i) aus einem öffentlichen Angebot der Angebotsaktien in
Deutschland und dem Großherzogtum Luxemburg ("Luxemburg") sowie (ii) aus
Privatplatzierungen der Angebotsaktien in bestimmten Jurisdiktionen außerhalb
Deutschlands und Luxemburgs. In den Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika (die
"Vereinigten Staaten") werden die Angebotsaktien ausschließlich qualifizierten
institutionellen Anlegern ("Qualified Institutional Buyers" – "QIBs"), unter
Berufung auf und wie in Rule 144A ("Rule 144A") des U.S. Securities Act von
1933 definiert in der derzeit gültigen Fassung (der "Securities Act"), angeboten.
Außerhalb der Vereinigten Staaten werden die Angebotsaktien in Offshore Trans-
aktionen gemäß Regulation S nach dem Securities Act ("Regulation S") angebo-
ten. Die Angebotsaktien wurden nicht und werden nicht gemäß dem Securities
Act oder durch eine Wertpapieraufsichtsbehörde eines Staates oder einer anderen
Jurisdiktion der Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika registriert.
konditionen.
Angebotsfrist

Der Zeitraum, in dem Anleger Kaufangebote für die Angebotsaktien abgeben
können, beginnt am 25. April 2018, und wird voraussichtlich am 8. Mai 2018
enden (der "Angebotszeitraum"). Am letzten Tag des Angebotszeitraums kön-
nen Kaufangebote (i) bis 12:00 Uhr (mitteleuropäische Sommerzeit) ("MESZ")
von privaten Anlegern und (ii) bis 14:00 Uhr (MESZ) von institutionellen Anle-
gern abgegeben werden.
Preisspanne

Die Preisspanne für das Angebot der Angebotsaktien, innerhalb derer Kaufange-
bote abgegeben werden können, liegt bei EUR 15,60 bis EUR 19,60 je Angebots-
aktie.
Angebotspreis

Sobald der Angebotszeitraum beendet ist, werden der Angebotspreis, die endgül-
tige Anzahl der Neuen Aktien und die endgültige Anzahl der Angebotsaktien von
der Gesellschaft, den Verkaufenden Aktionären und dem Sole Global Coordina-
tor, handelnd im Namen der Konsortialbanken, unter Zuhilfenahme des Order-
buchs, das während des Bookbuildings-Verfahrens erstellt wurde, festgelegt wer-
den. Dies wird voraussichtlich am oder um den 8. Mai 2018 erfolgen.

Die endgültige Anzahl der Neuen Aktien, der Angebotsaktien und der Angebots-
preis werden voraussichtlich am oder um den 8. Mai 2018 durch Ad hoc-
Mitteilungen in verschiedenen Medien, die über den gesamten Europäischen
Wirtschaftsraum ("EWR") verbreitet werden (Medienbündel), sowie auf der
Webseite der Gesellschaft (ir.nfon.com) veröffentlicht.
Änderungen der Angebotsbedingungen

Die Gesellschaft, zusammen mit dem Sole Global Coordinator, handelnd im Na-
men der Konsortialbanken, behält sich vor, die Gesamtzahl der Angebotsaktien zu
erhöhen oder zu senken, das obere und/oder das untere Limit der Preisspanne zu
erhöhen oder zu senken und/oder den Angebotszeitraum zu verlängern oder zu
verkürzen. Änderungen in der Anzahl der Angebotsaktien, in der Preisspanne
oder die Verlängerung oder Verkürzung des Angebotszeitraums haben keinen
Einfluss auf die Gültigkeit bis dahin abgegebener Kaufangebote. Sofern die An-
zahl der Angebotsaktien, die Preisspanne und/oder der Angebotszeitraum (ge-
meinsam die "Angebotsbedingungen") gegebenenfalls geändert wird oder wer-
den, werden diese Änderungen auf der Webseite der Gesellschaft (ir.nfon.com)
und über verschiedene Medien über den gesamten EWR verbreitet werden (Medi-
enbündel). Soweit es gemäß Wertpapierprospektgesetz erforderlich sein sollte,
würde ein Nachtrag des Prospekts bei der Bundesanstalt für Finanzdiensleis-
tungsaufsicht ("BaFin") eingereicht werden und nach Billigung durch die BaFin
auf der Webseite der Gesellschaft (ir.nfon.com) veröffentlicht werden. Jegliche
Änderungen der Angebotsbedingungen werden des Weiteren im Wege einer Ad-
hoc Mitteilung über elektronische Übertragungsmedien veröffentlicht, sofern dies
nach Artikel. 17 der Verordnung (EU) Nr. 596/2014 des Europäischen Parlaments
und des Rates vom 16. April 2014 über Marktmissbrauch (Marktmissbrauchsver-
ordnung) ("MAR") erforderlich sein sollte. Anleger werden nicht individuell
benachrichtigt. Gemäß Wertpapierprospektgesetz haben Anleger, die ihre Kauf-
order vor Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags abgegeben haben, das Recht ihre Kauf-
order, innerhalb von zwei Geschäftstagen nach der Veröffentlichung des Nach-
trags, zu widerrufen. Der Widerruf erfordert keine Begründung und muss in Text-
form an jene Person gerichtet werden, die im Nachtrag als Empfänger für Wider-
rufe bestimmt wurde. Alternativ können Anleger, die ihre Kauforder vor Veröf-
fentlichung des Nachtrags abgegeben haben, innerhalb von zwei Geschäftstagen
nach Veröffentlichung des Nachtrags, ihre Kauforder ändern oder neue be-
schränkte oder unbeschränkte Kauforder abgeben. Unter bestimmten Bedingun-
gen kann der Sole Global Coordinator, handelnd im Namen der Konsortialban-
ken, vom Übernahmevertrag, der mit der Gesellschaft, den Verkaufenden Aktio-
nären und den Verleihenden Aktionären und den Konsortialbanken am 24. April
2018 geschlossen wurde (der "Übernahmevertrag"), zurücktreten, selbst nach
Aufnahme des Handels der Aktien der Gesellschaft im regulierten Markt der
Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse.
Lieferung und Zahlung

Die Angebotsaktien werden gegen Zahlung des Angebotspreises und Zahlung der
marktüblichen Effektprovisionen an die Depotbanken voraussichtlich am 8. Mai
2018 geliefert. Die Angebotsaktien werden den Aktionären als Miteigentumsan-
teile an der Globalurkunde, die bei Clearstream hinterlegt ist, bereitgestellt.

Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen, Mehrzuteilungen und Greenshoe-Option
Im Zusammenhang mit der Platzierung der Angebotsaktien wird Berenberg für
die Rechnung der Konsortialbanken als Stabilisierungsmanager (der "Stabilisie-
rungsmanager") handeln und kann als solcher und in Übereinstimmung mit den
rechtlichen Bestimmungen (Artikel 5 Abs. 4 und 5 MAR in Verbindung mit Arti-
kel 5 bis 8 der delegierten Verordnung der Kommission (EU) 2016/1052), Mehr-
zuteilungen vornehmen und Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen ergreifen, um den Markt-
preis der Aktien der Gesellschaft zu stützen und dadurch einem etwaigem Ver-
kaufsdruck entgegenzuwirken.

Der Stabilisierungsmanager ist nicht verpflichtet, Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen
durchzuführen. Daher muss Stabilisierung nicht unbedingt erfolgen und kann
jederzeit ohne Vorankündigung beendet werden. Solche Maßnahmen können an
der Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse ab dem Zeitpunkt der Aufnahme des Börsenhan-
dels der Aktien der Gesellschaft am regulierten Markt der Frankfurter Wertpa-
pierbörse vorgenommen werden und müssen spätestens am 30. Kalendertag nach
diesem Zeitpunkt beendet sein (der "Stabilisierungszeitraum").

Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen sind auf eine Stützung des Marktpreises der Aktien
während des Stabilisierungszeitraums gerichtet. Diese Maßnahmen können dazu
führen, dass der Marktpreis der Aktien höher ist, als er es ohne diese sein würde.
Darüber hinaus könnte sich der Marktpreis zeitweise auf einem nicht nachhaltigen
Niveau bewegen.

Im Hinblick auf mögliche Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen können Anlegern, zusätz-
lich zu den Neuen Aktien und Verkaufsaktien bis zu 1.153.846 Mehrzuteilungs-
aktien als Teil der Zuteilung der Angebotsaktien zugeteilt werden (die "Mehrzu-
teilung"). Zum Zwecke einer solchen potentiellen Mehrzuteilung werden dem
Stabilisierungsmanager für Rechnung der Konsortialbanken 1.153.846 bestehende
Aktien der Gesellschaft aus dem Aktienbesitz der Verleihenden Aktionäre in
Form von Wertpapierdarlehen zur Verfügung gestellt. Die Gesamtzahl von Mehr-
zuteilungsaktien wird 15 % der endgültigen Anzahl der platzierten Neuen Aktien
und Verkaufsaktien nicht überschreiten. Im Zusammenhang mit der Mehrzutei-
lung werden die Verleihenden Aktionäre den Konsortialbanken eine Option zum
Erwerb von bis zu 1.153.846 zusätzlichen Aktien von den Verleihenden Aktionä-
ren zum Angebotspreis abzüglich der vereinbarten Provisionen, Kosten und Auf-
wendungen (die "Greenshoe-Option") einräumen, mit dem ausschließlichen
Zweck, dass der Stabilisierungsmanager den Rücklieferverpflichtungen der Kon-
sortialbanken unter den Darlehensverträgen mit den Verleihenden Aktionären,
nachkommen kann. Die Greenshoe-Option kann nur während des Stabilisierungs-
zeitraums durchgeführt werden.

Der Stabilisierungsmanager, für Rechnung der Konsortialbanken, ist berechtigt,
aber nicht verpflichtet, die Greenshoe-Option in dem Umfang auszuüben, in dem
ursprünglich Mehrzuteilungen vorgenommen wurden; die Anzahl der Aktien,
muss um die Anzahl der Aktien, die von dem Stabilisierungsmanager zu Datum,
an dem die Greenshoe-Option ausgeübt wurde und die vom Stabilisierungsmana-
ger im Rahmen der Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen gekauft wurden, reduziert werden.

Innerhalb einer Woche nach Beendigung des Stabilisierungszeitraums wird der
Stabilisierungsmanager für eine hinreichende Veröffentlichung Sorge tragen, ob
die Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen vorgenommen wurden, wann die Stabilisierung
begonnen und beendet wurde, und hinsichtlich der Preisspanne innerhalb derer
Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen vorgenommen wurden (für jedes Datum an dem eine
Stabilisierungsmaßnahme ergriffen wurde) und den Handelsplatz, an dem Stabili-
sierungsmaßnahmen vorgenommen wurden.

Die Ausführung der Greenshoe-Option wird unverzüglich mit allen notwendigen
Details, inklusive des spezifischen Datums der Ausübung der Greenshoe-Option
und der Anzahl und der Art der involvierten Wertpapiere gemäß Artikel 8 der
Delegierten Verordnung (EU) 2016/1052 der Kommission, veröffentlicht.

Im Rahmen des Übernahmevertrags haben sich die Verkaufenden Aktionäre, die
Verleihenden Aktionäre und die Mitglieder des Vorstands, hinsichtlich
Angebotsaktien die ihnen auf Basis einer bevorrechtigten Zuteilung zugeteilt
werden, mit den Konsortialbanken geeinigt, dass sie innerhalb eines Zeitraums
endend sechs Monate nach dem Tag, an dem die Aktien zum ersten Mal an der
Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse gehandelt werden (was voraussichtlich am 9. Mai
2018 stattfindet) und danach für einen weiteren Zeitraum von sechs Monaten,
ohne vorherige schriftliche Zustimmung des Sole Global Coordinators (die nicht
unangemessen verweigert oder verzögert werden darf) nicht:

     Aktien oder Wertpapiere der Gesellschaft verkaufen, zuteilen, übertragen
      oder anderweitig veräußern,
     Options- oder Wandlungsrechte auf Aktien der Gesellschaft ausgeben,
      anbieten oder veräußern,
     einer vorgeschlagenen Kapitalerhöhung der Gesellschaft oder der Ausgabe
      von Finanzinstrumenten, die Wandlungs- oder Optionsrechte auf Aktien
      der Gesellschaft beinhalten, zustimmen, oder
     sonstige Transaktionen abschließen oder sonstige Maßnahmen ergreifen,
      die wirtschaftlich einer der vorgenannten Maßnahmen entsprechen.
Der Lock-up für jeden einzelnen Verkaufenden Aktionär und jeden einzelnen
Verleihenden Aktionär findet keine Anwendung auf (i) Veräußerungen von Ak-
tien im Rahmen von öffentlichen Übernahmeangeboten gemäß dem Wertpapier-
erwerbs- und Übernahmegesetz und (ii) Übertragungen auf verbundene Unter-
nehmen der Verkaufenden Aktionäre, vorausgesetzt im Fall (ii), dass der jeweili-
ge Erwerber den Konsortialbanken gegenüber einwilligt, unter demselben Lock-
up gebunden zu sein.

Der Lock-up für die Mitglieder des Vorstands findet in Bezug auf Angebotsak-
tien, die sie im Wege der bevorrechtigten Zuteilung erhalten haben, keine An-
wendung auf Veräußerungen von Aktien im Rahmen von öffentlichen Übernah-
meangeboten gemäß dem Wertpapiererwerbs- und Übernahmegesetz.

Laut dem geprüften konsolidierten Konzernabschluss für das am 31. Dezember
2017 endende Geschäftsjahr betrug der Nettobuchwert der Gesellschaft zum
31. Dezember 2017 TEUR 343. Der Nettobuchwert zum 31. Dezember 2017
entspricht der Bilanzsumme Aktiva von TEUR 9.282 abzüglich der Summe der
langfristigen Verbindlichkeiten von TEUR 266 und der Summe der kurzfristigen
Verbindlichkeiten TEUR 8.673. Der Nettobuchwert je Aktie (auf den
Anteilseigner der Gesellschaft entfallendes Eigenkapital je Aktie), der dem Wert
des Nettobuchwerts geteilt durch die Anzahl der ausstehenden Aktien unmittelbar
vor dem Angebot entspricht, würde EUR 0,04 pro Aktie basierend auf 9.640.150
ausstehenden Aktien vor dem Angebot betragen.

1. RISK FACTORS

An investment in shares of NFON AG, Munich, Germany (the "Company" and, together with its consolidated
subsidiaries, the "Group" or the "NFON Group" or "NFON" or "we", "us", "our", and all shares of the
Company, together, the "Shares" and each share, a "Share") is subject to risks. Prospective investors should
carefully consider the risks discussed below, in addition to the other information contained in this prospectus
(the "Prospectus") as well as their personal circumstances, before making an investment decision with respect to
the Shares. The order in which risks are presented is not necessarily an indication of the likelihood of the risks
actually materialising, of the potential significance of the individual risks or of the scope of any potential harm
to the NFON's business, results of operations, financial position and prospects. The following risk factors are
based on assumptions that could turn out to be incorrect. In addition, other risks and circumstances which we
are currently unaware of or that we currently deem immaterial, alone or together with the following risks, could
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, cash flows, financial position and
prospects.

The occurrence of one or more of these risks, individually or cumulatively, could have a material adverse effect
on the Group's business, results of operations, financial position and prospects. In such a case the value of the
Shares could decline and investors may lose all, or part of their investment.

1.1   Risks Relating to the Company's Business, Operations, Financial Position and
      Industry

We have incurred significant operating losses since inception and there is no guar-
antee that we will be able to successfully grow and operate our business and achieve
or sustain profitability in the future business.

risk_factor: We have incurred significant operating losses since inception and there is no guar-antee that we will be able to successfully grow and operate our business and achieveor sustain profitability in the future business.

blobs.text:
While we have grown significantly in terms of revenue since establishment of the Company in 2007, we have
never recorded a net profit. There is no assurance that we will be able to ever become profitable in terms of net
profit. Our net losses are primarily attributable to the costs associated with expanding our business, including
sales & marketing and research & development ("R&D") expenses. For example, we made significant invest-
ments in connection with our entrance into the market of the United Kingdom ("UK") in 2013 which we expect
to be offset only in the coming years, if at all.

We believe that it is critical for our future success that we expand our market position in Europe. To achieve this
aim, we intend, inter alia, to enter additional European markets, to intensify our activity in the European markets
in which we already operate and to continue to make significant investments into our marketing activities and
distribution infrastructure. In addition, we intend to continue to make significant financial investments into our
R&D activity to further enhance the attractiveness of our service offering by further developing our cloud tele-
phone system, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, and integrating further attractive features and solutions.
These investments will likely, in the short-to-medium term, put further pressure on our profitability, which may
be offset in the future if we are able to scale our business successfully. The pressure on our margins may be
higher than anticipated if the necessary investments prove more costly than we currently expect. There can also
be no assurance that these investments will actually prove successful and/or will enhance our financial results or
that we will be able to successfully scale our business.

Even if we are able to grow the business and benefit from economies of scale, there is still no assurance that we
will achieve net profitability over time. Some of the factors driving our cost base are beyond our control and we
may not be able to recover increased costs through raising the prices charged to our customers.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We rely on third party network operators and other Internet service providers for
the access by our customers to the NFON Cloud Telephone System and the inter-
connection of the NFON Cloud Telephone System to the public switched telephone
networks. Frequent or persistent interruptions of the services of these third parties
could cause current or potential customers to believe that our systems are unrelia-
ble, leading them to avoid our services which could permanently harm our reputa-
tion and brands.

risk_factor: We rely on third party network operators and other Internet service providers forthe access by our customers to the NFON Cloud Telephone System and the inter-connection of the NFON Cloud Telephone System to the public switched telephonenetworks. Frequent or persistent interruptions of the services of these third partiescould cause current or potential customers to believe that our systems are unrelia-ble, leading them to avoid our services which could permanently harm our reputa-tion and brands.

blobs.text:
Similar to other companies in the information and communication technology ("ICT") industry, we are heavily
dependent on certain third-party service providers and suppliers.

Unlike traditional communications services, our services depend on our customers' high-speed broadband access
to the Internet. Our customers ultimately obtain Internet access services from third-party Internet service
providers. In addition, customers who would like to access our services through mobile devices, such as
smartphones and tablets, must have a high-speed connection, such as Wi-Fi, 3G or 4G, to use our services. This
access is also provided by third-party Internet service providers. If these Internet service providers have outages
or deteriorations in their quality of service, our customers will not have access to our services or may experience
a decrease in the quality of our services. Increasing numbers of seats and increasing bandwidth requirements
may degrade the performance of our services due to capacity constraints of the Internet access of our customers
and other Internet infrastructure limitations associated with Internet service providers or more generally.
Furthermore, as the rate of adoption of new technologies increases, cable and telecommunications networks may
not be able to sufficiently adapt to the increased demand for services like ours. Frequent or persistent
interruptions could cause current or potential customers to believe that our systems are unreliable, leading them
to avoid our services. This could permanently harm our reputation and brands. In addition, some Internet and
telecommunications service providers, such as Vodafone, offer services that directly compete with our own
service offering. These providers could take measures that degrade, disrupt or increase the cost of Internet access
services provided to our customers, for example, by restricting, prohibiting or increasing the costs of the use of
their infrastructure to support or facilitate third-party services like ours, which would make our services less
attractive and reduce our revenue. This problem could, in particular, arise in the event the European Union
("EU") moved away from the principle of net neutrality as has recently been the case in the United States.

The NFON Cloud Telephone System includes interconnections with public switched telephone networks
("PSTN"). As we do not have our own telecommunications network, we rely on the ability to interconnect with a
PSTN operator. We source PSTN services from a number of third-party network carriers such as British
Telecom for Germany, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, Telefónica Germany for Germany, Neotel for
Austria and Colt for Austria and Portugal, Orange/Jazztel for Spain and Sunrise for Switzerland to provide call
termination and origination services, the provision and management of telephone numbers, and local number
portability for our customers. We do not have direct control over the quality of their network and the services
they provide to us. Any difficulties or delays in the provision of these services could subject us to damage claims
of our customers, affect our revenue and harm our reputation. Historically, our reliance on third-party PSTNs has
reduced our operating flexibility, for example, with regard to the timely porting of telephone numbers (see "—
1.1.3 If we experience delays in effectively processing local number portability provisioning in a timely manner,
our growth may be negatively affected."). In addition, if any of these third-party network carriers stop providing
us with access to their infrastructure, fail to provide their services to us on a cost-effective basis, ceases
operations, or otherwise terminate their services to us, the delay caused by qualifying and switching to another
third-party PSTN network service provider, if one is available, could have a material adverse effect on our
business and results of operations.

We expect that we will continue to rely on third-party network operators and other Internet service providers for
the access by our customers to the NFON Cloud Telephone System and the interconnection of the NFON Cloud
Telephone System with a PSTN.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

If we experience delays in effectively processing local number portability provision-
ing in a timely manner, our growth may be negatively affected.

risk_factor: If we experience delays in effectively processing local number portability provision-ing in a timely manner, our growth may be negatively affected.

blobs.text:
We support local number portability, which allows our customers to transfer to us and thereby retain their exist-
ing phone numbers when subscribing to our services. Transferring numbers from a previous carrier to a new
carrier can take up to 15 business days or longer to complete. During the number transferring process, our new
customers must maintain both our service and their existing phone service. Any delays that we experience in
transferring phone numbers typically result from the fact that we depend on third-party carriers to transfer these
numbers. We do not control the transfer of phone numbers by third-party carriers, and these third-party carriers

may refuse or substantially delay the transfer of these numbers to us. Local number portability is considered an
important feature by many potential customers, and if we fail to reduce any related delays, we may experience
increased difficulty in acquiring new customers. Moreover, if we, or our third-party carriers, are unable to pro-
cess number portability requests within the requisite timeframes, both customers and carriers may seek relief
before a court or from the relevant public authority for violation of local number portability requirements.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We could infringe emergency services access laws which could result in claims for
damages, regulatory investigations, fines, loss of reputation and customer churn.

risk_factor: We could infringe emergency services access laws which could result in claims fordamages, regulatory investigations, fines, loss of reputation and customer churn.

blobs.text:
In most European countries, providers of publicly available phone services for domestic calls, including us, are
obliged to provide their users with free access to certain emergency services. Due to the complexity of the emer-
gency access laws and its interpretation within the various European countries we cannot provide any assurances
that we are in compliance with all requirements in this regard. In addition, any additional requirements imposed
by a stricter interpretation of the existing requirements or by future modifications of the emergency services
access laws could have a significant impact on our business operations and our ability to market our services to
existing or potential customers. For example, under current German regulations the geographical address of the
caller must be obtainable automatically by the emergency forces. If this is not possible for technical reasons
telecommunications services providers are exempted from this obligation. If such exemption were to be abol-
ished, we, and all other such telecommunications services providers, would not be able to comply with this re-
quirement.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We rely on hardware suppliers and third-party service providers for some of the op-
tional features and solutions of our NFON Cloud Telephone System. If any of these
service providers stop providing us with their services or provide them in a poor
quality, the delay caused by qualifying and switching to another third-party service
provider, if available, or building a proprietary replacement solution could have a
material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

risk_factor: We rely on hardware suppliers and third-party service providers for some of the op-tional features and solutions of our NFON Cloud Telephone System. If any of theseservice providers stop providing us with their services or provide them in a poorquality, the delay caused by qualifying and switching to another third-party serviceprovider, if available, or building a proprietary replacement solution could have amaterial adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

blobs.text:
We currently use third-party service providers to deliver certain optional features of our NFON Cloud Telephone
System and solutions and intend to continue to do so for the foreseeable future. For example, we rely on jtel to
enable the delivery of our contact centre solution, Ncontactcenter, and our call queue monitoring feature is
sourced as a cloud based service from Loway Switzerland. Our voice recording solution, Neorecording,
integrates a software application of ASC Technologies into the NFON Cloud Telephone System.

In addition, we offer a large variety of phones and accessories which we source from certain suppliers and on-
sell to our customers.

If any of these service providers or suppliers elect to stop providing us with access to their services, fail to
provide these services to us on a cost-effective basis, cease operations, or otherwise terminate these services, the
delay caused by qualifying and switching to another supplier or third-party service provider, or, in case of a
third-party service provider, by building a proprietary replacement solution could have a material adverse effect
on our business and results of operations.

Finally, if problems occur with any of these third-party service providers, our customers may experience errors
or poor quality in our service, and we could encounter difficulties identifying the source of the problem. The
occurrence of errors or poor service quality, whether caused by our systems or a third-party service provider,
may result in the loss of our existing customers, delay or loss of market acceptance of our services, or
termination of our relationships and agreements with our dealers. This could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Interruptions or delays in service from our third-party data centre co-location facili-
ties could impair the delivery of our services and harm our business.

risk_factor: Interruptions or delays in service from our third-party data centre co-location facili-ties could impair the delivery of our services and harm our business

blobs.text:
Except for the end-customers of our Swiss wholesale partner, Sunrise, whom we serve from data centres of
Sunrise in Switzerland, we currently serve our customers from geo-redundant servers placed in two data centre
co-location facilities in Munich and Nuremberg, Germany. We rent the necessary space for our own servers and,
the racks the servers are placed in, as well as power supply, fire-prevention, air-conditioning and certain basic

on-premises service support from the owner of the co-location data centre facilities. Any damage to these
facilities or failure of related services could result in interruptions of our service.

As part of our current disaster recovery arrangements, both data centres have virtually the same setup and can
each handle the customer load and customer functionality of all our customers. The data centres are operated in a
so-called "active/active" mode, meaning that 50 % of the customer load is handled by each data centre. The
server and network capacity in each data centre is constantly expanded so that during normal operations the
capacity utilisation of one data centre does not exceed 50 %. As a result, even in the event of a loss of all servers
and network connectivity in one data centre we should have enough spare capacity in the remaining data centre
to handle the load. In case of such a loss, the servers in the other data centre can take over the tasks performed by
way of an automated takeover process.

We do not control the operation of the data centre co-location facilities, and these facilities are vulnerable to
damage or interruption from earthquakes, floods, fires, power loss, telecommunications failures, and events with
similar effects. They may also be subject to break-ins, sabotage, acts of vandalism, and other misconduct with
similar effects. Despite precautions taken at these facilities, the occurrence of a natural disaster or an act of
terrorism or other unanticipated problems at these facilities could result in lengthy interruptions in our service.
Even with the above mentioned disaster recovery arrangements in place, our service could be interrupted if the
takeover process does not work as intended or the other data centre facility is affected by the same event or
experiences a failure at the same time for another reason.

Interruptions in our services may reduce our revenue, require us to make compensation payments to our
customers or pay penalties, subject us to claims and litigation, cause customers to terminate their subscriptions
and adversely affect our churn rate and our ability to attract new customers. Because our ability to attract and
retain customers depends on our ability to provide customers with a highly reliable service, even minor
interruptions in our service could harm our brand and reputation and have a material adverse effect on our
business.

We may also be required to transfer our servers to new data centre co-location facilities in the event that we are
unable to renew our leases on acceptable terms, if at all, or the owners of the facilities decide to close their
facilities, and we may incur significant costs and possible service interruption in connection with doing so. In
addition, any financial difficulties, such as bankruptcy or foreclosure, faced by the owner of the data centre co-
location facilities may have negative effects on our business, the nature and extent of which are difficult to
predict. Additionally, if our existing data centre co-location facilities are unable to keep up with our increasing
needs for capacity, and we are not able to procure space for additional servers at other data centre co-location
facilities, our ability to grow our business could be materially and adversely impacted.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Most of our customers can terminate their subscriptions for our service at any time
without penalty, and any costs we incur to retain our customers and encourage
them to add extensions and, subscribe for additional features and premium solu-
tions, could materially and adversely affect our financial performance.

risk_factor: Most of our customers can terminate their subscriptions for our service at any timewithout penalty, and any costs we incur to retain our customers and encouragethem to add extensions and, subscribe for additional features and premium solu-tions, could materially and adversely affect our financial performance.

blobs.text:
Our customers generally do not have fixed-term contracts with us. They may terminate their subscription, subject
to a 30 days' notice period, or reduce the scope of subscribed services at any time, without penalty or early
termination charges. We have entered into subscription agreements with fixed-terms of two to three years with a
few large customers. However, these large customers only contribute a small portion of our revenue.

Customer churn, as well as reductions in the number of seats for which a customer subscribes, each have a
significant impact on our results of operations, as does the cost we incur in our efforts to retain our customers
and encourage them to upgrade their services and increase their number of seats. Our churn rate could increase in
the future if customers are not satisfied with our service, the value proposition of our services or our ability to
otherwise meet their needs and expectations. Churn and reductions in the number of seats for which a customer
subscribes may also result from factors beyond our control, including the failure or unwillingness of customers
to pay their monthly subscription fees due to financial constraints and the impact of a slowing economy. If we
were to experience churn and reductions in the number of seats for which a customer subscribes, we would be
required to acquire new customers, or acquire new seats within our existing customer base, at the same rate as
the loss simply to maintain our existing level of revenue. If a significant number of customers terminate, reduce
or, as the case may be, fail to renew their subscriptions, we may be required to incur significantly higher
marketing expenditures than we currently anticipate in order to increase the number of new customers or to
upsell existing customers, which would decrease our margins or require us to increase our prices and,
consequently, could harm our business and results of operations.

Our future success also depends in part on our ability to sell additional subscriptions and additional features and
solutions to our current customers. This may also require increasingly sophisticated and more costly sales and
marketing efforts and a longer sales cycle. Any increase in the costs necessary to upgrade, expand and retain
existing customers could materially and adversely affect our financial performance. If our efforts to convince
customers to add seats and to subscribe for additional features and premium solutions are not successful, our
business may suffer. In addition, such increased costs could cause us to increase our subscription rates, which
could increase our churn rate or reduce our ability to attract new customers.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

If we are unable to cost-effectively attract new customers to our services, our busi-
ness will be materially and adversely affected.

risk_factor: If we are unable to cost-effectively attract new customers to our services, our busi-ness will be materially and adversely affected.

blobs.text:
In order to grow our business, we must continue to cost-effectively attract new customers and expand the
number of seats in our existing customer base. We use and periodically adjust the mix of advertising and
marketing programs to promote our services. Significant increases in the pricing of one or more of our
advertising channels would increase our advertising costs or cause us to choose less expensive and perhaps less
effective channels to promote our services. As we add to or change the mix of our advertising and marketing
strategies, we may need to expand into channels with significantly higher costs than our current advertising and
marketing programs, which could materially and adversely affect our results of operations. We will incur
advertising and marketing expenses in advance of when we anticipate recognising any revenue generated by
such expenses, and we may fail to otherwise experience an increase in revenue or brand awareness as a result of
such expenditures. We may make significant expenditures and investments in new advertising campaigns, and
we cannot provide any assurances that any such investments will lead to the cost-effective acquisition of
additional customers. If we are unable to maintain cost-effective advertising and marketing programs, our ability
to attract new customers could be materially and adversely affected, our advertising and marketing expenses
could increase substantially, and our results of operations may suffer.

Some of our potential customers learn about us through well-known search engines, such as Google and Bing.
While we employ search engine optimisation and search engine marketing strategies, our ability to maintain and
increase the number of visitors directed to our website is not entirely within our control. If search engine
companies modify their search algorithms in a manner that reduces the prominence of our listing, or if our
competitors' search engine optimisation efforts are more successful than ours, fewer potential customers may
click through to our website. In addition, the cost of purchased search listings has increased in the past and may
increase in the future. A decrease in website traffic or an increase in search costs could materially and adversely
affect our customer acquisition efforts and our results of operations.

The majority of our customers are small and medium-sized businesses, which may
have fewer financial resources to weather an economic downturn and thus if our
customers experience financial hardship in such an economic downturn this could
lead to an overall reduction in demand for our services which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects.

risk_factor: The majority of our customers are small and medium-sized businesses, which mayhave fewer financial resources to weather an economic downturn and thus if ourcustomers experience financial hardship in such an economic downturn this couldlead to an overall reduction in demand for our services which could have a materialadverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operationsand prospects.

blobs.text:
We generate the majority of our revenue by providing services to small and medium-sized businesses. These
customer groups may be affected by economic downturns to a greater extent than larger, more established
businesses. They also typically have more limited financial resources, including capital-borrowing capacity, than
larger entities. Because a large number of our customers pay via direct debit, weakness in certain segments of the
credit markets and global economies has resulted in and may in the future result in cash flow and profitability
problems for our customers and a corresponding increase in the number of rejected direct debit card payments,
which could materially affect our business by increasing customer cancellations and impacting our ability to
engage new customers. If small and medium-sized businesses experience financial hardship, the overall demand
for our services could be materially and adversely affected which could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We face significant risks in marketing and distributing our services to large cus-
tomers and, if we do not manage these efforts effectively, our business and results of
operations could be materially and adversely affected.

risk_factor: We face significant risks in marketing and distributing our services to large cus-tomers and, if we do not manage these efforts effectively, our business and results ofoperations could be materially and adversely affected.

blobs.text:
We derive only a small portion of our revenue from large customers. However, a part of our sales efforts is also
addressed to such potential customers. With these sales efforts we normally incur higher costs and longer sales
cycles than with smaller customers, as larger organisations typically have more complex decision making

processes requiring the involvement of multiple departments and management levels as compared to smaller
organisations. Moreover, larger organisations often use competitive bidding processes, through which they may
decide to use the services of a competitor.

This has historically resulted in our large customers requiring significantly above-average lead times (as
compared to our other customers) of approximately six to twelve months, or even longer, as well as extensive
sales services support. In addition, our large customers have often required a high degree of customisation,
making the integration of our services into their specific IT environment more complicated. As a result of these
factors, sales opportunities to large customers have normally required us to devote greater resources of sales and
services personnel as well as software engineers and other technical personnel, resulting in increased up-front
costs. This may even require us to hire additional staff to handle customer needs of large organisations. There
can be no assurance that the significant up-front investment involved with targeting large customers will
ultimately translate into revenue that justify the costs incurred. In certain cases, we may not be able to fulfil the
specific requirements of a large enterprise. This may particularly be the case where a large customer decides to
use an on-premise or a single-instance off-premise private branch exchange ("PBX") because of the higher
