degree of control over the PBX and data safety concerns linked with using a multi-tenant off-premise PBX like
ours. Even if a large customer decides to subscribe for our services, the revenue generated by such a subscription
could turn out to be insufficient to fully compensate for the increased customer acquisition costs.

To the extent we are not successful in translating the customer acquisition costs of targeting large businesses into
revenue, such costs will directly reduce our profitability. This could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We rely significantly on a network of distributors and dealers to sell our services
and our business could suffer if we are unable to maintain and expand our distribu-
tion network.

risk_factor: We rely significantly on a network of distributors and dealers to sell our servicesand our business could suffer if we are unable to maintain and expand our distribu-tion network.

blobs.text:
We distribute our services mainly through indirect distribution channels (i.e. our wholesale partners and our
network of approximately 1,100 distributors and dealers (as at 31 March 2018)). The distributors generally do
not market our services themselves, but handle the relationship with dealers distributing our services. While we
work with a large number dealers in the Austrian, German and Polish markets, we rely on very few dealers in
other markets such as Spain and the United Kingdom. In the Netherlands and in Switzerland, we currently work
with only one wholesale partner, respectively. Our future success therefore depends on our ability to maintain
and expand our distribution network in our current markets and establish an efficient distribution network as we
expand our operations into additional European markets. The loss of or reduction in sales through dealers could
materially reduce our revenue.

Our agreements with distributors and dealers provide neither for a fixed contract term, nor for exclusivity. Many
of our dealers sell or may in the future decide to sell services of other cloud PBX services providers. Our
competitors may in some cases be effective in causing our distributors and dealers to favour their services and
prevent or reduce the distribution of our services. If we fail to maintain relationships with our distributors and
dealers, fail to develop relationships with new distributors and dealers in new markets or expand the network of
distributors and dealers in our existing markets, or if we fail to manage, train, or provide appropriate incentives
to our distributors and dealers, or if our dealers are not successful in their sales efforts, sales of our services
could decrease, we could be hindered from further growing our customer base and our results of operations
could suffer.

In case of a termination of the business relationship with any of our distributors or dealers who are considered to
be commercial agents under Section 84 of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch, – "HGB") or
similar regulations in other countries, we may be liable to pay a commercial agent's compensation pursuant to
Section 89b HGB or similar regulations in other countries upon the end of the contractual relationship.

Recruiting and retaining distributors and dealers with the necessary technical and distribution capability in our
network and training the dealers in our services offering requires significant time and resources. To develop and
expand our indirect sales channels, we must continue to scale and improve our processes and procedures to
support these channels, including investment in systems and training. Many dealers may not be willing to invest
the time and resources required to train their staff to effectively market our services. While we are usually
compensated by our dealers for necessary training, there can be no assurance that the investment of time and
resources in such training will yield a level of sales sufficient to offset the costs of such training.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

A termination or failure to renew distribution agreements with wholesale partners
could negatively impact our business.

risk_factor: A termination or failure to renew distribution agreements with wholesale partnerscould negatively impact our business.

blobs.text:
In order to accelerate the expansion of our customer reach, we have distribution agreements with approximately
12 wholesale partners (as at 31 March 2018). Under these agreements, we provide our services to wholesale
partners on a white-label basis, which means that they market our services under their own brands or under a co-
branding of their own brand and our brand to end-customers. Under our distribution partnerships with one
category of wholesale partners, such as Westcoast Limited, we also provide PSTN termination services, while
other wholesale partners, in particular carriers such as Deutsche Telekom (including its subsidiary T-Systems)
and Telefónica Germany, provide PSTN termination services to the end-customers themselves.

The agreements with our wholesale partners normally do not provide for exclusivity except for our wholesale
partner in the Netherlands. Our wholesale partners are, therefore, free to prefer to distribute services of our
competitors over our services. In addition, these agreements do not have a fixed contract term and can be
terminated without cause typically with notice periods of between six weeks and twelve months to the end of a
contractual year. As our wholesale partners hold the contractual relationships with the end-customers, the
termination of a wholesale partnership would mean the loss of customers and seats for us and result in
corresponding losses of revenue. Failure to maintain existing, or attract new, wholesale partners could prevent us
from further growing and diversifying our customer base and increasing our revenue.

Some of our wholesale partners, such as Deutsche Telekom, have developed services that compete with ours.
They could prefer to distribute these services over ours. In addition, we are exposed to the risk that a negative
reputation of our wholesale partner could have a negative impact on the distribution of our services by such a
wholesale partner.

The risks associated with our dependence on wholesale partners could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

A disproportionately high increase in distribution through our wholesale partner
distribution channel would likely decrease our overall gross profit margin.

risk_factor: A disproportionately high increase in distribution through our wholesale partnerdistribution channel would likely decrease our overall gross profit margin.

blobs.text:
In order to accelerate the growth of our customer base, we also distribute our services through wholesale part-
ners. Sales of our services through wholesale partners generally yield a lower gross profit margin for us than
direct sales. We have nevertheless decided to use and intend to increase our distribution through indirect sales
channels, such as our wholesale partners, as we believe that it allows for faster top-line growth without having to
make the up-front investments necessary for direct distribution. We believe that the portion of our services that is
sold to wholesale partners will increase in the future. Investors should be aware that while this may be beneficial
for our top line growth, a disproportionately high increase in distribution through our wholesale partner distribu-
tion channel would likely decrease our gross profit margin, which could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Intense competition in the markets in which we compete could have a negative ef-
fect on our revenue and margins.

risk_factor: Intense competition in the markets in which we compete could have a negative ef-fect on our revenue and margins.

blobs.text:
The cloud communications industry is competitive, and we expect it to become increasingly competitive in the
future.

In the cloud communications industry, we face competition from US providers (e.g. Cisco through its subsidiar-
ies Broadsoft and Placetel, RingCentral, 8x8) and European providers (e.g. easycall, Fuze, Gamma, j2global,
Sipgate, Telecom, Vonage, voz, Voz Telecom and vozelia) of cloud delivery models, known as Unified Com-
munications as a Service ("UCaaS"), that offer a variety of communication and collaboration applications and
services such as enterprise messaging, online meetings, team collaboration, telephony and video conferencing
and cloud PBX services. The large providers in this area are US-based, although they currently have only a small
footprint in continental Europe, such as Cisco through its German subsidiary Placetel, if any. The continental
European and UK cloud PBX markets in which we operate are highly fragmented and heterogeneous. Due to
low language barriers and similar PBX user patterns, US competitors are active in the United Kingdom. There is
a large number of small-scale providers, some of which follow aggressive pricing strategies. Competition from
these providers could increase even further in the future. In addition, we believe that US providers regularly
assess the potential entrance into continental European markets. These US providers could decide to enter the
continental European markets to expand their geographical reach. In such event competitors with greater finan-
cial resources (such as Cisco, RingCentral, 8x8) may adopt more aggressive pricing policies and devote greater
resources to the development, promotion and sale of their services.

resources to the development, promotion and sale of their services.
We may also face competition from large Internet and cloud service companies in adjacent or overlapping indus-
tries such as Google, Amazon, Oracle and Microsoft, any of which may launch a new cloud-based PBX, expand

their existing cloud-based offerings (as for example, Skype for Business from Microsoft) or acquire other cloud-
based PBX companies in the future. Should any of these or other Internet service companies decide to put a
strategic focus on cloud PBX, they would, given their brand awareness, customer base and financial and techno-
logical resources, be in an excellent starting position to become a major provider in the market for cloud PBX.

In addition, because many of our target customers have historically purchased communications services from
incumbent telephone companies along with legacy on-premises communication equipment, we compete with
these customers' existing providers. These competitors include, for example, BT, Deutsche Telekom, Orange and
Vodafone, all in conjunction with on-premises hardware solutions from companies like Avaya, Cisco, NEC,
Unify, Aastra, Alcatel-Lucent and Mitel. These incumbent telephone companies could increasingly capitalise on
their large customer base by offering either their own cloud PBX or that of one of our competitors more aggres-
sively than they have done in the past.

Many of our current and potential competitors have longer operating histories, significantly greater resources and
brand awareness, and a larger customer base than we do. As a result, these competitors may have greater credi-
bility with our existing and potential customers. They also may be able to adopt more aggressive pricing policies
and devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products and services. Our com-
petitors may also offer bundled service arrangements that present a more differentiated or better integrated prod-
uct to customers. Increased competition could require us to lower our prices, reduce our sales revenue and/or
cause us to lose market share.

Given the significant price competition in the markets for our services, we may be at a disadvantage compared
with those competitors who have substantially greater resources than us or may otherwise be better positioned to
withstand an extended period of downward pricing pressure. The adverse impact of a shortfall in our revenue
may be magnified by our potentially limited ability to adjust our expenses to compensate for such a shortfall.
Announcements, or expectations, as to the introduction of new services, products and technologies by our com-
petitors or us could cause customers to defer the subscription of our existing services, which also could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We may not be able to develop, license or acquire new services or applications or
react to changing customer preferences on a timely and cost-effective basis.

risk_factor: We may not be able to develop, license or acquire new services or applications orreact to changing customer preferences on a timely and cost-effective basis.

blobs.text:
The cloud-based business communications industry is an emerging market that is characterised by rapid changes
in customer requirements, frequent introductions of new and enhanced services, and continuing and rapid
technological advancement. We cannot predict the effect of technological changes on our business. For example,
our solutions allow our customers to use and manage the NFON Cloud Telephone System on their computers
and mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets. As new devices and operating systems are released, we may
encounter difficulties supporting these devices and systems, and we may need to devote significant resources to
the creation, support, and maintenance of our respective applications. To compete successfully, we must
anticipate and adapt to technological changes and evolving industry standards, and continue to design, develop,
manufacture and sell new and enhanced services that provide increasingly higher levels of performance and
reliability at lower cost. Currently, we derive a majority of our revenue from subscriptions to the NFON Cloud
Telephone System, and we expect this will continue for the foreseeable future. However, our future success will
also depend on our ability to introduce and sell additional features and solutions that enhance or are beyond the
services we currently offer, as well as our ability to improve usability and support and increase customer
satisfaction. Our failure to develop solutions that satisfy customer preferences in a timely and cost-effective
manner may harm our ability to renew our subscriptions with existing customers or to create or increase demand
for our services, and may materially and adversely impact our results of operations.

The introduction of new services by competitors or the development of entirely new technologies to replace
existing offerings could make our solutions obsolete or adversely affect our business and results of operations.
Announcements of future releases and new services and technologies by our competitors or us could cause
customers to defer purchases of our existing services. Moreover, the development of new or enhanced services
or applications may require substantial investment, and we must continue to invest a significant amount of
resources in our research and development efforts to develop these services and applications to remain
competitive. We do not know whether these investments will be successful. If customers do not widely adopt
any new or enhanced services and applications, we may not be able to realise a return on our investment.

If we are unable to develop, license, or acquire new or enhanced services and applications on a timely and cost-
effective basis, or if such new or enhanced services and applications do not achieve market acceptance, our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects may be materially and adversely
affected.

Hacker attacks or other unauthorised access to our systems with the aim of stealing
data and/or sabotaging our operations could delay or interrupt service to our cus-
tomers, harm our reputation, or subject us to significant liability.

risk_factor: Hacker attacks or other unauthorised access to our systems with the aim of stealingdata and/or sabotaging our operations could delay or interrupt service to our cus-tomers, harm our reputation, or subject us to significant liability.

blobs.text:
Our success depends on our ability to protect our operations from interruptions or damages resulting from
unauthorised entry, computer viruses or other events beyond our control. In the past, we have been subject to
denial or disruption of service attacks by hackers intending to bring down our services, and we may be subject to
such attacks in the future. There can be no assurances that our systems, security protocols and other procedures
currently in place, or that may be in place in the future, are or will be adequate to prevent significant damage,
system failure, theft or loss. Also, our services are web-based, and the amount of data we store for our customers
on our servers and that could be subject to data theft has been increasing and will continue to increase as our
business grows. Despite the implementation of security measures, our infrastructure may be vulnerable to
hackers, computer viruses, worms, other malicious software programs or similar disruptive problems caused by
our customers, employees, consultants or other Internet users who attempt to sabotage or invade our operations.
Currently, a large number of our customers authorise us to debit their bank accounts directly for all fees that we
charge. We rely on encryption and authentication technology to ensure secure transmission of confidential
information throughout the whole data exchange. Advances in computer capabilities, new discoveries in the field
of cryptography or other developments may result in a compromise or breach of the technology we use to protect
transaction data.

Additionally, third parties may have attempted in the past, and may attempt in the future, to fraudulently induce
domestic and international employees, consultants or customers into disclosing sensitive information, such as
seat names, passwords or other customer information (e.g. personal data such as names, addresses, telephone
numbers, email addresses and bank account details), or other information more generally in order to gain access
to our customers' or our data. Third parties may also attempt to fraudulently induce employees, consultants or
customers into disclosing sensitive information. In addition, because the techniques used to obtain unauthorised
access, or to sabotage systems, change frequently and generally are not recognised until launched against a tar-
get, we may be unable to anticipate these techniques or to implement adequate preventative measures. Any sys-
tem failure or security breach that causes interruptions or data loss in our operations or in the computer systems
of our customers or leads to the misappropriation of our customers' confidential or personal information, could
result in significant liability to us. In addition, it could cause our service to be perceived as not being safe thereby
harming our reputation and deterring current and potential customers from using our services. Any of these
events could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects.

We may not be able to scale our business efficiently or quickly enough to meet our
customers' growing needs, in which case our operating results could be harmed.

risk_factor: We may not be able to scale our business efficiently or quickly enough to meet ourcustomers' growing needs, in which case our operating results could be harmed.

blobs.text:
Over the past several years, we have experienced substantial growth in our business. This growth has placed and
may continue to place significant demands on our management and our operational, technological and financial
systems and infrastructure. As our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we will need to increase our
sales and marketing efforts and add additional sales and marketing personnel and/or grow our partner network in
various regions of Europe, and improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure to attract, service and retain
an increasing number of customers. For example, we expect the volume of simultaneous calls to increase signifi-
cantly as our customer base grows. Our IT hardware and software may not be able to accommodate unexpected
volume increases or peaks in usages. The expansion of our systems and infrastructure will require us to commit
substantial financial, operational, and technical resources in advance of an increase in the volume of business,
with no assurance that the volume of business will increase. In addition, there can be no assurance that such
additional financial, operational and technical resources will be available on acceptable commercial terms, or at
all.

Continued growth could also strain our ability to maintain reliable service levels for our customers, develop and
improve our operational, financial and management controls, enhance our reporting systems and procedures and
recruit, train and retain highly skilled personnel.

As our customers gain more experience with our services, the number of seats and transactions managed by our
services, the amount of data transferred, processed and stored by us, the number of locations where our service is
being accessed, and the volume of communications managed by our services have in some cases, and may in the
future, expand rapidly. In addition, we will need to appropriately scale our internal business systems and our
services organisation, including customer support and services and regulatory compliance, to serve our growing
customer base. Any failure of or delay in these efforts could impair our system performance, result in reduced
customer satisfaction and reduce the attractiveness of our cloud software solutions to customers, resulting in
decreased sales to new customers, lower renewal rates by existing customers or requested refunds, which could

hurt our revenue growth and our reputation. The expansion of our systems and of our support and services have
been and will continue to be expensive and complex, requiring management time and attention and increasing
our operating expenses. We could also face inefficiencies or operational failures as a result of our efforts to scale
our infrastructure. Moreover, there are inherent risks associated with upgrading, improving and expanding our
information technology systems. We cannot give any assurances that the expansion and improvements to our
infrastructure and systems will be fully or effectively implemented on a timely basis, if at all.

The materialisation of any of the above mentioned risks could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We may require additional financing in the future, and such financing may not be
available on favourable terms, or at all.

risk_factor: We may require additional financing in the future, and such financing may not beavailable on favourable terms, or at all.

blobs.text:
We intend to make significant investments into marketing, distribution and R&D to achieve our strategic aim of
expanding our market position in Europe. This will require significant additional capital in the medium- to long-
er-term.

We have relied and expect to continue to rely on our cash flow from operations and access to third-party financ-
ing to finance our growth strategy. However, in 2016, for example, we had to cut back on our cost budget as we
lacked sufficient funds to fully execute our business plans and there can be no assurance that we will have suffi-
cient cash flow or access to third-party financing when required in the future. In particular, third-party financing
may not be available on terms favourable to us, or at all. Our ability to obtain additional funding will be subject
to various factors, including market conditions, our operating performance, lender sentiment, our history and
extent of operations in local markets, and our ability to incur additional debt or equity financing (see "—1.3.6
Future offerings of equity securities by the Company could adversely affect the market price of the Shares, and
future capitalisation measures could substantially dilute the interests of the Company's existing shareholders.").
These factors may make the timing, amount, terms and conditions of additional financings unattractive. Our
inability to raise capital in the medium- to longer-term could impede our future growth.

The materialisation of any of the above mentioned risks could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We may not be able to adequately protect our intellectual property rights and know-
how, and failing to do so could materially adversely affect our business. Moreover,
our use of open-source technology could impose limitations on our ability to com-
mercialise our services.

risk_factor: We may not be able to adequately protect our intellectual property rights and know-how, and failing to do so could materially adversely affect our business. Moreover,our use of open-source technology could impose limitations on our ability to com-mercialise our services.

blobs.text:
We regard our copyrights, trademarks and business secrets as important to our business. In addition, we have
developed, and we anticipate that we will continue to develop, a substantial number of software solutions, pro-
cesses and other know-how that are of key importance to the successful functioning of our business. We have
registered one patent (EP 2 100 438 B1) titled "hosted PBX servers with telephony device allocation, routing and
configuration information controlled by central database". We own certain registered trademarks ("nfon",
"NFON The Cloud Telephone System", "NFON Die Cloud-Telefonanlage", "nvoice", "nconnect", "fairfon" and

the logo " ") that are registered with the European Union Intellectual Property Office and additionally some of
them with intellectual property authorities in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Turkey. However, our use of
the nfon brand is limited to a certain extent by a coexistence agreement we entered into to settle a trademark
infringement dispute (see "—1.1.20 We were accused of infringing the trademark of a third party and had to
enter into a coexistence agreement limiting our use of the nfon trademark.").

However, as our software solutions use open-source software, they are not themselves eligible for intellectual
property protection, if and to the extent they comprise modifications of the source code of the relevant open-
source software. While we currently try to use only open-source software, the license terms of which do not
require the publication of modifications to the source code, these license terms may change in the future and
require such publication. There is a risk that the owners of the copyrights in such software could claim that the
licenses under which we use that software impose conditions or restrictions on our ability to market or provide
our services. If such owners were to prevail in such a claim, we could be required to make the modifications that
we made to the source code of the respective open-source software generally available to third parties, including
competitors, at no cost, to seek licenses from third parties in order to continue offering those services which use
such open-source software, to re-engineer our technology, or to discontinue offering our services if re-
engineering cannot be accomplished on a timely basis or at all, any of which could cause us to discontinue our
services, harm our reputation, result in customer losses or claims, increase our costs or otherwise materially and
adversely affect our business, results of operations and prospects.

Even in cases where we would be in a position to register certain intellectual property rights for protection with
copyright and/or patent authorities, we often deliberately refrain from doing so, because of the publicity involved
with such filing which makes it easier for third parties to use the intellectual property rights illegally and the
limited possibility of detecting such illegal use. Despite our efforts to maintain secrecy, including confidentiality
obligations agreed with our employees and suppliers, our intellectual property and know-how could fall into the
hands of our competitors, enabling them to capitalise on our technological developments and expertise which
may further increase the competitive pressure on us. This risk is particularly high where employees holding spe-
cific know-how (e.g. product managers) are hired by competitors which has occasionally happened in the past.

Also in cases where we have registered or will in the future register our intellectual property rights, we may not
be able to obtain effective intellectual property protection covering all relevant aspects and/or every country in
which we are active or in which such protection is relevant, and we cannot be sure that the law might not change
in a way that would affect the nature or extent of our intellectual property ownership and/or the rights granted
under such intellectual property. Similarly, we cannot be certain that others will not independently develop or
otherwise acquire equivalent or superior technology or intellectual property rights. There can be no assurances
that our intellectual property rights will not be infringed, violated or otherwise challenged by third parties, or that
we will be successful in enforcing, defending or combatting any such infringements, violations, or challenges.
We may initiate claims, administrative proceedings or litigation against others for infringement, misappropria-
tion or violation of our intellectual property rights or proprietary rights or to establish the validity of such rights.
Any legal dispute especially any litigation, whether or not it is resolved in our favour, could result in significant
expense and divert the efforts of our technical and management personnel. Failure to adequately protect our
intellectual property could lead to a loss of our ability to use our intellectual property in our solutions. Addition-
ally, our efforts to enforce our intellectual property rights may be met with defences, counterclaims, and counter-
suits attacking the validity and enforceability of our intellectual property rights.

It may not be possible for us to protect our confidential information and intellectual property, thus enabling third
parties to use it to create product offerings that compete with ours. This could lead to a loss of customers to
competitors with a corresponding loss in revenue and may render us unprofitable or unable to effectively com-
pete in the market.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We were accused of infringing the trademark of a third party and had to enter into
a coexistence agreement limiting our use of the nfon trademark.

risk_factor: We were accused of infringing the trademark of a third party and had to enter intoa coexistence agreement limiting our use of the nfon trademark.

blobs.text:
We were accused of infringing the trademark of a third party and as a result in 2015, we entered into a coexist-
ence agreement, inter alia, on our use of the trademark "NFON" for goods and services in certain trademark
classes, including trademark class 38 relating to telecommunications services which covers the services we cur-
rently market. In this coexistence agreement we undertook, among other things, to use the NFON trademark,
inter alia, for services in trademark class 38 only as "NFON The Cloud Telephone System" and together with

the Symbol " ". The preceding dispute led to significant expenses and diverted the attention of our manage-
ment and technical personnel from our business and the coexistence agreement limits our flexibility in marketing
our services.

The resulting limitations on our use of the "NFON" trademark could hinder us from marketing our services un-
der the brand that we may deem best suited which may have a detrimental impact on the brand appeal of our
services to potential customers. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Accusations that we infringe the intellectual property rights of third parties could
harm our reputation and materially adversely affect our business, financial condi-
tion, and results of operations.

risk_factor: Accusations that we infringe the intellectual property rights of third parties couldharm our reputation and materially adversely affect our business, financial condi-tion, and results of operations.

blobs.text:
Third parties may claim in the future that we infringe or violate their trademarks, patents, copyrights, design
rights, domain names, publicity rights or other proprietary rights as well as use unfair business practices. Such
claims, regardless of their merit, could result in litigation or other proceedings that could harm our reputation,
require us to expend significant financial resources and attention by our management and other personnel that
otherwise would be focused on our business operations, require us to pay damages to third parties or result in
injunctions against us that would prevent us from using material intellectual property rights. We may need to
obtain licenses from third parties who allege that we have infringed or violated their rights, but such licenses
may not be available on terms acceptable to us or at all. Increasing dependence of the ICT industry on proprie-
tary technology could increase the possibility that we will be exposed to infringement allegations, claims or other

disputes in relation to the intellectual property rights of others. Furthermore, we may be forced to acquire addi-
tional and costly technology licenses in the future or have to pay higher royalties for currently used technologies.
If we cannot obtain a necessary third-party license, we may be forced to change our name and/or logo, opera-
tions, software solutions, processes, services or strategy or develop alternative intellectual property as well as
terminate customer agreements and pay damages.

It is possible that we could become subject to infringement actions based upon certain intellectual property that
we already license from third parties. Additionally, as we rely on open-source software, we may face claims
from third parties that claim ownership of the open-source software or derivative works that were developed
using such software, or otherwise seek to enforce the terms of the applicable open-source license. These risks
have been amplified by the increase in intellectual property claims by third parties whose sole or primary busi-
ness is to assert such claims.

As our business continues to expand, we are likely to be subject to intellectual property claims against us with
increasing frequency, scope and magnitude and we cannot guarantee that we will not become liable for damages
or subject to other claims. We may also be obligated to indemnify affiliates or other partners who are accused of
violating third parties' intellectual property rights by virtue of those affiliates or partners' agreements with us, and
this could increase our costs in defending such claims and our damages. Furthermore, such affiliates and partners
may discontinue their relationship with us either as a result of injunctions or otherwise.

Finally, if intellectual property claims are asserted against us, we may be required to provide detailed business
information, including business secrets, to the claimants. Any such claim can also result in significant expense
and divert the attention of our technical and management personnel from other matters.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Defects in our services could harm our reputation, result in damage claims of cus-
tomers and other significant costs to us, and impair our ability to sell our services.

risk_factor: Defects in our services could harm our reputation, result in damage claims of cus-tomers and other significant costs to us, and impair our ability to sell our services.

blobs.text:
Our customers use our services to manage important aspects of their businesses, and any errors, defects, disrup-
tions to our service, including our customer billing process, or other performance problems with our service
could hurt our reputation and may damage our customers' businesses. The system infrastructure underlying the
NFON Cloud Telephone System is highly technical and complex. It is based on third-party hardware and soft-
ware as well as a number of software components we developed in-house. Our proprietary software has con-
tained, and may now or in the future contain, undetected errors, bugs, or vulnerabilities. Some errors in our soft-
ware code may only be discovered after the code has been released. The same applies for the third party hard-
ware and software that we use. Our customer billing process is also susceptible to systematic errors and bugs
which could potentially render a significant number of customer bills incorrect. Internet-based services frequent-
ly contain undetected errors and bugs when first introduced or when new versions or enhancements are released.
They may have errors or defects that customers identify after they begin using them that could result in unantici-
pated interruptions or malfunctioning of service. While the substantial majority of our customers are small- and
medium-sized businesses, the use of our services in complex, large-scale network environments may increase
our exposure to undetected errors, failures or bugs in our services. Although we test our services to detect and
correct errors and defects before their general release, we have from time to time experienced interruptions in
our service as a result of such errors or defects and may experience future interruptions of service if we fail to
detect and correct these errors and defects. We implement bug fixes and upgrades as part of our regularly sched-
uled system maintenance, which may lead to system downtime. Even if we are able to implement bug fixes and
upgrades in a timely manner, any history of defects, or the loss, damage or inadvertent release of confidential
customer data, could result in damage to our reputation and market acceptance of our services, loss of seats and
loss of revenue. In addition, our customers, to whom we guarantee an annual availability of our NFON Cloud
Telephone System during 99.9 % of the time, could make warranty claims against us and request compensation
for any damages. Customers may also elect not to subscribe for or renew their service subscriptions with us. In
addition, the costs incurred in correcting such defects or errors may be substantial and may divert our develop-
ment resources or require us to make extensive changes to our software, which would increase our expenses and
slow down progress towards achieving our growth strategy.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

If we fail to continue to develop our brand or our brand becomes associated with
negative reviews or poor service quality, our business may suffer.

risk_factor: f we fail to continue to develop our brand or our brand becomes associated withnegative reviews or poor service quality, our business may suffer.

blobs.text:
We believe that continuing to strengthen our brand will be critical to being able to achieve widespread ac-
ceptance of our services and will require continued focus on active marketing efforts. The demand for and cost
of online and traditional advertising have been increasing and may continue to increase. Accordingly, we may
need to increase our investment in, and devote greater resources to, advertising, marketing, and other efforts to
create and maintain brand loyalty among customers. Brand promotion activities may not yield increased revenue,
and even if they do, any increased revenue may not offset the expenses incurred in building our brands. If we fail
to promote and maintain our brand, or if we incur substantial expenses in an unsuccessful attempt to promote and
maintain our brands, our business could be materially and adversely affected.

Our services, as well as those of our competitors, are regularly reviewed and commented upon by online media
sources, as well as computer and other business publications. In the past we have experienced some negative
reviews from third parties with regard to our offered services. Negative reviews, or reviews in which our com-
petitors' services are rated more highly than ours, could negatively affect our brand and reputation.

If we do not handle customer complaints effectively, our brand and reputation may suffer, we may lose our cus-
tomers' confidence, and they may choose to terminate, reduce or not to renew their subscriptions. In addition,
many of our customers participate in social media and online blogs about Internet-based services, including our
services, and our success depends in part on our ability to minimise negative and generate positive customer
feedback through such online channels where existing and potential customers seek and share information. If
actions we take or changes we make to our services upset these customers, their blogging could negatively affect
our brand and reputation. Complaints or negative publicity about our services or customer service could materi-
ally and adversely impact our ability to attract and retain customers and our business, financial condition, cash
flows, results of operations and prospects.

Our current operations in the United Kingdom and future operations in other non-
euro countries subject us to currency risks.

risk_factor: Our current operations in the United Kingdom and future operations in other non-euro countries subject us to currency risks.

blobs.text:
In 2017, approximately 13.8 % of our revenue (before reconciliation) resulted from our segment United King-
dom. Although the currency risks resulting therefrom were largely offset in the past by costs that we also in-
curred in Pound Sterling, there can be no assurance that this will not change in the future. The Euro is the cur-
rency in which we report. A decrease in the value of the Pound Sterling relative to the Euro could therefore have
a detrimental effect on our revenue reported in Euro and the margin of our business in the United Kingdom. Due
to our expansion strategy we are already active in Poland and Switzerland and considering entering into coun-
tries such as Sweden, Norway and/or Denmark which could subject us to currency risks with regard to the cur-
rency of these countries. Fluctuations in exchange rates may also affect our ability to market our products suc-
cessfully in such markets. We currently do not hedge against currency risk. If the value of the Euro declines
against currencies in which our obligations are denominated or increases against currencies in which our sales
are denominated, our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be materially ad-
versely affected.
Our operations in the United Kingdom subject us to risks brought about by Brexit.

risk_factor: Our operations in the United Kingdom subject us to risks brought about by Brexit.

blobs.text:
On 23 June 2016, the British public voted in favour of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union ("Brex-
it"). Subsequently, the UK parliament passed the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Act 2017 which
gave the UK government power to begin the formal process for Brexit. A process of negotiation, which formally
began on 29 March 2017 when the United Kingdom submitted its Article 50 notice of intention to withdraw
from the European Union, will determine the terms of the UK's European Union exit and a possible future
framework agreement.

The prospect of Brexit has resulted in significant economic, political and social uncertainty, not only in the Unit-
ed Kingdom and Europe, but across the globe generally. The extent of the impact of Brexit on our business,
particularly our UK operations, will depend in part on the nature of the arrangements that are put in place be-
tween the United Kingdom and the European Union following Brexit and the extent to which the United King-
dom continues to apply laws that are based on EU legislation. We may be subject to a significant period of un-
certainty in the period leading up to Brexit including, inter alia, uncertainty in relation to any potential regulato-
ry or tax change and their effect on our UK business. For example, Brexit may disrupt established trading rela-
tionships by imposing tariffs or withholding taxes on royalty payments.

Brexit could ultimately yield the result that we would no longer be able to serve UK customers from our servers
in Germany for regulatory reasons, but would rather have to establish servers in the United Kingdom. There can
be no assurance that it would be possible to establish such server infrastructure in the United Kingdom in a short

time or at all which would disrupt our business relationship with our existing customers in the United Kingdom
and keep us from acquiring additional customers. Even if we were successful in establishing a server infrastruc-
ture in the United Kingdom, this would likely take significant investments and would, from an overall financial
and operational perspective, likely be less efficient.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We are in the process of expanding our international operations, which exposes us
to significant risks.

risk_factor: We are in the process of expanding our international operations, which exposes usto significant risks.

blobs.text:
To date, we offer our services to customers in 13 European countries, but have not generated significant revenue
from countries other than the Federal Republic of Austria ("Austria"), Germany and the United Kingdom. How-
ever, we intend to grow our revenue in other European countries where we offer our services, such as the Nether-
lands, Spain and Switzerland, and to enter additional European markets, such as France, Italy, Belgium and Lux-
embourg, in the near to mid-term. The future success of our business is likely to depend, in part, on our ability to
expand our operations and customer base and to further strengthen our leading position as a provider for cloud
PBX services in Europe. Operating in international European markets requires significant resources and man-
agement attention and subjects us to regulatory, economic and political risks that are different from those in
Germany. Our European expansion efforts may not be successful. We could in particular, face the following
obstacles and risks:
our ability to comply with differing technical and environmental standards, data privacy and

Our failure to manage any of these risks successfully could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We depend largely on the continued services of members of the management board
and other key employees, the loss of any of whom could adversely affect our busi-
ness, results of operations and financial condition.

risk_factor: We depend largely on the continued services of members of the management boardand other key employees, the loss of any of whom could adversely affect our busi-ness, results of operations and financial condition.

blobs.text:
Our future performance depends on the continued services and contributions of the members of the management
board and other key employees to execute our business plan, and to identify and pursue opportunities and service
innovations. The loss of services of our management board members or other key employees could significantly
delay or prevent the achievement of our development and strategic objectives. The replacement of any of the
members of the management board or any other of our key employees would likely involve significant time and
costs. The loss of the services of our management board members or other key employees for any reason could
adversely affect our business, financial condition cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

If we are unable to hire, retain and motivate qualified personnel, our business will
suffer.

risk_factor: If we are unable to hire, retain and motivate qualified personnel, our business willsuffer.

blobs.text:
Our future success depends, in part, on our ability to continue to attract and retain highly specialised personnel
with a very specific skill set. We believe that there is, and will continue to be, intense competition for highly
skilled personnel with experience in our industry across Europe and particularly in Germany. Competition is
particularly intense with regard to software engineers where the demand substantially exceeds the number of
available candidates. We must provide competitive compensation packages and a high-quality work environment
to hire, retain and motivate employees. If we are unable to retain and motivate our existing employees and attract
qualified personnel to fill key positions, we may be unable to manage our business effectively, including the
development, marketing and sale of existing and new services.

Our inability to retain our employees or to attract additional sufficiently qualified employees could have a mate-
rial adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We may be unable to successfully consummate, integrate, or achieve the expected
benefits from acquisitions.

risk_factor: We may be unable to successfully consummate, integrate, or achieve the expectedbenefits from acquisitions.

blobs.text:
benefits from acquisitions.
It is our strategic aim to selectively analyse and ultimately execute acquisitions of existing companies with the
aim of acquiring certain technologies or products and/or to expand our customer base.

The success of our acquisition strategy depends upon our ability to identify suitable acquisition targets, conduct
appropriate due diligence, negotiate transactions on favourable terms and ultimately complete such transactions.
There can be no guarantee that negotiations with attractive targets will lead to completed acquisitions. Certain of
our competitors may pursue similar acquisition targets and strategies, and they may have greater financial re-
sources available for investments or may be able to offer more favourable terms than we are able to offer, there-
by preventing us from acquiring the businesses that we target.

To the extent we are successful in making acquisitions, we may have to spend substantial amounts of cash or
shares, incur debt, assume loss-making divisions and incur other types of expenses. In particular, future acquisi-
tions could result in increased indebtedness and significant commitment of management resources, and in a dilu-
tion of our shareholders if the acquisition is structured fully or partially as a share for share deal. We might not
achieve the cost savings, synergies or other benefits that we hope to achieve from acquisitions.

Our analysis of an acquisition target will inevitably include assessments which are subject to certain assumptions
concerning profitability, growth, quality of the operations of the acquisition targets, interest rates, realisable
synergies and company valuations. There can be no assurance that our assessment of, and assumptions regard-
ing, acquisition targets will prove to be correct, and actual developments may significantly differ from our ex-
pectations. We therefore cannot guarantee that the integration of any future acquisitions will yield benefits to us
that are sufficient to justify the expenses we will incur in completing such acquisitions. We may not be in a posi-
tion to carry out substantive due diligence and any failure by us to identify, or to correctly assess, all of the prob-
lems, liabilities or other shortcomings or challenges of an acquired company or technology, including issues
related to intellectual property, data protection, regulatory compliance, accounting practices or employee or
customer issues could harm our business, and we could incur extraordinary or currently unexpected legal, regula-
tory, contractual, labour or other costs as a consequence of acquisitions.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

We are currently subject to a tax audit by the German tax authorities. Our business
is subject to the general tax environment in jurisdictions in which we are conduct-
ing our business and possible future changes may adversely affect our operations.
We may be required to pay additional taxes, accrued interest and penalties following
tax audits of the Group.

risk_factor: We are currently subject to a tax audit by the German tax authorities. Our businessis subject to the general tax environment in jurisdictions in which we are conduct-ing our business and possible future changes may adversely affect our operations.We may be required to pay additional taxes, accrued interest and penalties followingtax audits of the Group.

blobs.text:
Our business is subject to the various general tax environments of the jurisdictions in which we are conducting
our business. Our ability to use tax loss carry-forwards and other favourable tax provisions depends on the na-
tional tax legislation of the countries where we are subject to taxation. Changes in tax legislation, administrative
practice or case law could have adverse tax consequences for us. In addition, amendments to applicable laws,
orders and regulations may be issued or altered with retroactive effect within certain limits. Further, divergent
interpretations of tax laws by the tax authorities or the tax courts are possible. These interpretations could change
at any time with adverse effects in relation to our tax burden. Court decisions are often overruled by the superior
tax courts and might lead to a higher tax burden as well as increased legal and tax advisory costs for us.

Since our establishment we have only been subject to a finalised tax audit with regard to wage tax (Lohnsteuer),
but not with regard to any other types of taxes such as corporate income tax and trade tax. Accordingly, the
German tax assessment notices for all periods since inception are still preliminary. As a result, the tax authorities
could revise original tax assessments which might materially increase our tax burden (including interest and
penalty payments).

As a result of our filing of a correction of our tax declarations for the financial years 2009 through 2015 with the
competent German tax authority, we are currently subject to a tax audit pertaining to corporate income tax
(Körperschaftsteuer), capital gains tax (Kapitalertragsteuer), value added tax (Umsatzsteuer) and trade tax
(Gewerbesteuer) for the financial years 2012, 2013, 2014 and 2015. The correction declaration was deemed
necessary, mainly as services performed by the Company for its foreign subsidiaries had not been charged by the
Company to these subsidiaries. However, the tax authorities may, to some extent, not accept our proposed ad-
justments in respect of the above mentioned issues and tax declarations and challenge them or address additional
topics of which we are not aware. In addition, the correction declaration pertains also to our engagement of free-
lancers under terms that potentially qualify them as our employees and, as a result obliged us to make respective
wage tax deductions and social welfare contributions. We contacted the competent federal authority for social
welfare contributions in Germany and made them aware of the underlying facts. The respective investigations by
this authority are ongoing and will likely lead to a payable amount of outstanding wage tax, social welfare con-
tributions and possibly an administrative fine.

tributions and possibly an administrative fine.
The taxes actually assessed in this or any future tax audit could further reduce our loss carry-forward or exceed
taxes already paid by us, which could result in us having to make significant additional tax payments. Further,
tax authorities could revise original tax assessments, for example, by refusing to recognise our entitlement to
recover invoiced value-added taxes. Any tax assessments that deviate from our expectations could lead to an
increase in the tax obligations of the Company and/or any of our Group companies and, additionally, could give
rise to interest being payable on the additional amount of taxes as well as late filing penalties.

Due to the global nature of the Internet, it is possible that various jurisdictions might attempt to impose addition-
al or new regulation on our business or levy additional sales, income or other taxes relating to our activities. Tax
authorities in various jurisdictions are currently reviewing the appropriate treatment of companies engaged in e-
commerce. New or revised tax regulations may subject us or our customers to additional sales, income and other
taxes. We cannot predict the effect of current attempts to impose sales, income or other taxes. New or revised
taxes and, in particular, sales taxes, value-added taxes and similar taxes would likely increase the cost of doing
business and decrease the attractiveness of selling services. New taxes could also require us to incur significant
increases in internal costs to capture necessary data and collect and remit taxes.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
There is a risk that our tax loss carry-forwards cannot be utilised.

risk_factor: There is a risk that our tax loss carry-forwards cannot be utilised.

blobs.text:
As of 31 December 2017, the Company carried forward (i) domestic corporate tax losses of EUR 23,157 thou-
sand and (ii) domestic trade tax losses of EUR 14,741 thousand (together the "Tax Loss Carry-Forwards").
The German laws regarding elimination of tax losses are subject to change. The current laws provide for the
following: In cases (i) where, within any given five year period, more than 25 % of the subscribed capital, mem-
bership rights, ownership rights or voting rights in a corporate entity are directly or indirectly transferred to an
acquirer or to its related parties or to a group of acquirers with convergent interest, or (ii) where a comparable
event occurs (a "Relevant Change of Control") the German Corporate Income Tax Act (Körperschaftsteuerge-
setz) provides for an elimination of tax loss carry-forwards and current losses for German corporate income and
trade tax purposes. A Relevant Change of Control of up to and including 50 % causes a corresponding pro-rata
elimination of tax loss carry-forwards and current losses whereas, a Relevant Change of Control involving more
than 50 % of the subscribed capital, membership rights, ownership rights or voting rights, causes the elimination
of tax losses and tax loss carry-forwards in their entirety. The German Federal Constitutional Court (Bundesver-
fassungsgericht) decided on 29 March 2017 that the cancellation of tax loss carry-forwards in case of transfer of
more than 25 % and up to 50 % of the shares in a corporation constitutes a violation of constitutional laws. The
court has requested that the existing legal regime be replaced by a new regime by the end of 2018 with retroac-
tive effect from 2008. At this stage it is not clear how the lawmaker intends to comply with the German Federal
Constitutional Court's request. As a result of the unclarity of this legal regime there is a risk that the Tax Loss
Carry-Forwards may be affected in connection with significant changes of the Company's shareholder structure.

Our insurance coverage may be inadequate, may increase in cost and may not cover
certain risks or unexpected events.

risk_factor: Our insurance coverage may be inadequate, may increase in cost and may not covercertain risks or unexpected events.

blobs.text:
We maintain insurance coverage only for liability risks. There is no guarantee that this insurance coverage will
adequately cover all liability risks we may face. Our insurance coverage does not protect us from losses that we
may suffer as a result of business interruptions, such as damages to our assets or lost profit. Even if we decide to
obtain insurance coverage for additional risks in the future, some risks cannot be insured and, for certain risks,
insurance may not be available to cover all risks or may be available only at costs that are not economically
viable. In addition, following a significant insurance claim or a history of claims, insurance premiums may in-
crease or the terms and conditions of insurance coverage may become less favourable. This may also occur due
to a general change in the insurance markets. There is no guarantee that we will be able to continue to obtain
sufficient levels of insurance on economically viable terms. The materialisation of any of the risks described
above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and pro-
spects.
Regulatory and Legal Risks
We are subject to extensive regulation which will continue to impact our business.

risk_factor: We are subject to extensive regulation which will continue to impact our business.

blobs.text:
We are subject to extensive regulation which will continue to impact our business.
As we are providing telecommunications services, we are subject to the regulatory regime of the German Tele-
communications Act (Telekommunikationsgesetz, the "Telecommunications Act") and certain regulations that
supplement the Telecommunications Act. Our activities are subject to regulation and supervision by the Federal
Network Agency (Bundesnetzagentur, "FNA") in Germany and other regulatory authorities in Europe such as
the European Commission. In addition, various German authorities at the state, regional and local level and other
EU bodies have the power to regulate us and conduct reviews of our business. The provision of telecommunica-
tions services in the European Union does not require a license from a regulatory body. However, as a commer-
cial provider of publicly available telecommunications services, we must notify the FNA of the commencement,
any modification and the termination of our business activities. The Telecommunications Act contains provi-
sions regarding, among other things: (i) the establishment and powers of the regulatory body; (ii) notification
requirements; (iii) the granting of rights of way; (iv) the allocation of frequencies and numbers; (v) access obli-
gations; (vi) the regulation of rates; (vii) restriction of abusive behaviour; (viii) customer protection; and (ix)
data protection and public safety. The FNA and other regulatory authorities may impose obligations on us in
relation to the provision of our services.

As we collect, store and use data in the ordinary course of our business, we are subject to the data privacy and
protection laws and regulations adopted by federal, state and foreign governmental agencies. Privacy laws re-
strict our storage, use, processing, disclosure, transfer and protection of personal information, including debit and
credit card data, provided to us by our customers as well as data we collect from our customers and employees.

Compliance with the above mentioned obligations requires us to incur significant expenditures. Any failure, or
perceived failure, by us to comply with the above mentioned obligations or other applicable legal, regulatory or
contractual requirements could result in proceedings, actions and/or sanctions against us by governmental enti-
ties, contractual parties or others, which could result in significant liability to us as well as harm to our reputa-
tion. In cases where we rely on third parties (as, for example, service providers) for the compliance with the
above mentioned requirements, we can also be liable for the non-compliance of such third party. In addition, any
future change of laws and regulations or introduction of new legislative or regulatory initiatives could lead to an
increase in our compliance costs and could make it impossible for us to offer certain services that we currently
offer at current prices or at all.

Some of the obligations under the Telecommunications Act that do not apply to us, but only to providers which
have significant market power in their respective markets, nevertheless have a significant impact on our busi-
ness. For example, the regulation of the obligation of operators of public telecommunication networks to grant
network access to third parties and the rates that they may charge for these access services have an impact on the
PSTN interconnection of the NFON Cloud Telephone System and the terms of our respective agreements with
carriers providing PSTN services. The regulation of numbering, number portability and network neutrality are
also obligations of network operators that affect our business. A change in regulation in this regard could result
in us no longer being able to provide all of the services that we currently offer in their current form or at all or at
their current costs or could make it necessary that we use more costly alternatives.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

The European legal regime for data protection will change significantly which
could have an adverse impact on our business operations.

risk_factor: The European legal regime for data protection will change significantly whichcould have an adverse impact on our business operations.

blobs.text:
The data protection laws which we need to comply with will change substantially with effect of May 2018 when
the new General Data Protection Regulation ("GDPR") (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) will become enforceable.
The GDPR harmonises the data protection regulations throughout the European Union and implements a stricter
data protection compliance regime. It also substantially increases the fines for a breach of data protection law.
German data protection agencies have the right to audit us and impose orders and fines if they find that we have
not complied with applicable laws and adequately protected customer data.

We have taken action to implement the requirements of the GDPR. However, the stricter rules of the GDPR and
any limitations imposed by a stricter interpretation of the existing requirements or by future modifications of the
data protection laws could have a significant impact on our business operations and our ability to offer and mar-
ket certain of our current services at current costs or at all and significantly increase our compliance costs. It may
not be possible to prevent cases of data leakage or the misuse of data as a result of human error, technological
failure, cyber-attacks, criminal activities or other factors outside of our control. Violation of the GDPR may
result, inter alia, in fines and customer churn, and harm our reputation in the market. In addition, data leakage
may lead to the obligation to inform the individuals affected and the competent data protection supervisory au-
thority.

The materialisation of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

Legal, jurisdictional or administrative changes in the field of data retention may
lead to significant additional cost for us.

risk_factor: Legal, jurisdictional or administrative changes in the field of data retention maylead to significant additional cost for us.

blobs.text:
After the German Federal Constitutional Court declared the data retention obligation (as it was drafted at the
time) unconstitutional on 2 March 2010 and the Court of Justice of the European Union ("CJEU") annulled the
respective European directive on 8 April 2014, German lawmakers adopted a revised data retention legislation in
2015. The revised legislation obliges providers of publicly available telecommunications services to store traffic
data of their customers from 1 July 2017. In relation to one of the various claims filed against such legislation,
the Higher Administrative Court of North Rhine-Westphalia issued a preliminary injunction on 22 June 2017
ruling that the revised data retention legislation infringes European law. Subsequently, the FNA announced that
it would refrain from enforcing the obligations imposed by such legislation until the ruling in the principal pro-
ceedings (Hauptsacheverfahren) which are still pending.

Therefore, we currently do not save the traffic data of our customers. However, it is possible that in the future,
either the provisions of the revised data retention legislation will be declared lawful or new legislation imposing
data retention obligations will come into force. In either of these cases, the implementation of data retention
measures may lead to significant additional costs for us and therefore have a significant adverse impact on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

The proposed new European Communications Code may adversely affect our busi-
ness operations.

risk_factor: The proposed new European Communications Code may adversely affect our busi-ness operations.

blobs.text:
On 14 September 2016, the European Commission published a new draft European Electronic Communications
Code ("EECC") to amend the existing European regulatory framework for electronic communication services.
The objectives of the EECC include the strengthening of consumer protection rights and the creation of a level
playing field for traditional operators and new online service providers that offer equivalent services (so-called
"over-the-top" or "OTT" services.

As the draft EECC is still being negotiated and discussed between the European Parliament, the European Com-
mission and the European Council, it is not possible to estimate when and to what extent the EECC will be final-
ly adopted. However, as some of our services may be qualified as OTT services, the implementation of the
EECC may lead to additional and increased regulatory obligations for us. We may have to devote significant
resources in order to comply with such additional obligations and may be subject to sanctions if we fail to com-
ply with them. These factors may have a significant impact on our business operations and our ability to market
services to customers in the future and therefore have a material adverse effect on our business and our ability to
compete.

Compliance with requests from law enforcement agencies and compliance with data
disclosure and lawful interception laws is costly and difficult and might subject us
to conflicting obligations and result in improper interpretation and application of
complex laws.

risk_factor: Compliance with requests from law enforcement agencies and compliance with datadisclosure and lawful interception laws is costly and difficult and might subject usto conflicting obligations and result in improper interpretation and application ofcomplex laws.

blobs.text:
As a company active in the telecommunications industry, we are subject to various regulations that require us to
assist law enforcement and intelligence agencies with access to personal and traffic data and lawful interception
of certain services and products. The scope of application and level of sophistication of such regulations vary
greatly from country to country. We have been and may in the future be asked to disclose personal data to vari-
ous law enforcement agencies. In addition, authorities could consider that we are subject to lawful interception
laws, and we have been contacted from time to time by authorities in relation to our ability to intercept, trace or
identify our users' communications. To the extent that our services are or were found to be or would become
subject to lawful interception laws in any jurisdiction, we would need to adapt our systems and processes to
comply with a variety of requirements on a jurisdiction-by-jurisdiction basis, which can be very costly and tech-
nically difficult. Furthermore, such requests by law enforcement and other authorities can make us subject to
potentially conflicting obligations across jurisdictions. In addition, determining whether compliance is legally
appropriate in any particular case could require us to exercise judgment and result in improper interpretation and
application of complex laws. Compliance with data disclosure and legal interception orders may also conflict
with certain local laws, including laws governing privacy.

1.3   Risks Related to the Company's Shareholder Structure, the Shares and the
      Offering

              Following the offering, the Company's existing shareholders will retain a signifi-
              cant interest in the Company and their interests may conflict with those of the Com-
              pany's other shareholders.

risk_factor: Following the offering, the Company's existing shareholders will retain a signifi-cant interest in the Company and their interests may conflict with those of the Com-pany's other shareholders.

blobs.text:
Following the successful completion of this offering, the Company's existing shareholders will continue to own
approximately 37.2 % of the outstanding share capital of the Company (assuming the placement of 2,840,909
New Shares, 3,977,272 Sale Shares and 1,022,727 Over-Allotment Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range
and exercise of the Greenshoe Option with regard to the number of Shares corresponding to the number of Over-
Allotment Shares sold in the Offering). The interests of the Company's existing shareholders may be different
from the Company's interests or those of other shareholders. The remaining stake of the Company's existing
shareholders may have the effect of making certain transactions more difficult or impossible without the support
of the Company's existing shareholders, and may have the effect of delaying, postponing or preventing certain
major corporate actions, including a change of control in the Company, and could thus prevent mergers, consoli-
dations, acquisitions or other forms of combination that might be advantageous for other shareholders.

The realisation of any of the Company's existing shareholders' interests that are in conflict with those of the other
shareholders may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of oper-
ations and prospects.
The Company does not expect to pay any dividends in the foreseeable future.

risk_factor: The Company does not expect to pay any dividends in the foreseeable future.

blobs.text:
The Company has not yet paid any dividends to its shareholders and does not currently intend to pay dividends
in the foreseeable future. Under the German corporate law, a company may only pay dividends if it has unappro-
priated retained earnings in its unconsolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with the generally
accepted accounting principles of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch). Certain reserves must be
established by law and have to be deducted when calculating the distributable profit. The Company's ability to
pay dividends therefore depends upon, among other things, our results of operations, financing and investment
requirements, as well as the availability of distributable profit. In addition, the Company's current financing
arrangements contain, and the future financing arrangements may contain, covenants which impose restrictions
on its business and on its ability to pay dividends under certain circumstances. In particular, the ability to pay
dividends may be impaired if any of the risks described in this section "1. Risk Factors" were to occur. Any of
these factors, individually or in combination, could restrict the Company's ability to pay dividends. Even if the
Company were able to pay dividends, it currently does not intend to propose the distribution of dividends to its
general shareholders' meeting in the foreseeable future. Therefore, investors cannot expect to receive a partial
return on their investment in Offer Shares through dividend payments. This may result in the return on invest-
ments in the Shares by a prospective investor being limited.

The Shares have not been previously publicly traded, and there is no guarantee that
an active and liquid market for the Shares will develop.

risk_factor: The Shares have not been previously publicly traded, and there is no guarantee thatan active and liquid market for the Shares will develop.

blobs.text:
Prior to this Offering, there has been no public offering of or public trading in the Shares. There can be no assur-
ance that an active, liquid trading market for the Shares will develop or be sustained following the listing of the
Shares on the regulated market segment (Regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter
Wertpapierbörse) and, simultaneously, on the sub-segment thereof with additional post-admission obligations
(Prime Standard) (the "Listing"). The price of the Offer Shares will be determined on the basis of a book-
building procedure. The price for the Offer Shares determined and established in this manner may not corre-
spond to the price at which the Shares will be traded on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpa-
pierbörse) after the Offering. Active trading in the Shares might not develop or continue after the Offering. If
fewer than all Offer Shares are sold, the free float and thus the liquidity of the Offer Shares after the Listing will
be lower, which may have an additional adverse effect on investors' ability to trade the Shares. Investors may not
be in a position to sell their Shares quickly or at all or at the market price if there is no active trading in the
Shares. If an active market for the Shares does not develop after the Listing, the liquidity and market price of the
Shares may be adversely affected.

The Company will incur increased costs as a result of operating as a public compa-
ny, and its management will be required to devote substantial time to additional
compliance initiatives and to additional legal, regulatory and administrative re-
quirements. If the Company fails to comply with these requirements, it will possibly
damage our reputation and may affect an investment in the Offer Shares.
