Where financial information in the following tables is labelled "audited", this means that it was taken from the
Audited Consolidated Financial Statements mentioned above or the audited unconsolidated financial statements
of the Company as of and for the financial year ended 31 December 2017. The label "unaudited" is used in
tables to indicate financial information that was taken from a source other than the Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements. Unless otherwise indicated, all of the financial figures presented in the text in this section
of the Prospectus are shown in thousands of euro. Unless expressly otherwise noted, the percentage amounts
included in the text have been commercially rounded to two decimal points. Because of this rounding, the figures
shown in the tables may not, in all cases, add up exactly to the respective totals given.
10.1 Overview

We are the only true pan-European cloud PBX provider with a market-leading position in Germany in terms of
number of multi-tenant cloud PBX seats (Source: MZA). As at 31 March 2018, we provided our services to
more than 15 thousand business customers (including end customers of our wholesale partners) with more than
250 thousand seats. Our flagship service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, is a public multi-tenant PBX
delivering its services from the cloud. As such, it is designed to enable convenient and effective location-
independent communication for our customers and their employees, all the time, on multiple devices, including
smartphones, tablets, personal computers ("PCs") and desk phones.

Traditionally, businesses have exclusively used on-premise PBX. These systems generally require expensive
hardware that must be deployed at every business location of the customer and are primarily designed for em-
ployees working only at that location and using only their desk phones. In addition, these systems generally
require significant upfront investment and ongoing maintenance and support costs. In contrast, public multi-
tenant PBX, such as the NFON Cloud Telephone System, are easy to deploy, have increased functionality, are
highly flexible and scalable and are updated automatically. Normally, public multi-tenant PBX also provide for
lower total costs of ownership than on-premise and other off-premise PBX. The market development is expected
to be clearly in favour of Hosted/Cloud PBX: While as at 31 December 2017, just over 10 % of all PBX systems
deployed in the European PBX Market were estimated to be Hosted/Cloud PBX, this portion is expected to in-
crease to more than 25 % by the end of 2022. (Source: MZA).

Over the last ten years we have developed a highly reliable, enterprise grade cloud service platform that is hori-
zontally scalable, meaning that we can quickly and cost-effectively expand the capacity of our infrastructure and
delivery platform by connecting additional hardware or software components and that it relies almost exclusively
on infrastructure operated in Germany and complying with the strict European data privacy requirements. To
ensure short reaction times and high quality in both development and services, almost all of our solutions and
processes were developed in-house and are operated by ourselves. The NFON Cloud Telephone System is highly
reliable and provides for more than 150 core features that are constantly updated at no additional cost to our

customers. It can be used for up to several thousand seats per customer. Due to our self-developed zero-touch
provisioning process, the deployment of the NFON Cloud Telephone System is easy and intuitive.

We offer the NFON Cloud Telephone System to companies of all sizes. Our customer base ranges from small
office/home office customers ("SoHos") to large businesses. We address them with a multi-channel distribution
strategy. Besides our direct distribution, we have a network of more than 1,100 (as at 31 March 2018) dedicated
distributors and dealers. In addition, our wholesale partners, such as Deutsche Telekom (including its subsidiary
T-Systems), Chess Communication, Telefónica Germany and Sunrise, distribute our cloud telephone system on a
white label and co-branded basis to their customers.

We primarily generate revenues by selling subscriptions for our services. Generally, our NFON Cloud Tele-
phone System services are offered at a monthly license fee per seat. The amount of the monthly license fee de-
pends on the type and number of optional features and premium solutions to which the customer subscribes and
the maximum number of devices per seat. The license fee also varies slightly from market to market.

Our customers typically do not have fixed-term contracts with us. They may terminate their subscription or re-
duce the scope of subscribed services at any time, subject to 30 days' notice, without penalty or early termination
charges. We have entered into subscription agreements with fixed terms of two to three years with a few large
customers. However, these large customers only contribute a small portion of our revenue. Generally, telephone
services are billed and paid on a monthly basis.

With offices in Berlin, Greven, Madrid, Mainz, Munich, St. Pölten and Uxbridge, we are active in 13 European
markets, including Austria, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom. In
2017, we generated 72.50 % of our revenue in our IFRS segment Germany, 13.83 % in our IFRS segment United
Kingdom and 11.58 % in our IFRS segment Austria (including Eastern Europe), before reconciliation. With our
core service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, tailored to the needs of European customers, we intend to
leverage on our proven market entry strategy to enter additional European markets with a particular focus on
France, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg and further expand our business in the Netherlands.

We have experienced significant growth in recent periods, with total revenue of EUR 20,951 thousand,
EUR 30,388 thousand (including an extraordinary effect of non-recurring service revenue of EUR 1,500 thou-
sand generated in connection with setting up a wholesale partnership) and EUR 35,654 thousand in the financial
years 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively, representing year-over-year increases of 45.04 % and 17.33 %, respec-
tively. In 2015, 2016 and 2017, recurring revenues, mainly from monthly payments of a fixed license fee per seat
plus an additional fixed or volume-based fee for voice telephony usage, accounted for more than 72.50 %,
71.10 % and 77.87 %, respectively of our revenue. The balance of our revenue is comprised of non-recurring
revenues, which principally comprise revenues from the sale of hardware and communication devices as well as
activation fees and professional services, for example, in connection with the implementation of premium solu-
tion at our customer sites. In 2016, non-recurring revenue also included non-recurring service revenues of
EUR 1,500 thousand generated in connection with setting up a wholesale partnership. We incurred net losses of
EUR 6,054 thousand, EUR 1,548 thousand and EUR 2,021 thousand, in 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively.
10.2 Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations

The key factors discussed below have significantly affected our results of operations for 2015, 2016 and 2017
and we believe that these factors will continue to affect our results of operations in the foreseeable future.
Growth Strategy, International Expansion and Investments in R&D and Marketing

We believe that it is critical for our success that we aggressively expand our customer base and obtain a leading
market position in Europe. In the past, our growth strategy and our international expansion have led to costs and
investments that have had a negative effect on our profitability. In particular, establishing our own presences in
Austria, the United Kingdom and Spain has led to significant costs which we expect to be offset by revenue from
the respective markets only in the coming years, if at all. The EBITDA (before reconciliation) of our United
Kingdom segment was EUR -2,896 thousand and of our Austrian segment EUR -6,267 thousand in financial
year 2017.

In addition, we have made significant financial investments in R&D and intend to continue to do so to enhance
the attractiveness of our service offering by further developing our cloud telephone system, the NFON Cloud
Telephone System, and integrating further attractive features and premium solutions. Our financial investments
into R&D are mainly made in the form of personnel costs of our employees engaged in R&D activity, costs of
freelancers for external product development and, to a lesser extent, related travel expenses. In the financial year
2018, we have, in particular, increased our use of freelancers for external development services. In financial
years 2015, 2016 and 2017 we did not capitalise any of our investments into R&D as intangible assets, but ex-
pect that we will be obliged to capitalise some or all of such expenditures in our future financial statements and

financial reports under IFRS. This would spread out the otherwise one-time impact of our respective investments
over the period of amortisation of the intangible assets.

We also intend to significantly invest into (i) brand marketing and various other marketing measures, including
digital performance marketing measures, in particular, programmatic and search engine advertising, in order to
be perceived as a leader in cloud PBX and (ii) our channel partner network to further expand our distribution
reach. These investments will likely, in the short-to-medium term, put further pressure on our margins, which
may be offset in the future if we are able to scale our business successfully.

As part of our international expansion strategy, we acquired the 49.8 % of shares in our Austrian subsidiary, nfon
GmbH, that were held by our former joint venture partner in November 2017. nfon GmbH was already consoli-
dated in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements throughout financial years 2015, 2016 and 2017. Of the
total purchase price of EUR 3,100 thousand, we paid EUR 775 thousand immediately upon signing of the
agreement and are obligated to pay the remaining amount immediately upon consummation of the Offering.

We believe that, although our strategy of focusing mainly on our European expansion and the growth of our
customer base has a short-term detrimental effect on our profitability, the long-term benefit of expanding our
leading position in the Cloud PBX market clearly outweighs these effects.
Development of our Customer Base

We generate the majority of our revenue with our customers on a recurring basis. Our customers pay a fixed
monthly license fee per seat for the usage of the NFON Cloud Telephone System. The amount of this license fee
depends on the type and number of available optional features and premium solutions and the maximum number
of devices that can be used per seat. The license fee also varies slightly from market to market. Except for NFON
Cloud Telephone System services distributed to wholesale partners without airtime, customers also pay us for
voice telephony usage either on a per minute-based charging model or on the basis of a flat rate. This includes
traffic into the PSTN and is also billed on a monthly basis. These recurring revenue directly result from the
number of seats for which customers subscribe services with us and the amount of the subscription fee agreed
with the customer. Voice traffic not charged under a flat rate is additionally influenced by the voice telephony
usage of our customers. The voice traffic of our customers fluctuates depending on the number of business days
in a month and in line with holiday seasons. There is above average voice traffic in months with many business
days and generally outside holiday seasons. These seasonal effects tend not, however, to be significant, and
voice telephony usage provides us with relatively stable recurring revenue.

voice telephony usage provides us with relatively stable recurring revenue.
An increase in our customer base and the number of total seats has a positive effect on our revenue and generally
also on our results of operations. The number of seats customers subscribed for with us increased at a CAGR of
37.41 % from approximately 134,000 as at 31 December 2015 to approximately 253,000 as at 31 December
2017. Changes in the number of our customers and the seats they subscribe for with us are driven by (i) the
number of new customers that subscribe for our services, (ii) the number of customers that discontinue to sub-
scribe for our services and (iii) the extent to which existing customers either increase or decrease the number of
seats they subscribe for.

We believe that the number of new customers who subscribe for our services reflects in large part the attractive-
ness of our services and pricing, the effects of our distribution and marketing efforts, including the perception of
our brand, the perceived quality of our services, all as compared to other PBX service providers. In addition,
general economic developments or specific industry trends such as a trend towards or away from public multi-
tenant PBX may also influence the demand for our services.

We measure the extent of subscriber disconnections during a given period, in our case monthly, by the Gross
Churn Rate. We define the monthly Gross Churn Rate as the number of lost seats in a month divided by the total
number of seats at the end of the previous month. This amount is calculated by taking into account all customers
who either terminated their contract in the respective month or reduced the amount of chargeable seats to zero
and adding up the individual maximum number of seats these customers have been charged with in the six
months prior to the termination. Our average monthly Gross Churn Rate was 0.3 % in 2015, 0.4 % in 2016 and
0.4 % in 2017. We believe that our comparatively low Gross Churn Rate reflects in large part the attractiveness
of our services and pricing, the subscriber experience and the quality of our services (including customer care).
Our Gross Churn Rate may also be impacted by shifts in subscriber status (where a subscriber becomes active or
inactive), subscription duration, and other factors.

Finally, the number of additional seats our existing customers subscribe for is influenced by the customer's satis-
faction with our services and the length of the relationship we have with the customer. Customers often initially
subscribe for a smaller number of seats and increase the number of seats, if they are satisfied with our services
during an initial period.
Average Revenue per User (ARPU)

We define ARPU as average total recurring revenue per month divided by the average number of seats per
month. Our average monthly ARPU was EUR 11.24 in 2015, EUR 10.86 in 2016 and EUR 10.32 in 2017. Our
ARPU is primarily determined by the amount of the fixed monthly subscription fee and the total voice traffic
volume of a user. The amount of a monthly license fee depends on the type and number of available optional
features and premium solutions and the maximum number of devices that can be used per seat. The license fee
also varies slightly from market to market. ARPU therefore reflects the attractiveness of our core features, op-
tional features and premium solutions and the success of our efforts to sell these services to our existing custom-
er base. In addition, the amount of the fixed monthly subscription fee is influenced by our pricing structure and
strategy which we determine, amongst other factors, depending on the market and competitive pressure.

The amount of the fixed monthly subscription fee and the tariffs for voice traffic varies greatly depending on the
distribution channel through which we sell our services (see "—10.2.4 Distribution Mix"). The fixed monthly
subscription fee is slightly higher for customers to which we sell our services through distributors and dealers
than for customers to which we market our services directly. The fixed monthly subscription fee and the fees for
voice traffic, if any, for services distributed through our wholesale partners are significantly below our overall
average. Finally, inflation rates also influence our pricing and, thus, our ARPU.
Distribution Mix

Our distribution strategy follows a multi-channel approach with the aim of enlarging our distribution reach and
addressing various customer target groups through different channels. We distribute our services primarily
through indirect distribution channels (i.e. our wholesale partners and our network of distributors and dealers).

Sales through wholesale partners generally yield a significantly below average Gross Profit Margin, as the aver-
age ARPU that we obtain for the seats of customers of our wholesale partners are significantly below our overall
average. The higher the portion of customers acquired through our wholesale partners, the lower the Gross Profit
Margin we earn on our revenue. The detrimental effect on our Gross Profit Margin is mitigated by lower market-
ing and personnel costs, as the acquisition efforts are undertaken by the wholesale partner. We believe that the
portion of our services that is sold to wholesale partners will increase in the future.

From the revenue that we generate with customers acquired and serviced by dealers, we pay a certain portion as
sales commission to compensate the dealers for the acquisition of the customer and for customer services pro-
vided by the dealers (for example, first level customer support) in equal parts during the entire customer lifetime
which reduces the profitability of our revenue generated with these customers. Where a distributor manages the
dealer that acquired the customer, we pay a sales commission to the distributor for managing the dealer in addi-
tion to the sales commission payable to the dealer. These sales commissions accounted for EUR 3,593 thousand
in 2017, EUR 2,520 thousand in 2016 and EUR 1,700 thousand in 2015 and are included in other operating ex-
penses in our consolidated statement of profit or loss. The detrimental effect on our profitability is mitigated by
(i) the fact that the fixed monthly subscription fee usually is slightly higher for customers to which we sell our
services through dealers and (ii) lower marketing and personnel costs, as the acquisition efforts are undertaken
by the dealers and, in case the dealers are managed by a distributor, the management of the dealers by the dis-
tributor.
Personnel Costs

Personnel costs account for a significant portion of our total costs and were the single highest cost item in the
periods under review. They include wages and salaries, social security contributions, share-based payment plans,
expenses for pensions and other benefits and other personnel costs. Our personnel costs increased by 16.83 %
from EUR 10,778 thousand in 2015 to EUR 12,592 thousand in 2016 and by a further 9.10 % to EUR 13,738
thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, personnel costs decreased from 51.44 % in 2015 to 41.44 % in
2016 and 38.53 % in 2017.

Our Adjusted Personnel Costs increased by 14.76 % from EUR 10,699 thousand in 2015 to EUR 12,279 thou-
sand in 2016 and by a further 8.93 % to EUR 13,376 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, Adjusted
Personnel Costs decreased from 51.07 % in 2015 to 40.41 % in 2016 and 37.52 % in 2017.

We believe our future performance depends in large part on highly specialised personnel with a very specific
skill set. We therefore plan to continue expanding our work force both domestically and internationally. We are
committed to paying competitive salaries in order to attract the talent necessary to sustain and grow our business
and the costs associated with doing so could have an impact on our results of operations going forward. We
believe that there is, and will continue to be, intense competition for highly skilled personnel with experience in
our industry across Europe and particularly in Germany. Competition is particularly intense with regard to soft-
ware engineers where the demand substantially exceeds the number of available candidates. We must provide

competitive compensation packages and a high-quality work environment to hire, retain and motivate employ-
ees. As we intend to further expand our workforce and competition for the personnel we require is very intense
and potentially intensifying, we believe that our personnel costs will continue to increase in the future.
Scale Effects

As we deliver our services from the cloud, we can expand them by increasing the capacity of our infrastructure
and delivery platform quickly and at little extra cost. As a result, the costs per seat of providing the NFON Cloud
Telephone Systems services become smaller, the higher the number of seats served. Certain other cost items not
related to our infrastructure and delivery platform such as personnel costs also do not increase fully linearly to
our revenue. Although our main strategic focus was and is on revenue growth rather than on increasing profita-
bility, we believe that our results of operations have benefited and will benefit from scale effects when expand-
ing our operations and increasing our customer base.
10.3 Basis of Presentation

Our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS.
IFRS 8 "Operating Segments" requires an entity to report financial and descriptive information about its reporta-
ble segments, which are operating segments or aggregations of operating segments that meet specified criteria.
Management reports our results primarily on a geographical basis based on the following three segments: Ger-
many, United Kingdom and Austria. The remaining three operating segments (Netherlands, Switzerland and
Spain) are not reporting segments and are discussed together as "Other countries". Revenues are attributed to
individual countries based on the Group sales office rather than the place of delivery. Segment results include
items directly attributable to the relevant segment as well as items that may be allocated on a reasonable basis,
while inter-segmental sales are eliminated. However, they do contain inter-segmental transfers and charges.
Management evaluates each segment's performance primarily on the basis of revenue and EBITDA. See the
section "9. Selected Consolidated Financial Information—9.4 Non-IFRS Financial and Operating Measures" for
how we define and calculate EBITDA, a reconciliation between EBITDA and income from continuing opera-
tions before net interest income and income taxes (the most directly comparable IFRS financial measure) and a
discussion about the limitations of EBITDA.

Our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements for the three years ended 31 December 2017 have been prepared
in Euro, which represents the functional and reporting currency of NFON AG. Unless otherwise indicated, all
figures in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements are rounded to the nearest thousand (EUR thousand).
Therefore, rounding differences may occur within the tables included in the notes to the Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements.

2017 compared with 2016
Group

Revenue. We principally generate revenue from telephone services. Most of our contracts relate to telephone
services with or without hardware sales and other services. In 2017, revenue increased by 17.33 %, from
EUR 30,388 thousand in 2016 to EUR 35,654 thousand in 2017. The increase in revenue was due primarily to
the acquisition of new customers and an increase in the number of users within our existing customer base, in
particular, in Germany, the United Kingdom and Austria. Management believes the overall growth in our
customer base reflects both our own distribution and marketing efforts as well as an overarching market trend
towards multi-tenant PBX. The total number of seats increased from 191,977 seats in 2016 to 253,360 seats in
2017, which corresponds to an increase by 31.97 %. This reflects the fact that the number of seats we lost was
more than offset by the number of seats we gained from new customers and customers that were already
customers at the beginning of the year.

Recurring revenue comprises revenue from monthly payments of a fixed license fee per seat and additional fixed
or volume-based fees for voice telephony usage. Non-recurring revenue is driven by the number of newly sold
seats and mainly consists of revenue from the sale of hardware as well as activation fees and professional
services in connection with the installation of premium solutions at our customers' premises. Recurring revenue
accounted for 77.87 % of our total revenue in 2017, compared with 71.10 % in 2016, whereas non-recurring
revenue accounted for 22.13 % in 2017 compared with 28.90 % in 2016. In 2016, non-recurring revenue
included service revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand generated in connection with setting up a wholesale
partnership. Disregarding this extraordinary effect, recurring revenue would have accounted for 74.79 % of the
total revenue in 2016. This revenue increase in 2017 reflects the successful growth of our business with our
existing customers. While we expect this trend to continue, we note that in any given year, the exact mix of
recurring and non-recurring revenue is subject to a multitude of factors. For example, some new customers may
initially subscribe to our services with a small number of seats followed by a larger user subscription in later
years, while other customers sign up a large number of seats upfront and grow more incrementally in the
following years. While the end result is the same in both cases, customers starting out with a smaller number of
seats will initially contribute less recurring revenue than customers signing up to a larger number of seats
upfront. Another factor is that the period of time between when customers sign up for our services and when
they purchase additional services may vary significantly.

Changes in inventories of finished goods and work in progress. Inventories mainly comprise hardware, e.g.,
telephone devices. Hardware on hand is usually minimal, as the relevant items are delivered to us by our
suppliers on a just-in-time basis whenever we request them to fill customer orders. In 2017, we recorded no
changes in inventories of finished goods, compared with an expense of EUR 150 thousand in 2016, owing to the
absence in 2017 of the work in progress item discussed under "—10.4.2 2016 compared with 2015—Group"
below.

Other operating income. In 2017, other operating income mainly comprised income resulting from non-cash
employee related benefits, the reversal of provisions and several other income. Other operating income increased
by 86.53 %, from EUR 245 thousand in 2016 to EUR 457 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, other
operating income remained stable, increasing only slightly from 0.81 % to 1.28 %. The increase in 2017 is
largely attributable to a one-off effect resulting from the reversal of provisions for cash settled share based
payments.

Cost of materials. Cost of materials are largely variable and mainly comprise costs for hardware sold, costs for
airtime sold and data centre housing costs. Cost of materials rose by 15.25 %, from EUR 8,421 thousand in 2016
to EUR 9,705 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, cost of materials remained virtually unchanged,
decreasing only slightly from 27.71 % to 27.22 % during the same period. Disregarding the extraordinary project
implementation revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand in 2016 mentioned above, cost of materials as a percentage of
revenue would have decreased from 29.15 % in 2016 to 27.22 % in 2017. Cost of materials are largely directly
correlated to revenue. The absolute increase in cost of materials in 2017 is a result of the growth of our business.
The decrease in relative terms, on the other hand, is a direct consequence of the fact that recurring revenue,
which generally has a higher gross margin than non-recurring revenue, increasingly accounts for a greater share
of our total revenue.

Personnel costs. Personnel costs comprise wages and salaries, social security contributions, share-based payment
plans, expenses for pensions and other benefits and other personnel costs. Personnel costs increased by 9.10 %,
from EUR 12,592 thousand in 2016 to EUR 13,738 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, personnel
costs decreased from 41.44 % to 38.53 %, which we believe further demonstrates the scalability of our business.
The increase in absolute terms is consistent with the growth of our business and reflects the impact of the
compensation paid for highly specialised personnel with specific skill sets, which we believe is key in expanding

our workforce. We expect that personnel costs, as a percentage of revenue, will generally decrease in the
medium to long term as a result of economies of scale.

Depreciation and amortisation. In 2016, depreciation and amortisation was EUR 544 thousand, compared with
EUR 671 thousand in 2017, corresponding to an increase of 23.35 %. As a percentage of revenue, depreciation,
and amortisation remained stable at approximately 2 %. This increase in absolute terms is a result of increased
investment and the depreciation and amortisation charges that this entails. Management expects to capitalise and
amortise some of our R&D costs going forward in accordance with IFRS, which may increase the level of
depreciation and amortisation in future years.

Other operating expenses. In 2017, other operating expenses comprised marketing expenses, sales commissions,
general administration expenses, supporting costs, selling costs, professional fees, consulting expenses, IT
expenses, travel expenses, rental costs and other personnel costs that were not allocable to any of the line items
discussed above. Other operating expenses increased by 34.43 %, from EUR 10,120 thousand in 2016 to
EUR 13,604 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, other operating expenses increased from 33.30 % to
38.16 %. The increase was primarily driven by increased marketing expenses and sales commissions as well as
higher professional fees and one-off consulting expenses.

Marketing expenses increased by 32.56 % from EUR 2,743 thousand in 2016 to EUR 3,636 thousand in 2017.
Historically, marketing expenses were fairly consistent at levels around EUR 3,000 to 4,000 thousand. The
decline in 2016 was due to a temporary reduction in marketing activities as result of budget reallocations.
Following the Offering, we expect to raise marketing expenses as we try to increasingly scale our services.

Sales commission, which represent a share of the revenue generated through dealers and distributors, increased
by 42.58 % from EUR 2,520 thousand in 2016 to EUR 3,593 thousand in 2017. This increase was mainly driven
by the increase of total revenue. In relative terms, sales commissions increased slightly as we generated more
revenue from indirect channels.

Other expenses mainly comprised professional fees and consulting expenses, general administration expenses
and other personnel costs. These costs are largely fixed and thus increased at a slower rate than revenue.

Professional fees and consulting expenses increased significantly from EUR 489 thousand in 2016 to EUR 1,134
thousand in 2017 primarily due to an increase of legal expenses and consulting expenses in connection with the
introduction of a transfer pricing model and the preparation of the Offering, as well as tax and social security
matters.

General administration expenses decreased slightly from EUR 1,019 thousand in 2016 to EUR 1,016 thousand in
2017. General administration expenses mainly reflect foreign exchange losses in the amount of EUR 170 thou-
sand in 2017, compared to EUR 508 thousand in 2016. In addition, general administration expenses included an
amount of EUR 176 thousand for non-deductible VAT in 2017.

The increase of other personnel costs from EUR 1,266 thousand in 2016 to EUR 1,706 thousand in 2017 was
primarily due to higher recruiting expenses, which were necessary to support our growth strategy, and due to the
need to hire freelancers in cases where new employees could not been recruited fast enough to support our path
of growth.

Impairment loss on trade and other receivables. Impairment loss on trade and other receivables decreased
significantly from an expense of EUR 55 thousand in 2016 to an income of EUR 39 thousand in 2017, due
mainly to the aging of the relevant receivables (which form the basis for the calculation under IFRS 9).

Other tax expense. Other tax expense comprised value added tax. Other tax expense rose substantially, from
EUR 14 thousand in 2016 to EUR 132 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, other tax expense
increased from 0.05 % to 0.37 %. This reflects VAT paid on expenses in connection with the preparation of the
Offering.

Net interest expense. In 2017, net interest expense rose by 35.16 %, from an expense of EUR 91 thousand in
2016 to an expense of EUR 123 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, net interest expense increased
slightly from 0.30 % to 0.34 %. This primarily reflects interest payable on loans extended to us by certain of our
shareholders and other related parties, all of which have since been refinanced.

Income tax expense. Income tax expense rose slightly by 2.05 %, from an expense of EUR 195 thousand in 2016
to an expense of EUR 199 thousand in 2017. As a percentage of revenue, income tax expense decreased slightly
from 0.64 % to 0.56 %. Minimum taxation rules applicable in Germany were the main cause of this.
Disregarding these rules, the profits we recorded at NFON AG in 2017 under transfer pricing principles would
have been offset in their entirety by loss carry-forwards generated in previous periods.
Deferred tax expense. We did not record any deferred tax expense in 2016 and 2017.

2016 compared with 2015
Group

Revenue. Revenue increased significantly by 45.04 %, from EUR 20,951 thousand in 2015 to EUR 30,388
thousand in 2016.

Recurring revenue accounted for 72.50 % of total revenue in 2015, compared with 71.10 % in 2016, whereas
non-recurring revenue accounted for 27.50 % in 2015 and 28.90 % in 2016. The slight decrease in recurring
revenue as a percentage of revenue reflects the impact of extraordinary project revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand
in 2016 discussed above. Disregarding this effect, recurring revenue as a percentage of total revenue would have
been 74.79 %. This reflects the fact that the average number of seats per customer went up.

Changes in inventories of finished goods and work in progress. In 2016, we recorded an expense of EUR 150
thousand in connection with changes in inventories of finished goods, compared with an income of EUR 150
thousand in 2015. The expense primarily reflects the release of accrued costs incurred in connection with work
in progress in relation to a one-time development project for a wholesaler we carried out in 2015.

Other operating income. Other operating income declined by 30.47 %, from EUR 352 thousand in 2015 to
EUR 245 thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, other operating income decreased from 1.68 % to
0.81 %. This decline reflects miscellaneous one-time items, none of which was significant individually.

Cost of materials. Cost of materials rose by 31.95 %, from EUR 6,382 thousand in 2015 to EUR 8,421 thousand
in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, cost of materials decreased slightly from 30.46 % to 27.71 % during the
same period. Disregarding the extraordinary project implementation revenue of EUR 1,500 thousand in 2016
discussed above, which did not correlate to any cost of materials, cost of materials as a percentage of revenue
would have decreased slightly from 30.46 % to 29.15 %. The absolute increase in cost of materials was primarily
driven by the expansion of our business, which was more than offset by economies of scale.

Personnel costs. Personnel costs increased by 16.83 %, from EUR 10,778 thousand in 2015 to EUR 12,592
thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, personnel costs decreased from 51.45 % to 41.44 %. The increase
in absolute terms reflects our need to employ highly specialised staff and was more than offset by growth of our
business and economies of scale.

Depreciation and amortisation. In 2016, we recorded an expense of EUR 544 thousand for depreciation and
amortisation compared to an expense of EUR 415 thousand in 2015, which is an increase by 31.08 %. As a
percentage of revenue, the expenses we recorded for depreciation and amortisation remained stable, decreasing
only slightly from 1.98 % to 1.79 % during the same period. The increase in absolute terms is a result of
increased investment and resulting depreciation and amortisation consistent with the growth of our business.

Other operating expenses. In 2016, other operating expenses comprised mainly marketing expenses, sales
commissions, general administration expenses and other personnel costs that are not allocable to any of the
expense items discussed above. Other operating expenses increased only slightly by 4.10 %, from EUR 9,721
thousand in 2015 to EUR 10,120 thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, other operating expenses
decreased from 46.40 % to 33.30 %. The absolute increase mainly reflects higher sales commissions and general
administration expenses, which also increased slightly in relative terms. This was partially offset by less
expenses in other areas.

Marketing expenses declined by 25.72 % from EUR 3,693 thousand in 2015 to EUR 2,743 thousand in 2016,
which was mainly attributable to a temporary reduction in marketing activities as result of budgets constraints.

Sales commissions increased by 48.24 % from EUR 1,700 thousand in 2015 to EUR 2,520 thousand in 2016.
The increase was mainly driven by the increase in revenue in total but also increased slightly as a percentage of
revenue due to higher share of revenue generated from indirect channels.

General administration expenses rose substantially by 125.94 % from EUR 451 thousand in 2015 to EUR 1,019
thousand in 2016. This reflects foreign exchange losses in the amount of EUR 508 thousand in 2016.

Impairment loss on trade and other receivables. Impairment loss on trade and other receivables decreased
significantly from an expense of EUR 171 thousand in 2015 to an expense of EUR 55 thousand in 2016, due
mainly to the aging of the relevant receivables (which form the basis for the calculation under IFRS 9).

Other tax expense. Other tax expense rose substantially by 100.00 %, from EUR 7 thousand in 2015 to EUR 14
thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, other tax expense remained virtually stable, increasing only
slightly from 0.03 % to 0.05 %.

Net interest expense. In 2016, net interest expense rose substantially, from an expense of EUR 31 thousand in
2015 to an expense of EUR 91 thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, net interest expense increased
from 0.15 % to 0.30 %. The increase in 2016 was driven primarily by interest payable on loans extended to us
during the year by certain shareholders and other related parties, which have since been refinanced.

Income tax expense. Income tax expense rose substantially from virtually zero in 2015 to an expense of EUR 195
thousand in 2016. As a percentage of revenue, income tax expense increased from 0.01 % to 0.64 %. The
increase in 2016 was mainly due to the minimum taxation rules applicable in Germany.
Deferred tax expense. We did not record any deferred tax expense in 2015 and 2016.

10.5 Liquidity and Capital Resources

Our liquidity needs arise principally from the need to finance our working capital and the expansion of our busi-
ness. In the period under review, most of our expenditures were operating expenditures, which are reflected in
our income statement. To finance these and meet other liquidity requirements we relied on cash flows from fi-
nancing activities and cash on hand. As a general matter, management believes we do not have a need for signif-
icant capital investment to drive our growth.

2017 compared with 2016
Cash flows from operating activities

Cash flows from operating activities was a cash outflow of EUR 341 thousand in 2017 compared with a cash
outflow of EUR 1,539 thousand in 2016. This reflects the fact that we incurred a net loss of EUR 2,021 thousand
in 2017 and the recognition of the purchase price for the acquisition of the remaining 49.8 % voting interest in
nfon GmbH, Austria, reflecting our strategy to own our operating subsidiaries. The effect of this was partially
offset by the effect of non-cash expenses, mostly depreciation and amortisation of tangible and intangible assets,
the net cash effect of our accounts receivables and payables management, which contributed a net EUR 2,156
thousand, and the cash effect of provisions, including for employee benefits.
Cash flows from investing activities

Cash flows from investing activities was a cash outflow of EUR 1,079 thousand in 2017, compared with a cash
outflow of EUR 433 thousand in 2016. This is mainly due to capital expenditures, mostly for IT equipment and
consolidation and reporting software, which compensate for a lower level of such investments in prior years, and
payments for the acquisition of the remaining 49.8 % voting interest in nfon GmbH, Austria, reflecting our strat-
egy to own our operating subsidiaries. As of 31 December 2017 only the first instalment of the purchase price
was paid.
Cash flows from financing activities

Cash flows from financing activities was a cash outflow of EUR 2,162 thousand in 2017, compared with a cash
inflow of EUR 1,350 thousand in 2016. This reflects the repayment of the related parties loans which were ex-
tended to us mainly in 2016 and repaid in 2017.

Cash flows from operating activities

Cash flows from operating activities was a cash outflow of EUR 1,539 thousand in 2016 compared with a cash

in 2016 and the net cash effect of our accounts receivables and payables management, which caused a cash out-
flow of EUR 1,907 thousand. The effect of this was partially offset by the effect of non-cash expenses.
Cash flows from investing activities

Cash flows from investing activities was a cash outflow of EUR 433 thousand in 2016, compared with a cash

Cash flows from financing activities

Cash flows from financing activities was a cash inflow of EUR 1,350 thousand in 2016, compared with a cash

Our current investments principally focus on increasing data centre capacity in Germany in order to be able to

vestments to shift to the entry into new markets consistent with our international growth strategy.
Capital Resources

We plan to continue to fund our operations from cash generated from operating activities as well as a variety of
debt and equity sources (including the proceeds from the Offering and bank borrowings). Management believes
we will have sufficient funds for our anticipated capital expenditure and other operating needs under its current
strategic plan. In the medium to long term, however, the actual amount of our financing requirements will vary
with our performance, market conditions and other factors, many of which are outside of our control and cannot
be predicted with any certainty. As a result, our future financing requirements may vary significantly from man-
agement's expectations.
Acquisition consideration payable

We have outstanding consideration payable for our acquisition of the remaining 49.8 % stake in nfon GmbH,
Austria in October 2017. The outstanding consideration bears interest at a rate per annum equal to 2.50 % over
the 3-month EURIBOR but at least 2.50 % per annum. As of 31 December 2017, our outstanding acquisition

consideration payable amounted to EUR 2,335 thousand (including interest of EUR 10 thousand). The consid-
eration is due on 31 May 2018, hence, it is classified as short term financial liability. See "13. Business—13.15
Material Contracts—13.15.9 Acquisition of 49.8 % of the shares in nfon GmbH" for more information.
Other material borrowings

We entered into a revolving credit facility in January 2017 with a maximum available credit line of up to
EUR 8,000 thousand. The credit line utilisation has been gradually increased in steps of EUR 2,000 thousand and
amounted to EUR 4,000 thousand as of 31 December 2017. The interest rate is variable and changes based on
changes to the monthly average of three-month EURIBOR. In the beginning of 2018, the remaining credit facili-
ty was swapped to two credit facilities in the total amount of EUR 3,100 thousand in order to finance the acquisi-
tion consideration payable related to the minority shareholding in nfon GmbH, Austria. (See "13. Business—
13.15 Material Contracts—13.15.8 Loan Agreement and Acquisition loan with UniCredit Bank AG" for more
information on material borrowings.) We also entered into a financing agreement in Austria in order to finance
hardware purchases. The agreement was entered into in light of the fact that when we sell hardware to customers,
we may agree with them to pay the price for the hardware over the duration of the contract. Therefore, working
capital financing was used historically whenever hardware for such types of contracts was sold. The working
capital loan was granted by H. Schebesta und A. Holzinger Mobilienleasing Gesellschaft n.b.R., an Austrian
company under civil law (Gesellschaft nach bürgerlichen Recht) which is owned by, inter alia, a shareholder and
a natural person related to a shareholder of the entity that held the minority stake in nfon GmbH up until
30 October 2017. Historically, the average interest rate on monthly drawings was 13 % p.a. and the average
repayment term for drawings was 36 months. The remaining loan amount as at 31 December 2017 was EUR 230
thousand. Since August 2017, no new loans have been received under this agreement. See "18. Certain Relation-
ships and Related-Party Transactions—18.2 Other Related Party Transactions—18.2.3 Loans From Related
Parties" for more information.

Off-balance Sheet Arrangements
We have no material off-balance sheet arrangements.

10.7 Financial Risk Management

In addition to general financial market risks, we have exposure to the following risks arising from financial in-
struments:
      Credit risks
      Liquidity risk
      Market risks (interest risks and currency risks)
Risk management framework

Our Management Board has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of our risk management
framework.

Our risk management policies are established to identify and analyse the risks we face, to set appropriate risk
limits and controls and to monitor risks and adherence to limits. Risk management policies and systems are re-
viewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and our activities. We aim to maintain a disciplined and
constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and obligations through our
training and management standards and procedures.
General Financial Market Risks

We are, and upon completion of the Offering will be, exposed to various financial market risks as part of our
business activity.

We have developed guidelines for risk management processes and for the use of financial instruments including
a clear separation of tasks with respect to financial activities, invoicing, financial reporting and associated con-
trolling. We actively monitor these risks using a risk management system.

The following sections discuss our significant exposure to market risk. The following discussions do not address
other risks that we face in the normal course of business, including country risk and legal risk.
Credit Risk

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to us if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet
its contractual obligations, and arises principally from our receivables from customers. The carrying amount of
financial assets represents the maximum credit exposure.

We consider the management of our commercial credit risk to be critical in order to achieve our goals for sus-
tainable growth of our business and our customer base in accordance with our risk management guidelines. We
believe that suitable processes have been established for management and monitoring of credit risk. These in-
clude ongoing monitoring of the expected risks and the level of default. Particular attention is paid to customers
who could have a significant effect on our consolidated financial statements and for whom, depending on the
business area and the type of business relationship, appropriate credit management instruments are used to limit
the credit risk.
Trade and other receivables

Our exposure to credit risk is influenced mainly by the individual characteristics of each customer. However,
management also considers the factors that may influence the credit risk of our customer base, including the
default risk associated with the country in which customers operate.

As of 31 December 2015, 31 December 2016 and 31 December 2017, our total maximum exposure to credit risk
for trade and other receivables amounted to EUR 2,802 thousand, EUR 3,805 thousand and EUR 4,628 thou-
sand, respectively.

For additional information on our credit risk, see Note 20 of the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements
reproduced in the "Financial Section" section of this Prospectus.
Concentrations of credit risk

Concentrations of risks are determined by management based on amounts outstanding from individual customers
as at period end. Due to our pan-European activities and diversified customer structure, there is no significant
concentration of credit risk except with one customer – Telefónica Germany. The receivable balance due from
this customer as at 31 December 2017 was EUR 851 thousand. For the years ended as of 31 December 2016 and
2015 the balances outstanding from this customer were not significant.
Cash and cash equivalents

We held cash and cash equivalents of EUR 2,176 thousand at 31 December 2017 (2016: EUR 5,777 thousand,
2015: EUR 6,397 thousand). The cash and cash equivalents are held with bank and financial institution counter-
parties, which are rated A-1 to A-2, based on S&P Global's ratings.

Impairment on cash and cash equivalents has been measured on a 12-month expected loss basis and reflects the
short term maturities of the exposures. We consider our cash and cash equivalents to have low credit risk based
on the external credit ratings of the counterparties. On the initial application of IFRS 9, NFON recognised no
impairment allowance as the amounts are considered not material.
Liquidity risk

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will encounter difficulties in meeting the obligations associated with our finan-
cial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. Our approach to managing liquidity is
to ensure, as far as possible, that we will have sufficient liquidity to meet our liabilities when they are due, under
both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation.

We aim to maintain our level of cash and cash equivalents at an amount in excess of expected cash outflows on
financial liabilities (other than trade payables). We also monitor the level of expected cash inflows on trade re-
ceivables together with expected cash outflows on trade and other payables. Also in order to avoid concentration
of liquidity risks with cash inflows from the normal course of sales, we also maintain a line of credit (i.e., a re-
volving credit facility) with a total facility amount of EUR 4,000 thousand as of 31 December 2017, with an
interest rate of 8.00 % per year and at commitment fee of 1.50 % per year.
Market risk

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices such as changes in exchange rates and interest rates will
affect the value of our financial instruments or our earnings. The objective of market risk management is to man-
age and control market risk exposures within acceptable parameters, while optimising the return.
Currency risk

We are exposed to currency risk to the extent that there is a mismatch between the currencies in which revenue,
purchases and borrowings are denominated and the respective functional currencies of our Group companies.
The functional currencies of our Group companies are primarily Euro and Great Britain Pounds.
Interest rate risk

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value of a financial instrument could fluctuate as a result of changes in
market interest rates.

Our interest rate exposure relates to short term loans, which are subject to fixed and floating interest rates. Our
objective is to minimise the cost of net borrowings and to minimise the impact of interest rate movements on our
interest expense and net earnings.

Accruals and provisions

enacted at the reporting date. The measurement of deferred taxes reflects the tax consequences that would follow

Deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities are offset if the conditions for doing so are met.

Technical Background
Technical Background of a PBX

A PBX provides for interconnection of communication devices such as phones or fax machines of a user with
each other and the public switched telephone network ("PSTN"). The connectivity between the PSTN and the
PBX is established either via traditional technologies (analogue lines or lines using Time Division Multiplexing
("TDM"), e.g. integrated service digital network ("ISDN")) or via Voice over Internet Protocol ("VoIP") tech-
nologies (e.g. SIP trunks) and allows for a certain amount of concurrent calls. Depending on the type of technol-
ogy used and the regulations in individual countries, the user can be reached via one or more individual phone
numbers (which is common in the United States) or Direct Inward Dialling (DID) number blocks (which is very
common in Europe).
The main features of a PBX are:

   Concentration: Any number of end-users (e.g. employees) and communication devices can be operated
    behind a PBX regardless of the amount of concurrent lines between the PBX and the PSTN (so-called
    "trunk lines") and regardless of the amount of public telephone numbers (e.g. the amount of available
    DIDs).
   Intercommunication: Any user and communication device can connect to any other user and communica-
    tion device behind the same PBX without using the PSTN and the scarce (and expensive) communication
    lines between the PBX and the PSTN thus enabling free calls within the organisation.

The amount of concurrent external calls between users on the PSTN and users behind the PBX is mainly limited
by the amount of concurrent PSTN trunk lines connecting the PSTN network and the PBX but can also be lim-
ited by the capacity of the PBX itself. The amount of internal calls (between users behind the PBX) is only lim-
ited by the capacity of the PBX.

PBX can be divided into on-premise PBX and off-premise PBX.
On-premise PBX
The following chart illustrates the way on-premise PBX operate:

On-premise PBX are operated within an office (or a data centre) of their user and can be either hardware or
software-based. Prior to the development of VoIP based systems on-premise PBX were mostly hardware-based
and used proprietary protocols for communication between telephone devices and the PBX. Telephone devices
used in on-premise PBX are often vendor specific without interoperability, meaning that the change of a PBX
typically results in the need to also replace all telephone devices. With the ongoing development and standardisa-
tion of VoIP protocols (mainly SIP and RTP), on-premise PBX started using VoIP for communication between
telephone devices and the PBX. In addition, modern on-premise PBX using VoIP technology are distributed and
operated as software-based solutions instead of vendor specific hardware-based systems. VoIP uses computer
networks (LAN, WAN) to connect telephone devices to the PBX instead of proprietary cabling. Moreover, it
provides a common protocol stack generally allowing interoperability so that the change of a PBX does not nec-
essarily result in the need to also replace all telephone devices.
On-premise PBX offer full control over the entire business telephony solution but have several limitations:

   The number of trunk lines limits the number of concurrent calls between the PSTN and the telephone
    system at the customers' premises.
   Trunk redundancy: While it is theoretically possible to make trunk lines redundant, it is very complex and
    expensive. The vast majority of trunk lines are not redundant and if they fail, the organisation will not be
    able to use telephone services.
   PBX redundancy: Due to the high costs and complexity involved, only few organisations operate redun-
    dant PBX. As a result, failure of the PBX can result in an organisation not being able to use telephone
    services.
   PBX scalability: On-premise PBX usually do not scale very well resulting in the need of costly replace-
    ment PBX with a higher capacity.
   PBX functionality: New functionalities (voicemail, UCC, fax, contact centre etc.) sometimes require new
    or additional hardware.
   Location-based: Depending on the on-premise solution and the organisation operating it, an on-premise
    PBX that services multiple locations and offices is very complex and expensive, and could even be im-
    possible to implement.
   Security/Updates: PBX are increasingly victims of cyberattacks. Yet keeping on-premise PBX updated
    and secure is a complex and cost intensive task because any update has to be installed on each system
    separately, which most IT departments are not capable of handling appropriately and organisations must
    therefore rely on third-party service providers.
Off-premise PBX

Off-premise PBX are available as hardware and software-based systems. Software based PBX use software ap-
plications and run on standard hardware components, whereas hardware-based systems rely on PBX specific
hardware.

Off-premise PBX are not located within an office or a data centre of their user but rather in hosted data centres.
Off-premise PBX can be categorised into private single-instance (sometimes also referred to as "Hosted PBX")
and public single-instance systems as well as public multi-instance and public multi-tenant systems (public sin-

gle-instance, public multi-instance and public multi-tenant systems also referred to as "Cloud PBX", and togeth-
er with the Hosted PBX, the "Hosted/Cloud PBX").

Private single-instance PBX are typically VoIP-based, owned by their user and can either be hardware or soft-
ware-based. They are deployed and operated in data centres. They are not sold as a service, but their users make
an upfront investment into acquiring and establishing the PBX, which is thereby deployed as a capital expendi-
ture rather than an operating expenditure which typically characterises Cloud PBX solutions and Software as a
Service ("SaaS") solutions in general.

Public single-instance PBX are VoIP-based and provide for a dedicated PBX system for each user. However,
unlike in private single-instance PBX, the PBX belongs to the service provider and is sold to the user as a ser-
vice.

The difference between a public multi-instance PBX and a public single-instance PBX is that in a public multi-
instance PBX even though a certain amount of central management and other shared components might exist,
there is still a dedicated system/instance for each customer.

there is still a dedicated system/instance for each customer.
A public multi-tenant PBX is similar to a public multi-instance PBX except that there is no separate instance for

each customer, but a fully shared platform.
The following factors limit the adoption of Hosted/Cloud PBX:

   Security & Reliability: Potential customers may have concerns over security, data control and service
    reliability of Hosted/Cloud PBX.
   Connectivity: Hosted/Cloud PBX depend on the development and reliability of public telecommunica-
    tions and other data transmission infrastructure.
   Features: Many Hosted/Cloud PBX have a standardised feature set and are less customisable than on–
    premise PBX.
We provide a public multi-tenant PBX. The following chart illustrates the way public multi-tenant PBX, like the

NFON Cloud Telephone System, operate:




               Unified communications as a service (UCaaS)

We market a number of premium solutions, such as a contact centre solution and voice recording solution that
are integrated into our NFON Cloud Telephone System. In the future, we intend to supplement our service offer-
ing with additional Unified communications as a service ("UCaaS") solutions such as video conferencing and
collaboration features such as screen sharing or chat functions.

UCaaS is a cloud delivery model that offers a variety of communication and collaboration applications and ser-
vices. UCaaS features include enterprise messaging, presence technology, online meetings, team collaboration,
telephony and video conferencing. Many UCaaS vendors also offer contact centre capabilities, including auto-
attendant, interactive voice response, call routing and customer relationship management integrations.

UCaaS vendors increasingly add communications platform as a service ("CPaaS") capabilities and application
programming interfaces ("APIs") to their cloud platforms. Customers can use CPaaS capabilities and APIs to
embed cloud-based communication features into their business applications and workflows.
Market
Macroeconomic development

The overall economic development in Germany and in the euro area has been generally positive since 2014. The
gross domestic product ("GDP") growth rate in Germany increased from 1.9 % in 2014 to 2.2 % in 2017
(Source: Eurostat Real GDP Growth Rate). In the euro area the GDP growth rate increased from 1.3 % in 2014
to 2.3 % in 2017 (Source: Eurostat Real GDP Growth Rate). The Winter 2018 Interim Economic Forecast by the
European Commission has estimated that the GDP growth rate in the euro area was 2.4 % in 2017 (Source: Eu-
ropean Commission). According to the Ifo Institute, the upswing seen in the German economy since 2013 has
accelerated markedly in 2017 and is expected to continue for the next two years. (Source: Ifo Institute) It is ex-
pected that the real GDP in Germany will increase at an annual rate of 2.6 % on average in 2018 and by 2.1 % on
annual average in 2019. The growth rate for the real GDP in the euro area is expected to be 2.5 % in 2018 and
2.0 % in 2019. (Source: Ifo Institute) The upturn in the euro area was mainly driven by private consumption and
private investments, which benefit from a better situation in the labour markets of the member states and im-
proved access to credit. (Source: Ifo Institute) According to the Ifo Institute, the early economic indicators for
the euro area, such as the consumer and corporate confidence indices and improvements in the labour market
situation or in the access to credit remain consistently positive and point to the continuation of the upturn.
(Source: Ifo Institute)

European and National PBX Markets
General Market Characteristics and Trends

As at 31 December 2017, the estimated number of all PBX seats1 in the market for business PBX ("PBX Mar-
ket") in Europe amounted to 134.7 million, compared to 135.0 million as at 31 December 2014. (Source: MZA)
It is estimated that the number of all PBX seats in the PBX Market in Europe will increase to approximately
135.7 million by 31 December 2022. (Source: MZA)

The European PBX Market can be broken down into an on-premise PBX (TDM) market, an on-premise PBX
(IP) market and a Hosted/Cloud PBX market, which is composed of a private single-instance PBX market (the
"Hosted PBX Market"), a public single-instance PBX market, a public multi-instance PBX market and a public
multi-tenant PBX market (together the "Cloud PBX Market" and together with the Hosted PBX Market, the
"Hosted/Cloud PBX Market"). (Source: MZA)

The European PBX Market is steadily shifting towards Hosted/Cloud PBX (Source: MZA). We believe that one
of the main drivers of this development is the transition from ISDN to All-IP networks by the European telecom
carriers, such as Deutsche Telekom which intends to switch off its ISDN network (Source: Deutsche Telekom).
We believe that the essential motive for switching to All-IP networks is cost efficiency by merging two separate
infrastructures (Internet and dedicated PSTN equipment) into one IP/VoIP based technology. Additional motives
include faster time to market for new services, technologies and service attributes and the simplified implemen-
tation of new platforms.

The complex, on-site, hardware based PBX (TDM) is expected to increasingly be replaced by All-IP platforms,
such as Hosted/Cloud PBX or on-premise PBX (IP). (Source: MZA) The on-premise PBX (TDM) requires up-
front investment and is expensive to maintain or upgrade and offers only limited scalability. The Company be-
lieves that on-premise PBX (IP) mainly attracts customers that intend to protect existing PBX investments in old
PBX equipment while still aiming to move away from ISDN and to save on the costs of voice traffic. The Com-
pany believes that the main advantages of a Hosted/Cloud PBX over an on-premise PBX (IP) are its flexibility
(e.g. as a result of easy administration), scalable technology, and increased mobility (as a result of the possibility
to use multiple-communication devices) and normally lower total cost of ownership (e.g. operational expendi-
ture) as well as location independence. Further drivers of the Cloud PBX Market are:

     The proliferation of SaaS delivery models: SaaS delivery is the backbone of an emerging software model
      that eliminates the need for customers to incur the expense of purchasing or maintaining expensive serv-
      ers and software. SaaS delivery allows organisations to significantly reduce the cost of using and main-
      taining software because the cloud services provider bears the expense of maintaining the applications
      and hardware on which the applications run. With SaaS delivery, the capital and operational expenses
      normally associated with hosting on-premise software applications are shifted from customers to the
      cloud software services provider.
     Increasing multi-channel and multi-device communication: Multi-channel and multi-device communica-
      tion enables users to interact with each other and with businesses on various platforms. In terms of busi-
      ness communication, this establishes the need for organisations to appropriately manage the various
      communication channels to provide customer support and optimise the customer experience and satisfac-
      tion.
     The way we work is changing: the modern work environment with an increasing adoption of location
      independent models, such as home office work, triggers a need for location independent communication
      and collaboration tools.
The following factors may hinder the adoption of Hosted/Cloud PBX:
     Data protection legislation may limit the use of Hosted/Cloud PBX.
     A change to a recurring revenue model can be financially challenging in the short term for distributors
      and dealers which could incentivise them to continue to market on-premise PBX.
     In certain usage scenarios of Hosted/Cloud PBX, the total costs of ownership can be higher than for on-
      premise PBX.

The European PBX Market by Technology

The market penetration of Hosted/Cloud PBX in all PBX in the European PBX Market measured by seats is
estimated to have increased to more than 10 % as at 31 December 2017, from more than 5 % as at 31 December
2014. This penetration rate is expected to increase to more than 25 % by 31 December 2022. (Source: MZA)
Hosted/Cloud PBX penetration is primarily driven by major carriers discontinuing operation of their ISDN net-
works as well as the advantages of Hosted/Cloud PBX, such as location independence, extended feature sets or,
in many cases, lower total cost of ownership. (Source: MZA)

It is expected that a significant number of seats of on-premise PBX (TDM) will continue to be used by custom-
ers, who either evaluate their cloud strategy or make IT investments in other areas as long as the TDM technolo-
gy is still available to them (Source: MZA). On-premise PBX (IP) technology is expected to be increasingly
employed by customers with existing, not fully depreciated on-premise PBX as a transition technology before
moving on to Hosted/Cloud PBX (Source: MZA).

The number of seats of on-premise PBX (TDM) is expected to decrease from 31 December 2017 until 31 De-
cember 2022 at a compound annual growth rate ("CAGR") of -8.6 %. In contrast, during the same period, the
number of seats of Hosted/Cloud PBX is expected to increase at a CAGR of 15.6 % and the number of seats of
on-premise PBX (IP) at a CAGR of 2.1 %. The CAGR of overall PBX seats is expected to be 0.1 % between 31
December 2017 and 31 December 2022. (Source: MZA)
The European Cloud PBX Market by Technology

As at 31 December 2017, the estimated number of Cloud PBX seats in the European PBX Market amounted to
12.5 million. It is estimated that of all seats in the European PBX Market as at 31 December 2017, approximate-
ly 9 % were Cloud PBX seats, compared to 5 % as at 31 December 2014. It is estimated that the number of
Cloud PBX seats will increase to 25.8 million or 19 % in all seats of the European PBX Market by 31 December
2022 (Source: MZA)

Public multi-tenant PBX are primarily adopted by small and medium sized customers, with less than 100 seats,

The Public Multi-Tenant Cloud PBX Market in Germany and in the United Kingdom

In Germany, the estimated number of public multi-tenant PBX was 0.6 million seats, as at 31 December 2017.

caused by several factors, including German customers having historically been conservative about adopting

In comparison to Germany, the overall PBX Market in the United Kingdom has significantly fewer seats. How-

11.3   Competition

The European Hosted/Cloud PBX Market is highly fragmented with a large number of very small local players
with only several thousand seats serviced. Only some of these smaller companies have their proprietary Cloud
PBX solution with many of them building a service offering around a solution from technology vendors such as
Broadsoft or Cisco. US competitors such as RingCentral or 8x8 have entered the European market only to a
limited extent with a presence concentrated in the United Kingdom acting as their natural European bridge head.
Incumbent carriers have traditionally not offered their own public multi-tenant Cloud PBX products (for reasons
of protection of profitable legacy business, etc.), but have instead offered third party cloud telephony solutions as
white label or co-branded solutions.

We compete in a fast changing environment. Our competitors in the field of business communication include
Hosted/Cloud PBX specialists, on-premise PBX and software based vendors as well as UCaaS technology ven-
dors. Depending on the offered products and services as well as their customer focus, most of our competitors
address only a certain portion of our potential customers without covering the full range of our services, or do
not currently possess the necessary skill set and expertise in order to offer Cloud PBX services.

In the Hosted/Cloud PBX market, we compete with various competitors including cloud delivery model provid-
ers and incumbent telephone companies:
Cloud delivery model providers

In the cloud communications industry, we face competition from US providers (e.g. Cisco through its subsidiar-
ies Broadsoft and Placetel, RingCentral, and 8x8) and European providers (e.g. easycall, Fuze, Gamma, j2global,
Sipgate, Telecom, Vonage, voz, Voz Telecom and vozelia) of UCaaS cloud delivery models that offer a variety
of communication and collaboration applications and services such as enterprise messaging, presence technolo-
gy, online meetings, team collaboration, telephony and video conferencing as well as cloud PBX system ser-
vices. The large providers in this area are US-based, although they currently have only a small footprint in Con-
tinental Europe, such as Cisco through its German subsidiary Placetel, if any. Due to low language barriers and
similar PBX user patterns, US competitors are, in particular, very active in the United Kingdom.
Incumbent telephone companies

We compete with incumbent telephone companies which historically sold communications services along with
legacy on-premise communication equipment. These competitors include, for example, BT, Deutsche Telekom,
Orange and Vodafone, all in conjunction with on-premise hardware solutions from companies such as Avaya,
Cisco, NEC, Unify, Aastra, Alcatel-Lucent and Mitel. They offer PBX services on the basis of third-party or
self-developed solutions.
