12.REGULATORY AND LEGAL ENVIRONMENT

Our operations are subject to sector-specific telecommunications regulations as well as to a variety of other regu-
latory requirements in Germany and other countries in which we operate.
Telecommunication Regulation

The liberalisation of the German telecommunications sector began in 1989 (the so-called Postreform I). The
liberalisation was in line with the European Community policy at that time which intended to break up monopo-
listic structures in the European telecommunications markets. It was continued in 1994 with the so-called Postre-
form II, which, inter alia, effected a constitutional change, allowing for the privatisation of Deutsche Telekom,
the former state owned telecommunication monopolist. In 1996, the initial German Telecommunications Act
(Telekommunikationsgesetz) came into force. Since the break off of Deutsche Telekom's last monopoly (voice
telephony) on 1 January 1998, the telecommunications market in Germany is regarded as liberalised.

Today, the provision of telecommunications services and the operation of telecommunications networks are
subject to the regulatory regime of the German Telecommunications Act of 22 June 2004, as amended on 30
October 2017 (Telekommunikationsgesetz, the "Telecommunications Act"), and certain regulations that sup-
plement the Telecommunications Act.

The Telecommunications Act implements the European Regulatory Framework for Electronic Communications
Networks and Services which was amended in November 2009 (the "Framework"). The Framework consists of,
amongst other provisions, the Framework Directive (2002/21/EC), the Authorisation Directive (2002/20/EC), the
Access Directive (2002/19/EC), the Universal Service Directive (2002/22/EC) and the Directive on Privacy and
Electronic Communications (2002/58/EC).

In November 2009, the European Parliament, following a proposal by the European Commission, passed legisla-
tion amending certain directives within the Framework in order to strengthen competition and consumer rights in
Europe's telecom markets and to facilitate access to high-speed broadband internet connections. The changes to
the existing Framework came into effect on 19 December 2009, and had to be transposed into national law. This
led to an amendment of the Telecommunications Act which entered into force in May 2012. Since 2012, the
Telecommunications Act has been subject to several other amendments, inter alia through the new law on the
security of IT systems (IT-Sicherheitsgesetz), the law on the selection and connection of telecommunication
terminal equipment (Gesetz zur Auswahl und zum Anschluss von Telekommunikationsendgeräten), the law on the
new regulations for radio equipment (Gesetz zur Neufassung der Regelungen über Funkanlagen und zur Ände-
rung des Telekommunikationsgesetzes sowie zur Aufhebung des Gesetzes über Funkanlagen und Telekommuni-
kationsendeinrichtungen), the law facilitating the expansion of digital high-speed networks (Gesetz zur Erleich-
terung des Ausbaus digitaler Hochgeschwindigkeitsnetze) and the law on the implementation of the data retenti-
on obligations (Gesetz zur Einführung einer Speicherpflicht und einer Höchstspeicherfrist für Verkehrsdaten).

The Telecommunications Act contains provisions regarding, among other things: (i) the establishment and pow-
ers of the regulatory body; (ii) notification requirements; (iii) the granting of rights of way; (iv) the allocation of
frequencies and numbers; (v) access obligations; (vi) the regulation of rates; (vii) restriction of abusive behav-
iour; (viii) customer protection; and (ix) data protection and public safety. Some of these obligations only apply
to providers which have significant market power in their respective markets. Other obligations, in particular
with respect to customer protection, data privacy and public safety, apply or might be imposed by the Federal
Network Agency (Bundesnetzagentur) in Germany (the "FNA") even if those operators do not have significant
market power but rather are mere providers of telecommunications services or operators of telecommunications
networks.

On 14 September 2016, the European Commission published a new draft European Electronic Communications
Code ("EECC") to amend the existing European regulatory framework.

The main objectives of the EECC are to increase competition and predictability for investments, to improve the
use of radio-frequencies, to strengthen consumer protection, and to create a safer online environment for users
and fairer rules for all players. The latter includes in particular online service providers that offer equivalent
services as traditional operators (so-called "over-the-top" or "OTT" service providers).

As the draft EECC is still negotiated and discussed between the European Parliament, the European Commission
and the European Council, it is not possible to estimate when and to what extent the EECC will be finally adopt-
ed.
The Regulatory Body

The FNA is, amongst other things, responsible for the regulation of the German telecommunications market. It
has at its disposal significant powers regarding the enforcement of telecommunications laws and regulations.
These powers include the authority to approve or review telecommunications charges as well as general business
terms and conditions of providers. Furthermore, the FNA is the competent authority to administer numbering and
to ensure data protection and network safety in the telecommunication sector. The FNA's decisions may be chal-
lenged in the relevant administrative courts.
Notification Requirements

The operation of telecommunications networks and the provision of telecommunications services no longer re-
quire a license from a regulatory body. However, commercial operators of public telecommunications networks
and commercial providers of publicly available telecommunications services must notify the FNA of the com-
mencement, any modification and the termination of their business activities.

We are notified with the FNA as a commercial provider of publicly available telecommunications services.
Furthermore, the use of numbers requires a number allocation.
Interconnection, Access Obligations, Rate Regulation and Call Termination
Interconnection and network access

The FNA may impose on operators of public telecommunications networks with significant market power the
obligation to grant other companies access to their services or to their networks. In particular, the FNA may
impose the obligation to grant access to certain telecommunications services on an unbundled basis. This means
that the operator must offer access to its network or its services in a manner that does not force the other party to
purchase any services that it does not require. Among other things, the FNA is authorised to impose on operators
the obligation (i) to grant access to certain network components and certain facilities as designated by the FNA,
and (ii) to offer the re-sale of their telecommunications services on a wholesale basis. However, we are neither
considered to have significant market power on the German telecommunications market, nor do we operate a
public telecommunications network in Germany and are therefore not subject to such regulation.

Under certain conditions, the FNA may also impose access obligations if the operators do not have significant
market power but control end-user access. Regardless of whether or not an operator has significant market pow-
er, it is obligated to offer any other operator, upon the request of the FNA, the interconnection of both parties'
networks, provided that the interconnection is technically feasible.
Rate Regulation and call termination

The rates charged by operators of public telecommunications networks on which the FNA has imposed such
access obligations may be subject to rate regulation under the Telecommunications Act. Rate regulation consists
of either ex-ante-rate regulation or ex-post rate regulation of the relevant rates. However, the FNA may also
decide not to impose rate regulation irrespective of an access obligation imposed on the network operator. Under
the ex-ante rate regulation, FNA's approval of the rates charged by the operator is required prior to their applica-
tion.
The Telecommunications Act provides for two basic approaches to prior approvals of rates: price-cap regulation
and individual approvals on the basis of the costs of efficient service provision. In addition, under these two
types of ex-ante regulation, the FNA shall not issue a rate approval in case the rates amount to an abuse of the
operator's significant market power
If rates are subject to ex-post rate regulation by the FNA, the relevant rates do not need to pass a review process

before the operator having significant market power charges those to other network operators or service provid-
ers, except if the FNA has imposed a notification obligation upon the operator. However, the FNA may prohibit
rates if, after carrying out a review at a later stage, the FNA comes to the conclusion that charging such rates
amounts to an abuse of the operator's significant market power. The FNA may furthermore order the application
of rates which it deems fit.

With respect to the provision of virtual telephone services, the previously mentioned provisions of the Telecom-
munications Act also apply.

According to the FNA several companies providing telecommunications services on the German market have
significant market power, for example with respect to the market of call termination on individual public tele-

phone networks provided at a fixed location or the market for voice call termination on individual mobile net-
works.
However, we are neither considered to have significant market power on the German telecommunications market
nor do we operate a public telecommunications network in Germany and, thus, are not subject to such access or
rate related regulations or requirements.
Irrespective of the application of these obligations, the aforementioned rate regulation may indirectly affect our
business activities. In particular, if higher rates are approved this could lead to increasing prices in our supplier
contracts.

Further, as a basis for some of our end customer products we purchase wholesale services from third party sup-
pliers which are subject to the above described access and re-sale obligations. Accordingly, any change of the
corresponding legislation may have an impact on our business activities in this regard.
Internet Access

In connection with the commercial provision of internet access services to end customers, the same provisions of
the Telecommunications Act apply as set out above. The regulations under the Telecommunications Act do not
differentiate between the content (phone or internet data) transmitted via telecommunications network.

We do not have significant market power within the market for such internet access services. The end customer
market is also not listed in the current Commission Recommendation on relevant product and service markets
(2014/710/EU). Therefore, we are not and do not expect to be subject to any competitive regulation regarding the
internet access market.
Consumer and Customer Protection

The Telecommunications Act contains various strict provisions for the protection of consumers. The protection
of consumers was further strengthened by the above-mentioned reform of the Framework. According to the
definition in the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch), which is applicable here, "consumer" refers to
every natural person who enters into a legal transaction for a purpose that is outside his trade, business or profes-
sion.

Our telecommunications services are not targeted at consumers and we do not enter into contractual agreements
with consumers but rather only with business customers, including small and medium sized enterprises. Accord-
ingly, we are not subject to the strict regulations on consumer protection.

Apart from the consumer-related obligations, the Telecommunications Act provides for protection provisions
which apply to services provided to (business) customers (users, end users or subscribers). "User" means a natu-
ral person using a telecommunications service for private or business purposes and "end users" are users which
themselves do not operate telecommunications networks or provide telecommunications services.

The customer-related provisions concern, among other things, (i) mandatory information to be provided upon
request in agreements with end users, (ii) duration of contracts as well as certain rights and obligations of the
contracting parties and of third parties engaged in telecommunications traffic, (iii) quality of service, (iv) details
of delivery periods, (v) obligations regarding waiting loops (Warteschleifen), (vii) specific obligations toward
disabled end users, (viii) the operator's liability vis-à-vis the end users, (ix) entries in directories and directory
enquiry service databases, (x) the blocking of the subscriber's line, (xi) billing and (xii) out-of-court dispute
resolution procedures for customers.

Further, the FNA is authorised under Section 43a para. 3 of the Telecommunications Act to determine the details
of the description of the type and relevant technical performance data of offered telecommunications services.
Number Portability and Continuity of Service

In the case of a change of the provider by the customer, each public phone network operator is obligated to allow
for number portability. Customers must be able to retain their phone number, in the case of geographic numbers,
at a specific location and in the case of non-geographic numbers at any location. The relevant telecommunication
service must not be discontinued for more than one calendar day. Customers of mobile telephone service provid-
ers may transfer their mobile telephone number to another provider at any time. The duration of their telephone
service contract with the original provider is not affected by such transfer.
12.6   Numbering Issues

The FNA is the competent authority for the administration of numbering issues. It is responsible for structuring
and configuring the national number space in Germany. The FNA also allocates (telephone) numbers to tele-
communications network operators, telecommunications service providers and end-users.

When numbers are allocated (for example, local or mobile numbers for end-customers) certain conditions (for
example, with regard to the transfer of numbers), as set out in the respective number allocation rules issued by
the FNA, have to be complied with.
Network Neutrality

The Regulation (EU) 2015/2120 on open internet access sets forth rules which should ensure the equal and non-
discriminatory treatment of traffic in the provision of internet access services. The Regulation (EU) 2015/2120
directly applies in Germany where the FNA is responsible for enforcing these rules.
Privacy of Telecommunications – Data Protection and Public Safety

Each provider of telecommunications services is obligated to maintain telecommunications privacy. This means
that the content and detailed circumstances of telecommunications, in particular, the fact whether or not a person
is or was engaged in a telecommunications activity must not be disclosed to third parties.

In addition, each operator is obligated to protect the personal data of telecommunications subscribers and users
in connection with the collection and use of such data.

Furthermore, any person offering publicly available phone services for domestic calls is obligated to provide all
users with free access to emergency services usually by either using the European-wide emergency call number
"112", or national emergency call numbers (such as "110" in Germany), by sending the corresponding emergen-
cy signals. National emergency call numbers and the extent of the emergency services obligations may vary in
different countries.

Moreover, each provider of telecommunications services is obligated to make appropriate technical arrange-
ments and other measures in order to protect the privacy of telecommunications and personal data. In addition,
providers of either public telecommunications networks or of publicly available telecommunications services
must make appropriate technical arrangements and other measures (i) to protect their telecommunications and
data processing systems against disruptions, which would result in considerable harm to telecommunications
networks and services, and (ii) to control potential risks for the security of telecommunications networks and
services. In addition, each provider is obligated to nominate a security commissioner (Sicherheitsbeauftragten)
and to draw up a security concept (Sicherheitskonzept) setting out (a) which public telecommunications networks
are operated and which publicly available telecommunications services are provided, (b) any potential hazards,
and (c) which technical arrangements or other safeguards have been made or put in place or are planned.

Providers of publicly available telecommunications services are obligated to notify violations of the protection of
personal data to the FNA, the Federal Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information (Bun-
desbeauftragter für den Datenschutz und die Informationsfreiheit) and, in certain circumstances, the individuals
affected by the violation.

In 2010, the Federal Constitutional Court of Germany (Bundesverfassungsgericht) declared the then applicable
data retention obligations to be unconstitutional and the Court of Justice of the European Union ("CJEU") an-
nulled the corresponding European Directive 2006/24/EC. Following this ruling, the new law on the implemen-
tation of the data retention obligation, came into force which obliges providers of publicly available telecommu-
nications services to save traffic data of their customers after 1 July 2017. Several claims have been filed against
these provisions. Following these claims the Higher Administrative Court of North Rhine-Westphalia (Oberver-
waltungsgericht Nordrhein-Westfalen) decided in a preliminary ruling on 22 June 2017 (file number 13 B
238/17) that the new German data retention regulation infringes European law. Subsequently, the FNA declared
to refrain from orders and other measures to enforce the storage obligations until a ruling in the principal pro-
ceedings (Hauptsacheverfahren) which are still pending.

Against this background, we are currently not obliged and do not save traffic data of our customers.
Irrespective of this specific data protection issue, we store and use data in the ordinary course of our operating
business. Such data is protected by data protection laws, which will change substantially with effect of May 2018
when the new General Data Protection Regulation ("GDPR") (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) will become enforce-
able. The GDPR harmonises the data protection regulations throughout the EU and implements a stricter data
protection compliance regime. It also substantially increases the fines for a breach of data protection law. Ger-

man data protection agencies have the right to audit us and impose orders and fines if they find that we have not
complied with applicable laws and adequately protected customer data.

When performing our services, we may need to transfer personal data to entities located outside of the EEA (e.g.
to service providers based in the USA). According to the applicable data protection regulations, transfers to third
countries are subject to additional requirements, such as adequacy decisions of the European Commission, ap-
propriate contractual safeguards (e.g. EU standard clauses or binding corporate rules) or other approved mecha-
nisms. Compliance with these requirements can also be monitored by data protection agencies who may impose
orders and fines if they find that we have not complied with these additional requirements.
Interception and Information Requests from Law Enforcement Authorities

Each operator of a telecommunications system on which publicly available telecommunications services are
provided must provide, at its own expense, technical facilities for telecommunications interception by law en-
forcement authorities. The administrative and procedural details of the telecommunications interception are spec-
ified    in     the    revised     telecommunications       interception     regulation   (Telekommunikations-
Überwachungsverordnung), whereas the technical details (for example, relating to transmission protocols) are
specified in the relevant technical guidelines relating to the telecommunications interception regulation. The
FNA regularly updates the technical guidelines in order to reflect developments in technology, such as the use of
e-mail and VoIP, for example.

For each interception measure ordered by the competent authorities, the operator of the telecommunications
system receives a monetary compensation. The amount and the provision for such compensation are stipulated in
the German Law on Payment and Compensation by Judiciary Authorities (Justizvergütungs- und
-entschädigungsgesetz).

In order to comply with statutory provisions related to law enforcement, each operator of a telecommunications
network or provider of telecommunications services used to be obligated to collect and store certain data for a
certain period of time with regard to the telecommunications traffic across its network (Vorratsdatenspeicher-
ung). Due to the decision by the Higher Administrative Court of North Rhine-Westphalia of 22 June 2017 (see
"—12.8 Privacy of Telecommunications—Data Protection and Public Safety") there is currently no obligation to
store such traffic data.
12.10   International Roaming

In November 2015, a new EU roaming regulation came into force which abolished retail roaming surcharges.
With effect from 15 June 2017, roaming providers are not allowed to levy any surcharge in addition to the do-
mestic retail price on roaming customers in any Member State for any regulated roaming calls made or received,
for any regulated roaming SMS message sent and for any regulated data roaming service used, including MMS
messages, nor any general charge to enable the terminal equipment or service to be used abroad (so called "roam
like at home" rule).

Only in specific cases, beyond a reasonably high volume of roaming data at domestic price, users may have to
pay a data roaming surcharge which will be equal to the wholesale (EU-wide) data cap (EUR 7.70 / GB of data
in 2017 plus VAT). This wholesale roaming price is the maximum the domestic operator has to pay a foreign
operator when an end-user utilises data roaming services.
12.11   Antitrust Regulation and Competition Law

We are subject to the general antitrust regulations of the EU and Germany on the prohibition of the abuse of a
market dominant position as well as the distortion of competition through agreements or collusive behaviour by
market participants.

Under Articles 101 and 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the implementing Eu-
ropean regulations as well as under the provisions of the German Act against Restraints of Competition (Gesetz
gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen), if the Federal Cartel Office ("FCO", Bundeskartellamt) or the European
Commission determines that a company has a dominant position in a market or distorts competition through
agreements or collusive behaviour, they are entitled to prohibit such practices and to impose various measures,
including fines or disgorgement of projects generated by such behaviour. The European Commission enforces
these rules in cooperation with the national competition authorities (i.e., the FCO in Germany). The FCO may
also directly enforce such rules. In addition, the national courts have jurisdiction over alleged violations of the
EU competition law. Moreover, third parties may initiate civil proceedings against companies that wilfully or

negligently violate provisions of the German Act against Restraints of Competition to obtain compensation for
damages suffered, provided that these provisions were intended to protect the interests of such third parties.

The European Merger Regulation (Regulation (EC) No 139/2004) requires that all mergers, acquisitions and
joint ventures involving participants meeting a certain turnover threshold be submitted to the EU Commission
for review, rather than to national authorities, i.e., the FCO in Germany. Concentrations are prohibited if they
pose the risk of creating or strengthening a dominant position on a relevant market.
12.12   Commercial Law

Pursuant to Section 89b of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch), which implemented into Ger-
man law the Council Directive 86/653/EEC on the coordination of the laws of the Member States relating to self-
employed commercial agents, a commercial agent is entitled to a compensation after the agency agreement has
terminated, if (i) the commercial agent brought new customers for the principal's business, or so significantly
increased the volume of business with already existing customers that it is economically equivalent to the acqui-
sition of a new customer and the principal continues to derive substantial benefits, even after termination of the
agency agreement, from such business relations and (ii) the payment of the compensation is equitable having
regard to all the circumstances and, in particular, the commission lost by the commercial agent on the business
transacted with such customers.

The compensation shall amount to not more than one year's commission or other annual remuneration calculated
on the basis of the commercial agent's average earnings for his activities over the preceding five years; if the
agency contract goes back less than five years, the average for the period of activity shall be determinative. The
claim for compensation must be asserted within one year after termination of the agency agreement.

However, the commercial agent is not entitled to a compensation if (i) the commercial agent has terminated the
agency contract, unless the conduct of the principal gave justified grounds for doing so, or the commercial agent
cannot reasonably be expected to continue his activities on account of his age or of illness, (ii) the principal has
terminated the agency contract and there was a compelling reason for such termination owing to culpable con-
duct on part of the commercial agent or (iii) a third party enters into the agency contract in place of the commer-
cial agent on the basis of an agreement between the principal and the commercial agent.

Section 89b of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch) may apply analogously in case of termina-
tion of certain distributor agreements or franchise agreements. The right to claim compensation cannot be
waived in advance.
12.13   Other Regulation

Apart from these specific telecommunications regulations related obligations there are various other regulatory
provisions we have to comply with. In particular, as besides our telecommunications services we sell user devic-
es, such as digital enhanced cordless telecommunications ("DECT") phones, conference phones and accessories
(for example, keypad expansions and headsets) and DECT servers, we are subject to product liability and safety
and other product compliance regulations.
13.BUSINESS
13.1   Overview

We are the only true pan-European cloud PBX provider with a market-leading position in Germany in terms of
number of multi-tenant cloud PBX seats (Source: MZA). As at 31 March 2018, we provided our services to
more than 15 thousand business customers (including end customers of our wholesale partners) with more than
250 thousand seats. Our flagship service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, is a public multi-tenant PBX
delivering its services from the cloud. As such, it is designed to enable convenient and effective location-
independent communication for our customers and their employees, all the time, on multiple devices, including
smartphones, tablets, personal computers ("PCs") and desk phones.

Traditionally, businesses have exclusively used on-premise PBX. These systems generally require expensive
hardware that must be deployed at every business location of the customer and are primarily designed for em-
ployees working only at that location and using only their desk phones. In addition, these systems generally
require significant upfront investment and ongoing maintenance and support costs. In contrast, public multi-
tenant PBX, such as the NFON Cloud Telephone System, are easy to deploy, have increased functionality, are
highly flexible and scalable and are updated automatically. Normally, public multi-tenant PBX also provide for
lower total costs of ownership than on-premise and other off-premise PBX. The market development is expected
to be clearly in favour of Hosted/Cloud PBX: While as at 31 December 2017, just over 10 % of all PBX systems
deployed in the European PBX Market were estimated to be Hosted/Cloud PBX, this portion is expected to in-
crease to more than 25 % by the end of 2022. (Source: MZA).

Over the last ten years we have developed a highly reliable, enterprise grade cloud service platform that is hori-
zontally scalable, meaning that we can quickly and cost-effectively expand the capacity of our infrastructure and
delivery platform by connecting additional hardware or software components and that relies almost exclusively
on infrastructure operated in Germany and complying with the strict European data privacy requirements. To
ensure short reaction times and high quality in both development and services, almost all of our solutions and
processes were developed in-house and are operated by ourselves. The NFON Cloud Telephone System is highly
reliable and provides for more than 150 core features that are constantly updated at no additional cost to our
customers. It can be used for up to several thousand seats per customer. Due to our self-developed zero-touch
provisioning process, the deployment of the NFON Cloud Telephone System is easy and intuitive. When used
with a mobile device it uses GSM/UMTS voice technology to transport the call in case of insufficient data con-
nectivity while still offering most PBX features.

We offer the NFON Cloud Telephone System to companies of all sizes. Our customer base ranges from small
office/home office customers ("SoHos") to large businesses. We address them with a multi-channel distribution
strategy. Besides our direct distribution, we have a network of more than 1,100 (as at 31 March 2018) dedicated
distributors and dealers. In addition, our wholesale partners, such as Deutsche Telekom (including its subsidiary
T-Systems), Chess Communication, Telefónica Germany and Sunrise, distribute our cloud telephone system on a
white label and co-branded basis to their customers.

With offices in Berlin, Greven, Madrid, Mainz, Munich, St. Pölten and Uxbridge, we are active in 13 European
markets, including Austria, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom. In
2017, we generated 72 % of our revenue in our IFRS segment Germany, 14 % in our IFRS segment United
Kingdom and 12 % in our IFRS segment Austria (including Eastern Europe), before reconciliation. With our
core service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, tailored to the needs of European customers, we intend to
leverage on our proven market entry strategy to enter additional European markets with a particular focus on
France, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg and expand our business in the Netherlands.

We have experienced significant growth in recent periods, with total revenue of EUR 20,951 thousand,
EUR 30,388 thousand (including an extraordinary effect of non-recurring service revenue of EUR 1,500 thou-
sand generated in connection with setting up a wholesale partnership) and EUR 35,654 thousand in the financial
years 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively, representing year-over-year increases of 45.04 % and 17.33 %, respec-
tively, and were awarded the Frost & Sullivan Growth Excellence Leadership Award 2017 for Hosted IP Te-
lephony and UCaaS Industry in Europe.
13.2   Competitive Strengths

We believe that the following strengths have been the primary drivers of our success to date and, coupled with
our planned strategy, will continue to distinguish us from our competitors in the future:
Large addressable market for business communication shifting towards cloud PBX

As at 31 December 2017, the estimated number of all PBX seats 3 in the European PBX Market amounted to
134.7 million. (Source: MZA). Traditionally, PBX systems were based on on-premise hardware which is expen-
sive to buy, install, maintain and extend. On-premise PBX systems provide for little flexibility, as they are bound
to a specific site and infrastructure and the possibility to integrate additional communication services, such as
video conferencing or the use of mobile phones, is limited. While as at 31 December 2017, only more than 10 %
of all PBX systems deployed in the European PBX Market were estimated to be Hosted/Cloud PBX, this portion
is expected to increase to more than 25 % by the end of 2022. (Source: MZA). We believe that this trend will be
intensified by the fact that many incumbent network carriers, such as Deutsche Telekom or Swisscom, are ex-
pected to stop offering their customers ISDN services and switch to an All-IP networks. This will make it neces-
sary for all customers currently using a PBX that is not VoIP capable to either make their PBX VoIP capable,
e.g. through a SIP trunk, or replace their existing on-premise PBX with a cloud PBX. We believe that many of
these customers will decide to subscribe for cloud PBX services. In addition, the European markets also offers
interesting growth opportunities for UCaaS providers, such as high growth rates in central and eastern European
countries due to relatively limited UCaaS penetration and high demand for flexible and economical communica-
tions solutions. (Source: Frost & Sullivan)

As the only true pan-European cloud PBX provider increasingly integrating UCaaS solutions, we believe that we
are ideally placed to capitalise on the market momentum towards cloud PBX and UCaaS.
The only true pan-European cloud PBX provider with a market leading position in Germany

Unlike US-based cloud PBX providers that are mainly present in the US and the United Kingdom, we currently
market our services to business customers in 13 European countries (i.e. Austria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Ger-
many, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Spain, Switzerland and the United King-
dom). We have built this footprint on the back of a strong position in our German home market. Based on the
total number of seats with public multi-tenant PBX in the German market estimated by MZA for 31 December
2017 (Source: MZA) we estimate that our market share measured by number of seats as at 31 December 2017
was above 25 %. Within our geographic footprint, we already have experience in overcoming existing market
entry barriers, such as the different regulatory requirements and consumer preferences in the fragmented Europe-
an markets. In addition, we have established our own distribution organisations in Austria, Spain and the United
Kingdom and have long-standing channel partnerships in the Netherlands and Switzerland and a dealer network
in Poland. This puts us in a position to benefit from an increase in demand for cloud PBX services in these Euro-
pean markets. For example, the revenue (before reconciliation) from our IFRS segment United Kingdom in-
creased from EUR 1.0 million in 2015 to EUR 3.3 million in 2016 and EUR 4.9 million in 2017 and the revenue
(before reconciliation) from our IFRS segment Austria (also including revenue generated in Eastern Europe)
increased from EUR 2.7 million in 2015 to EUR 3.3 million in 2016 and EUR 4.1 million in 2017.
Highly attractive combination of high revenue growth rates and very stable recurring revenue

We have a history of strong top line revenue growth. From financial years 2015 to 2017, our customer base in-
creased at a compound annual growth rate ("CAGR") of 37 % and our total revenue increased at a CAGR of
30 %.The majority of our revenue is comprised of monthly payments of a fixed license fee per seat and an addi-
tional fixed or volume based fee for voice telephony usage which leads to a significant level of predictable recur-
ring revenue. During each of the financial years 2015, 2016 and 2017, the number of seats lost during the year
was smaller than the number of seats gained during the year from customers that were already customers at the
beginning of the year. This is, in part, the result of a comparatively low Gross Churn Rate. In the financial years
2015, 2016 and 2017 our average monthly Gross Churn Rate was only 0.3 %, 0.4 % and 0.4 %, respectively. We
believe that the outstanding quality and reliability of our services in a business communication environment with
almost no tolerance for quality issues and service interruptions and our transparent and flexible subscription
agreements contribute to the high "stickiness" of our customers and their willingness to subscribe for additional
seats. Marketing optional features and premium solutions also increases the recurring revenue that we generate
with our existing customer base, increases customer satisfaction and reduces churn. This helps us to provide a
high level of stability and predictability to the revenue generated from our existing customer base.
State-of-the-art "German Engineering" enterprise grade cloud PBX tailored to European customer needs

Our core service, the NFON Cloud Telephone System, is tailored to the needs of European customers and the
underlying infrastructure and delivery platform is located in Germany. We cater for these concerns with our

delivery platform based on server infrastructure located in two highly redundant data centres in Germany. In

services, almost all of our features and processes were developed in-house and are operated by ourselves. This
way, we can guarantee to our customers that our NFON Cloud Telephone System will be available at 99.9 % of
the time on an annual basis. In addition, the voice quality of the NFON Cloud Telephone System is certified by
TÜV Saarland. Our NFON Cloud Telephone System also provides a full range of PBX features that are im-
portant in the European market, such as allowing for direct inward dialling and the support of devices commonly
used in Europe. Importantly, the scope and delivery of our services complies with the very stringent regulatory
requirements and data protection laws of the European markets in which we are active. We believe that many of
our competitors or potential competitors would have to spend significant time and make cost-consuming changes
to their cloud PBX services and their delivery platform in order to be able to compete with us in the markets in
which we are active.
Outstanding track record in scalable growth underpinned by positive Adjusted EBITDA

As we deliver our services from the cloud, we can scale our services by expanding the capacity of our infrastruc-
ture and delivery platform. Such capacity expansion can generally be effected quickly and at little extra cost. As
a result, the costs per seat of providing the NFON Cloud Telephone System services become smaller, the higher
the number of seats served. Although our main strategic focus was and is on revenue growth rather than on in-
creasing profitability, our scalability profile has contributed to our positive Adjusted EBITDA of EUR 173 thou-
sand in financial year 2017, respectively. The effects of our scalability profile are demonstrated by our most
mature operations in Germany which recorded an EBITDA margin (before reconciliation) of 25.12 % in 2017.

The sustainability of our growth is also underpinned by the high portion of recurring revenue in our total reve-
nue, our high Gross Profit Margin of total revenue, our comparatively low Gross Churn Rate and our relatively
stable ARPU.
13.3   Strategy

Our vision is to deliver freedom of communication. To simplify communication for companies across Europe
and to offer intuitive communication solutions for businesses is our main mission.
Following this vision, we intend to pursue the following strategic goals:
Expand regionally throughout Europe

Due to the high "stickiness" of business communication solutions, we believe that it is critical for our future
success that we increase our customer base by accelerating our international expansion. We are currently active
in 13 European countries (i.e. Austria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland,
Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom). With our core service, the NFON
Cloud Telephone System, tailored to the needs of European customers, we intend to leverage on our proven
flexible go-to-market model to enter additional European markets with a particular focus on France, Italy, Bel-
gium and Luxembourg and expand our business in the Netherlands. We intend to enter new markets either
through partnerships with local distributors, dealers and/or wholesale partners or by opening our own local pres-
ence, as we did, for example, in Spain and the United Kingdom. We believe that, although setting up our own
local presence involves more up-front investment than entering a market solely through indirect distribution
channels, it puts us in a better position to capitalise on market opportunities. We therefore aim to initially estab-
lish our own presence in larger markets where we believe there is a strong potential for cloud PBX and to there-
after continuously build a channel partner network around this presence.

Roll-out innovative UCaaS features to attract additional customers, increase ARPU and add value to the core
product

We are currently working on a new version of the end-user client which we intend to release in the second half
of 2018. As a next development step, we intend to supplement the new client with additional UCaaS solutions
such as video conferencing and collaboration features such as screen sharing or chat functions. We believe that
the integration of additional UCaaS solutions is a necessary step to meet the need for more comprehensive com-
munication solutions in a quickly changing work environment. We believe that additional UCaaS solutions
would add value to our core services, make our service offering more attractive for potential customers, and
allow us to increase the revenue we generate from our existing customer base.

Most of our premium solutions, such as our contact centre or voice recording solutions, are sourced from third
parties. We intend to continue integrating additional third party solutions after a diligent "make or buy" assess-
ment, as this allows us to enhance the attractiveness of our service offering by choosing a proven and accepted
solution and avoids the costs and risk of failure involved with developing such a solution in-house.
Further develop open APIs to allow broad access to third party solutions

We intend to continue to develop interfaces for enabling third parties to integrate the NFON Cloud Telephone
System into their service solution and market the combined service. These open interfaces would also allow us to
offer the NFON Cloud Telephone System in a so-called "Communication Platform-as-a-Service" business mod-
el.
Expand customer base and increase penetration of customers in our existing markets

Due to the high "stickiness" of business communication solutions, we believe that it is critical for our future
success that we strongly expand our customer base. To this end, we intend to significantly invest into brand
marketing in order to be perceived as a leader in the cloud PBX market as well as to invest in various other mar-
keting measures, including digital performance marketing measures, in particular, programmatic and search
engine advertising. In addition, we intend to make significant investments into our channel partner network to
further expand our distribution reach. We believe that the long-term benefits of growing our customer base
through such measures will outweigh the detrimental short-term effect they have on our profitability.

We also intend to increase the penetration of our existing customer base by selling them additional seats, option-
al features and premium solutions which is also commercially attractive, as the acquisition costs are comparably
low. We believe that the planned roll-out of additional UCaaS features and premium solutions will help us to
achieve this aim.
Capitalise on the opportunities in highly fragmented European cloud PBX markets

The European cloud PBX market is highly fragmented (Source "MZA"). We intend to play an active role in the
consolidation of this market not only by pursuing organic growth, but also by selectively acquiring competitors
in the cloud PBX area should attractive opportunities arise in order to increase our customer base and benefit
from scale effects. We regularly screen the market for such opportunities. In addition, we would also consider
acquiring companies with technologies and solutions that we deem an attractive supplement to our existing ser-
vice offering.
13.4   History of the Group

NFON was founded in March 2007. We launched the first version of the NFON Cloud Telephone System at the
beginning of 2009 in our home market Germany. Also in 2009, we started to address the Austrian market by
entering into a sales and technology joint venture with a potential competitor. In 2013, we entered the UK mar-
ket, incorporated our UK-based subsidiary on 30 April 2013 and opened an office near London. In 2014, we
intensified the indirect distribution of our services through a distribution network of distributors and dealers and
further intensified this approach by entering into wholesale partnerships with Telefónica Germany in 2014 and
Deutsche Telekom in 2016.

Mid 2015, we founded a sales entity in Madrid, Spain, in order to better serve the Spanish market. In 2016, we
expanded our service offering by integrating additional attractive premium solutions such as our contact centre
solution Ncontactcenter and our call recording solution Neorecording. In November 2017, we acquired the out-
standing 49.8 % of shares in our Austrian subsidiary nfon GmbH, St. Pölten, from our former joint venture part-
ner.
13.5   NFON Offering
NFON Business Model

Our business model centres around our NFON Cloud Telephone System. The NFON Cloud Telephone System is
a public multi-tenant PBX (see "11. Industry—11.1 Technical Background—11.1.1 Technical Background of a
PBX"). This means that it does not require on-premise hardware, but is provided as a service from the cloud (i.e.
from our shared servers that are situated in two geo-redundant data centres in Germany). As a cloud-based ser-
vice to which the customer connects through the Internet, the NFON Cloud Telephone System can be used
across all customer and other (e.g. home office) locations without the need to deploy server hardware at any such
location. Accordingly, it can be installed and maintained without the on-site support required for an on-premise
PBX. While expansion, update or modification of an on-premise PBX might require complicated changes to the
on-premise hardware or the deployment of additional hardware at a customer site, our NFON Cloud Telephone
System can be expanded, updated or modified at the level of the cloud without significant involvement of the
customer.

Certain of the features of the NFON Cloud Telephone System are available on an optional basis. These features
include for example our encryption feature, our softphone feature Nsoftphone or our voice recording feature ad-
hoc recording.

We also market add-on premium solutions, such as contact centre and voice recording solutions that are integrat-
ed into our NFON Cloud Telephone System.

We follow a full-service approach meaning that if required, we also provide our customers with service support,
a variety of compatible hardware devices and accessories and, exclusively in Germany, a high-speed Internet
access. Most of the first level service support is conducted by our dealers and wholesale partners.

We currently market our services to business customers of all sizes in 13 European countries (i.e. Austria, Croa-
tia, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Spain, Switzer-
land and the United Kingdom) with the largest portion of our revenue being generated in Austria, Germany and
the United Kingdom.

We generate recurring and non-recurring revenue with our service and product offering. In the financial year
2017 78 % (2016: 75 %4, 2015: 73 %) of our total revenue were recurring revenue. In general, we charge for our
NFON Cloud Telephone System services on a monthly basis. Our customers pay a monthly license fee per seat
for the usage of the NFON Cloud Telephone System. The amount of the monthly license fee depends on the type
and number of available optional features and premium solutions and the maximum number of devices that can
be used per seat. For example, our business tariff already includes three devices per seat, and a number of op-
tional features such as, inter alia, our softphone feature Nsoftphone and our Nvoice Mobile for the integration of
mobile devices. The license fee also varies slightly from market to market. All our tariffs across segments and
regions offer customers the advantage that all platform, maintenance and feature upgrades are included in the
monthly licence fee and updates are available automatically for every user once released, without the need for
additional on-site service. Except for the NFON Cloud Telephone System services distributed to wholesale part-
ners without airtime (see "—13.8 Distribution, Marketing and Customer Care—13.8.1 Distribution"), customers
also pay us for voice telephony usage either on a per minute-based charging model or on the basis of a flat rate.
This includes traffic into the PSTN and is also billed on a monthly basis.

Should the customer require communication devices and accessories to be delivered with the NFON Cloud Tele-
phone System, we source these from certain suppliers and on-sell them to our customers against a one-time
payment of the respective purchase price. We also obtain non-recurring revenue from professional services, if
any, provided in connection with the installation of the NFON Cloud Telephone System, general activation fees
and activation fees for porting or allocating telephone numbers, one-time set-up fees for our Internet service
Nconnect and professional services provided in connection with the implementation of premium solutions.
NFON Cloud Telephone System

The NFON Cloud Telephone System provides for a self-developed zero-touch auto provisioning solution, mean-
ing that the customers' telephone devices do not need any preconfiguration and can simply be unboxed and
plugged in. Our NFON Cloud Telephone System is designed in a way so that most installations do not need
specific changes to the customer's firewall system and configuration of the devices is not only done automatical-
ly but also in a secure fashion through encryption of data streams between telephone and provisioning system. It
is therefore very easy to install, operate and expand. The NFON Cloud Telephone System is location, device and
network provider independent, meaning that its services can be used at any time, from any place and with vari-
ous types of devices for up to several thousand seats. If needed, and provided that we have sufficient ramp-up
time of approximately six months, we can cater for more than 100,000 seats per customer.

The NFON Cloud Telephone System comprises more than 150 intelligent features that are constantly updated at
no cost for our customers. Our operational set-up based on our own server infrastructure (see "— 13.10 Tech-
nical Platform and Operating Infrastructure") enables us to deliver services with a very high grade of service
availability. We guarantee our customers an annual availability of our NFON Cloud Telephone System of
99.9 %. The voice quality of the NFON Cloud Telephone System is certified by TÜV Saarland.
Core Features

Our NFON Cloud Telephone System comprises a number of core features, such as, for example, click-to-dial,
conference rooms, automatic call distribution ("ACD") and time-controlled call routing, that are available to all
our customers irrespective of individual specifications. The NFON Cloud Telephone System includes PSTN

termination services in more than 50 countries. For all 13 countries in which we currently market our services,
we can assign new telephone numbers to our customers and port existing telephone numbers of our customers.
For other countries, we can assign new telephone numbers to customers via various network carriers.

The management of the NFON Cloud Telephone System is performed entirely via web-based administration
tools that are designed for end-user and administrator self-care without additional external service need. They
include an administration portal through which the customer's administrator controls the NFON Cloud Tele-
phone System by, for example, defining seats, adding devices, or installing interactive voice response systems
and conference rooms. We train our distributors and dealers on our services and provide our customers with
training materials on the administration of the NFON Cloud Telephone System, for example, in the form of
YouTube tutorials. Our web-based end-user client, Ncontrol, allows access to telephone configuration, call for-
warding, eFax, voicemail, click-to-dial, conference calls and call history. Additional web-based portals provide
access to call data records and contract information.
Click-to-dial

The NFON Cloud Telephone System includes a click-to-dial feature which allows users to start outbound calls
via their desktop computer. In addition, it makes the use of any (even a non-NFON) phone with the NFON
Cloud Telephone System possible. This means that even if customers use, for example, their home phone or a
hotel phone line they can still signal the office number for all outgoing calls (so-called "one number concept"). If
the user initiates a call, the NFON Cloud Telephone System will call the respective telephone device and once
the user answers that call the NFON Cloud Telephone System will create and connect the desired outbound call
using the user's business number.
Conference Rooms

By using the conference room function, which is integrated into the NFON Cloud Telephone System at no extra
cost, our customers can organise conference calls through establishing virtual conference rooms. Each such con-
ference room has its own access number and code. It allows users to conduct conference calls at any time and to
invite up to 50 external and internal participants.
Automatic Call Distribution

The ACD feature allows calls to be placed on hold without handling the actual enquiries or transferring callers to
the desired party. While in the call queue, the caller is played pre-recorded music or messages. Call queues are
often used in call centres where a large number of calls need to be handled.

When using our skill-based call routing feature, the customer's administrator defines skills, for example a sales
or support function of the employee or English or German language skills, and assigns them to respective agents.
As a result, calls from German speaking callers who need support, will be, for example, primarily automatically
directed to seats of end-users with a support function and German language capabilities.

The ACD feature further offers the interactive voice response ("IVR") which enables the automatised interaction
of a PBX with callers via a telephone keypad, after which services can be inquired about through the IVR dia-
logue.
Time-Controlled Call Routing

Our time-controlled call routing feature transfers incoming calls to the correct employee or the appropriate target
depending on the day and exact time of the call. For example, incoming calls can be routed to a group of users
during business hours and to an announcement or a mailbox during the remaining time. Various routine routing
operations are conducted, depending on the time and weekday, in order to connect the caller with the correct
destination. Simple tools allow the customer's administrator to programme the call routing of the NFON Tele-
phone System himself.

Additionally to the ACD and skill-based or time-controlled call routing features, we offer our customers Ncon-
tactcenter, a fully-fledged premium contact centre solution (see "—13.5.3 Premium Solutions").
Optional Features

Certain features of the NFON Cloud Telephone System are available on an optional basis. Usually, customers
pay for optional features through an increased monthly subscription fee per additional module. However, we also
offer tariffs where the use of some of our optional features is included in the monthly subscription fee.
Nvoice Mobile

Nvoice Mobile
With the Nvoice Mobile customers can integrate mobile phones operating on Android and iOS systems into the
NFON Cloud Telephone System. The Nvoice Mobile is a true fixed mobile convergence ("FMC") solution and
as such enables a smartphone to act like a fully featured seat of the NFON Cloud Telephone System. If data

connectivity is sufficient (e.g. WLAN, LTE/4G), the Nvoice Mobile uses VoIP technology. If the end-user
chooses so or if data connectivity is not sufficient, the Nvoice Mobile will use classic GSM/UMTS voice tech-
nology to transport the call while still offering most features. This is a major differentiator to competitors relying
on VoIP and data connectivity only and allows our solution to also be used basically in all situations where only
classic GSM-based telephony is available.

The Nvoice Mobile allows for a cost free connection to the NFON Cloud Telephone System, if data connectivity
is available. Mobile phones can be reached via the office number and are able to signal the office number for all
outgoing calls (the so-called one number concept). This way, business use can clearly be distinguished from
private use supporting a "bring your own device" policy. Additional features, like the ability to voice record a
call or to push or pull a call to or from another seat are also available.
Nsoftphone

Customers can also make voice calls with their computer or laptop using Nsoftphone, a softphone option inte-
grated in the NFON Cloud Telephone System. All the user needs to make a call after installing the softphone
software is a microphone or a headset. This way, users can make calls completely location-independent and still
use all of the functions and features of a desktop phone connected to a PBX system.
Encryption

We optionally offer customers VoIP signalling and media stream encryption. With VoIP telephony, voice infor-
mation is transmitted in data form, so that it can be encrypted. During the encryption process the VoIP signalling
and media stream are encrypted while being transmitted from the customer telephone to the data centre, where
the NFON Cloud Telephone System is operated, and vice versa. To set up the encryption process, customer's
telephones are registered with the assigned encryption gateway operated on the NFON servers in the data centres
which have multiple layers of security. In the course of setting up the secured call, keys that are specifically
created for every call are exchanged (via session description protocol security descriptions, "SDES") to later
encrypt the media streams (via secure real-time transport protocol, "SRTP" and symmetric encryption algo-
rithms). If supported by a customer's telephone, the phone display indicates when calls are encrypted. Connec-
tions between the NFON data centres and the PSTN cannot be encrypted for systematic reasons.
Fax

Whilst it was previously necessary to send copies of documents using a fax machine, today it is possible to fully
integrate a fax function into the computer. With the NFON Cloud Telephone System, each employee can be
assigned his or her own fax number. NFON offers an easy to use eFax service allowing the sending and receiv-
ing of faxes in a PDF format. It allows for the integration into many on-premise fax services with Session Initia-
tion Protocol ("SIP") trunks offering the T.38 fax protocol which greatly enhances the probability of successful
fax transmissions over VoIP lines. The T.38 fax protocol is a standard for fax over IP based on the conversion of
digital information into acoustic information.
Nrecording

The Nrecording-basic option is customisable for each seat. It records calls as needed and sends recordings in an
mp3 or wav format via email. Additional features like storing, organising and searching are only available with
our call recording premium solution Neorecording (see "—13.5.3 Premium Solutions").
Nmonitoring Queues

Our call centre monitoring feature, NFON Nmonitoring Queues, serves to facilitate the optimisation of working
processes and to enhance efficiency. It allows customers to monitor incoming calls to a specified queue in a
customer's NFON Cloud Telephone System enabling more efficient configuration of working processes. The
data, which is gathered by the NFON Cloud Telephone System can be used for a real-time analysis of queues or
to prepare statistical reports. Call centre operators generally receive information about the number of callers in
the queue and the waiting time. This allows them to respond flexibly to peak demand by deploying extra call
centre staff.
Computer Telephony Integration

Computer Telephony Integration ("CTI") provides for a connection between a computer and the NFON Cloud
Telephone System and enables desktop-based interaction with the PBX such as the workflow integration of the
PBX into Outlook or a customer's relationship management system ("CRM") to help the user to be more effi-
cient. Through this integration with Outlook or other programmes the user can manage his entire office commu-
nications and control all incoming and outgoing phone calls from his PC or laptop.
Premium Solutions

In addition to our core and optional cloud telephony features, we offer a range of add-on premium solutions
which typically require a specific configuration to the individual customer's requirements and comprehensive
implementation. This allows us to capitalise on attractive business opportunities in these areas and is an im-
portant element of our strategy of adding value to our core product, NFON Cloud Telephone System. We started
the integration of premium solutions into our service offering in 2015 with Nhospitality and Nvoice for Skype
for Business but commenced doing so on a larger scale in December 2016 with the introduction of Neorecording
and Ncontactcenter, our premium call recording and contact centre solutions. Accordingly, revenue generated
with the sale of our premium solutions accounts for a relatively small part of our total revenue so far. However,
we intend to increase the contribution of our premium solutions to our total revenue going forward.

Nhospitality: Hospitality Services Premium Solution

Our hospitality service premium solution, Nhospitality, seamlessly integrates the NFON Cloud Telephone Sys-
tem into property management solutions. It provides for hotel-specific features, such as multilingual wake-up
calls and guest accounting, as well as for communication features related to scheduling and administrating ser-
vice (e.g. internal communication by a room maid that a hotel room is ready for check-in).
Nvoice for Skype for Business Premium Solution

Skype for Business is a unified communications ("UC") platform operating on the basis of the Microsoft soft-
ware "Skype for Business Server" or "Skype for Business Online". It integrates common channels of business
communication and online meetings, including instant messaging ("IM"), presence, VoIP, voicemail, file trans-
fers, video conferencing, web conferencing and email. Skype for Business has the advantage of natively integrat-
ing with Microsoft address book contacts, calendar presence and other office applications - as well as more fun-
damental infrastructure services like Active Directory. However, Skype for Business primarily works over data-
based connections and does not include an enterprise grade PBX telephony solution.

We have developed an integration into Skype for Business enterprise solution providing the features of a cloud-
based PBX. With our Nvoice for Skype for Business premium solution, a Skype for Business client is trans-
formed into a functioning end-device which can be treated as any other seat within the NFON Cloud Telephone
System. This allows our customers to be included in all of the traditional telephony features without requiring
complex changes to the Skype for Business solution. Another advantage is the individual licensing of the system.
Only the users requiring Skype for Business need a respective license, whilst the rest of the organisation can
simply use our standard NFON Cloud Telephone System. This hybrid model allows both sets of users to benefit
from our full range of telephone functions as well as to communicate with each other and to be reached from the
PSTN.

In addition to offering the possibility to integrate the NFON Cloud Telephone System into existing Skype for
Business installations, we also subscribe for the Skype for Business licensed cloud services from a respective
server platform of Deutsche Telekom. We combine these services with our cloud telephone system components
and market the resulting Nvoice for Skype for Business solution under our own brand to our customers.
Neorecording: Call Recording Premium Solution

Our call recording solution, Neorecording, integrates the call recording solution from ASC Technologies AG
("ASC Technologies") into our NFON Cloud Telephone System. It allows the user to safely record and store all
calls and other customer interaction conducted over voice. Every call is captured as an audio recording, encrypt-
ed in a manipulation-proof manner, and stored in secure data centres in Germany. Neorecording offers compre-
hensive reporting functionalities, including customisable logs, statistics and agent reports, and is pre-loaded with
20 standard reports.

Since the beginning of 2018, Directive 2014/65/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May
2014 on markets in financial instruments and related legislation ("MiFID II") requires investment firms
throughout Europe to record certain telephone calls with their customers, stipulates specific requirements on the
format of the recording and specifies the term during which the recordings must be retained (five years). Neore-
cording allows investment firms of any size to comply with requirements under MiFID II.
Ncontactcenter: Contact Centre Premium Solution

Ncontactcenter is a web-oriented solution that employs browser technology for the management and display of
call centre data. The solution offers defined rules and requirements for incoming and outgoing calls, as well as
multi-channel communication. Administration, monitoring and system use by supervisors or agents are conduct-
ed using a web-based interface and can be accessed via the Internet. The solution includes the following ser-
vices:

   Automatic Call Distribution: With ACD, incoming phone calls and multimedia events (voicemail, fax,
    text messages, call-back requests and emails) can be distributed to seats and staff members (for example,
    call centre agents) based on defined rules. As a result, the caller is connected as quickly as possible with
    the best suited free staff member. The web-based interface is used for administration, as well as supervi-
    sor and agent access. An administrator can establish one or more supervisors for groups of agents. They
    are able to supervise and observe the involvements of the call centre agents, actively intervene and moni-
    tor, and assess what takes place in the call centre. Call centre agents have an overview of the call occur-
    rences in their group.
   Interactive Voice Response: IVR helps its user to efficiently handle large call volumes. It enables the
    automatised interaction of a PBX with callers via a telephone keypad as well as by speech recognition, af-
    ter which services can be inquired about through the IVR dialogue.
   Integration into backend systems: The solution provides for interfaces for the potential integration into a
    CRM or enterprise resource planning ("ERP") system.
   Agent and queue monitoring: The agent and queue monitoring feature allows for freely configurable logs,
    statistics, and agent reports.

The Ncontactcenter solution is based on "Call Center in a Box", a contact centre solution which we source from
jtel GmbH ("jtel") as a cloud based service.

The Ncontactcenter solution includes a number of optional features. A mandatory Ncontactcenter workshop
defines the implementation type of the desired features. The configuration of Ncontactcenter is conducted by us
and the solution can only be used in conjunction with a NFON Cloud Telephone System.

The minimum subscription period for Ncontactcenter is twelve months. After this period, the contract automati-
cally extends by successive one month periods unless terminated. The amount of the monthly subscription fee
depends on the type and number of optional features included.
Ndaks Eco 100: Alarming & Notification

Ndaks Eco 100 combines the NFON Cloud Telephone System with a hardware-based system sourced from a
supplier. It allows the full integration of analogue sensors and devices into the communication workflow of the
NFON Cloud Telephone System. Examples of its use include silent alarm, building technology, and plant moni-
toring or staff/code alter notifications.
Devices

We offer a large variety of desktop, DECT and conference phones and accessories (for example, keypad expan-
sions and headsets) and DECT servers to our customers. We source these devices from certain suppliers and on-
sell them to our customers. The self-developed zero-touch provisioning feature of the NFON Cloud Telephone
System is coded in a way that all supported devices automatically connect to the NFON Cloud Telephone Sys-
tem and are automatically configured and integrated as soon as the device connects to the customer's local area
network (so called "zero-touch" or "plug-and-play" installation). Customers can choose to buy the above men-
tioned devices either from us, our sales partners or from any other source. If the customer purchases a telephone
from another source, he has to identify the telephone to us in an easy process to start the automatic configuration
and integration process. Our self-developed zero-touch provisioning feature and the breadth of supported devices
provide us with a clear competitive advantage.
Nconnect

Provided that it has sufficient upload and download speed, the customer can use any existing Internet connection
to connect to the NFON Cloud Telephone System. Optionally, customers in Germany can subscribe to our Inter-
net access services (Nconnect). Nconnect is based on ADSL and VDSL. We source these services from Versatel.
Nconnect is structured to ensure optimal functionality of the NFON Cloud Telephone System (full quality of
service). If a potential customer requires an optical fibre connection, we provide tailor made project offers on
based on services sourced from Versatel.
Nconnect Voice

With the Nconnect Voice, we provide customers who use on-premise PBX with PSTN access using VoIP tech-
nology. The Nconnect Voice allows the termination and porting of PSTN numbers and is often subscribed for to
replace existing ISDN connections. SIP trunks are expected to be increasingly deployed by customers with exist-
ing, not fully depreciated on-premise PBX as transitory technology before moving on to Hosted/Cloud PBX
(Source: MZA).

Customers can connect multiple sites and numbers to our SIP trunking services via any existing Internet connec-
tion with sufficient upload and download speed. The Nconnect Voice is certified for use with a number of on-
premise PBX systems. Technically, it is also possible to connect other, non-certified PBX with the Nconnect
Voice. However, we do not accept liability for the full compatibility of the Nconnect Voice with such non-
certified PBX and do not provide cost-free support in case of incompatibility.
13.6   The new client

We are currently working on a new client which we intend to release in the second half of 2018. We intend to
offer the new client as a browser-based version, a version for use in Windows and Mac PCs and an Android and
iOS version for use in smartphones. The desktop versions of the new client are intended to integrate the func-
tions and features of Ncontrol and Nsoftphone in a modern and intuitive interface. We plan for the smartphone
version of the client to also contain the functions and features of the current Nvoice Mobile and a majority of the
functions and features of Ncontrol. We intend the new client to make use of the smartphones VoIP integration
frameworks as, for example, Apple CallKit.

frameworks as, for example, Apple CallKit.
As a next development step, we also intend to supplement the new client with additional UCaaS solutions such
