13.7   Customers

As at 31 March 2018, we provided our services to more than 15,000 business customers (including end custom-
ers of our wholesale partners) with more than 250 thousand seats. Due to the high flexibility and scalability of
our NFON Cloud Telephone System supporting one to several thousand seats without an additional ramp-up
time, we can offer our services to companies of all sizes. Our customer base ranges from small office/home of-
fice customers ("SoHos") and small and medium enterprises ("SMEs") to large customers. Currently, our cus-
tomer range is between two and several thousand seats. We have a highly diversified customer base with no
single customer (excluding wholesale partners) accounting for more than 5 % of our revenue in 2017.

Larger customers often have higher customisation requirements, making the integration of our services into their
specific IT environment more complicated, and more complex decision making processes requiring the involve-
ment of multiple departments and management levels as compared to smaller organisations. This leads to signif-
icantly longer lead times (as compared to our other customers) of approximately six to twelve months, or even
longer, and requires us to devote greater resources of sales and services personnel as well as software engineers
and other technical personnel, resulting in increased up-front costs. In contrast, sales to SoHos and SMEs can
often be conducted efficiently through our indirect distribution channels with short lead times and little involve-
ment from our side.

Our customers generally do not have fixed-term contracts with us. They usually pay a non-recurring activation
fee depending on the number of seats they want to be able to use. Moreover, they pay monthly subscription fees
for the number of activated and thus useable seats (i.e. the seats configured by the customers' administrator for
use of our services) in a specific month. The customers may increase or decrease the number of activated seats at
any time. In addition, customers may terminate their subscription, subject to a 30 days' notice period, or reduce
the scope of subscribed services at any time, without penalty or early termination charges. However, we believe
that the high quality and reliability of our services in a business communication environment with almost no
tolerance for quality issues and service interruptions and our cost transparent and flexible subscription agree-
ments nevertheless allow us to maintain a comparatively low Gross Churn Rate (monthly average in 2017:
0.4 %). We have entered into subscription agreements with fixed terms of several years with a few large custom-
ers. However, these large customers only contribute a small portion of our revenue. For the typical terms and
conditions of the subscription agreements we enter into with our customers, see "—13.15 Material Contracts—
13.15.4 Material service and sales agreements with our customers".
Distribution, Marketing and Customer Care
Distribution

Our distribution strategy follows a multi-channel approach with the aim to enlarge our distribution reach and to
address various customer target groups through different channels. We distribute our services primarily through
indirect distribution channels (i.e. our wholesale partners and our network of distributors and dealers).We have a
team of technical consultants that mainly assist our customers with the customisation and deployment of the
NFON Cloud Telephone System and premium solutions, assist in bidding processes and support our channel
partners in connection with projects, such as the implementation of our premium solutions Ncontactcenter or
Nhospitality.
Direct Distribution

We conduct direct sales mainly to large customers with their own IT departments that want to be able to install
and administrate the NFON Cloud Telephone System themselves without additional advice and service. In most
cases, we refer the sales leads that we generate to our distributors and dealers.
Indirect Distribution

To accelerate the growth of our customer base, we strategically expanded our sales efforts to indirect distribution
channels. In 2014, we intensified the indirect distribution of our services through a distribution network of
distributors and dealers and further intensified this approach by entering into wholesale partnerships with
Telefónica Germany in 2014 and Deutsche Telekom in 2016. In the meantime, we distribute the majority of our
services through indirect distribution channels, such as dealers and wholesale partners.

While we work with a large number of dealers in the Austrian, German and Polish markets, we rely on very few
dealers in other markets, such as Spain and the United Kingdom. In the Netherlands and in Switzerland, we
currently even work with only one wholesale partner.

While we usually do not grant territorial exclusivity to dealers, we have established a CRM system which helps
us to avoid competition between multiple dealers for the same target customer. Through our CRM system, a
dealer can block a target customer for other dealers for a defined period of time. If the respective dealer does not
successfully acquire the respective target customer during such time period, the target customer will be
unblocked and can be approached by other dealers.
Dealer Network

The dealers directly approach and negotiate with potential customers, but customers enter into a contractual
relationship for the subscription of our services with us. The dealers are compensated through a share in the
activation fees and the monthly fees payable by the customer per seat, for optional features and premium
solutions, if any, and the one-time revenue they generate from selling hardware devices to the end-customer
(system, DECT and conference phones and accessories), if any. The sales commission is intended to compensate
the dealers in equal parts for both, the acquisition of the customer and for customer services provided by the
dealers. When selecting dealers we aim at covering the various target customer segments and having a complete
regional coverage of our target markets. Dealers need to have sufficient personnel with technical and distribution
expertise. In addition, they are required to participate in various courses that we offer in order to train them in
our service offering. Depending on the number of the marketed PBX seats in the previous contract period, we
categorise our dealers into "Standard Partners", "Approved Partners", "Qualified Partners" or "Premium
Partners". For the typical terms and conditions of the agreements we enter into with dealers, see "—13.15
Material Contracts—13.15.1 Agreements with dealers ".
Distributors

In this distribution model, we have a contractual relationship with and pay a commission to the dealer as
described in "Dealer Network". The distributor receives an additional share in the monthly license fees payable
by the customers to us per seat and for optional features and premium solutions, if any, for managing the
respective dealers. Also in this distribution model, customers enter into a contractual relationship with us. The
distributors sell hardware devices (system, DECT and conference phones and accessories), if any, themselves
and we do not receive any revenue from such sales. For the typical terms and conditions of the agreements we
enter into with distributors, see "—13.15 Material Contracts—13.15.2 Agreements with distributors ".
Wholesale with Airtime

We also market the NFON Cloud Telephone System through wholesale partners, for example Chess
Communications, Westcoast Limited, ACMEO or Francotyp-Postalia, partly as white label services. Under these
arrangements the wholesale partners market the NFON Cloud Telephone System services to customers under
their own brand or under a co-branding of their own and our brand and enter into contractual relationships with
end-customers meaning that we do not have a contractual relationship with these end-customers. The monthly
fees payable per seat and, for optional features and premium solutions, if any, by wholesale partners tend to be
lower than the fees generated through dealers or distributors. Under wholesale with airtime agreements, we also
provide PSTN termination services and sell monthly minute charges or flat rates for telephony (so-called airtime)
to the wholesale partners.
Wholesale without Airtime

The wholesale partnerships in this category are mainly with telecommunication carriers, for example Deutsche
Telekom (including its subsidiary T-Systems), Telefónica Germany and Sunrise. The main difference between
wholesale without airtime and wholesale with airtime is that these wholesale partners operate their own PSTN
termination and, as a consequence, we do not sell minute charges or flat rates to them.
Marketing

Since inception, we have always invested in marketing activities to build a strong brand. We believe that a strong
brand makes a major difference in a competitive environment, but also helps us to gain customer loyalty and
achieve better conversion rates (i.e. the rate of targeted customers that actually subscribe for our services). We
use and periodically adjust the mix of advertising and marketing programs to promote our services. We focus on
creating high-quality marketing materials and fostering a highly professional brand presence. We have a broader
target audience than is normally the case in a business to business environment. Our marketing and advertising
measures are mainly aimed at decision makers in the IT segment as well as general decision makers and IT
administrators and specialists. To address this broad target audience we engage in both digital marketing and
traditional marketing measures.

We aim to generate sales leads through performance marketing measures such as programmatic advertising (i.e.
advertising measures that are specifically placed in the context of certain topics or specifically address persons
with a specific profile) or search engine advertising through well-known search engines, such as Google and
Bing with the aim of being placed prominently as a search result when an Internet user searches for terms such
as telephone system, cloud telephone system or PBX. In addition, we focus on the ongoing optimisation of our
digital channels, in particular, our website, with the aim of achieving a prominent position as a search engine
result also on a non-advertised basis and reaching an optimal on-page conversion rate (i.e. the rate of customers
visiting our website that actually subscribe for our services). We also market our brand and services through our
own Internet blog and our social media presence (for example, Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn).

Our traditional marketing measures comprise print campaigns in journals specialising in IT or
telecommunications and television commercials. As part of our public relations activities, we produce press
releases and send these to business publications with the aim of triggering press articles on NFON.

We also put significant efforts on distribution channel marketing which is particularly important for our
international expansion. We support our dealers and distributors in their marketing activities by providing co-
branded materials and offering our support in joint marketing activities at fairs or joint marketing campaigns
(online, flyers, mailings, and print). We also supply our dealers with sales leads that we generated and that allow
dealers to further grow their business. This directly supports the business of our channel partners and helps us to
scale our operations faster. We also create dedicated incentive programs (i.e. provide higher one-off
commissions and additional bonuses) for dealers, distributors and wholesale partners. Selectively, we also
directly financially support marketing activities of dealers and distributors.

We co-operate with freelancers and other external marketing partners to a significant extent. This external
support allows us to quickly implement marketing measures also on a large scale.
Customer Care
We provide customer support services to our customers at no cost on three support levels.

On the first level, the service support for our customers is mainly performed by our dealers and our wholesale
partners. In addition, first level service support is provided by an outsourcing partner. First level service support
is normally the first point of contact for the customer. It deals with certain simple requests such as service re-
quests or problems that can be addressed by referring the customer to a service manual and escalates more com-
plex requests or incidents to the second level support teams.

The second support level teams are the first point of contact for certain important customers and channel part-
ners. They also deal with more complex requests such as a request for a call flow analysis. If second support
level team cannot adequately address the request, the customer will be referred to the third level support.

The third support level mainly deals with more complex problems and also involves, where necessary, our Oper-
ations and R&D departments.
Suppliers

We purchase and obtain a number of products, components and services from a variety of third-party service
providers and suppliers. Maintaining a strong and trustful relationship with these service providers and suppliers
is an important aspect of our ability to successfully conduct our business.

The NFON Cloud Telephone System includes interconnections with PSTN. As we do not have our own
telecommunications network, we rely on the ability to interconnect with PSTN operators. We source PSTN
services from a number of third-party network carriers such as British Telecom for Germany, the Netherlands
and the United Kingdom, Telefónica Germany for Germany, Neotel for Austria and Colt for Austria and
Portugal, Orange/Jazztel for Spain and Sunrise for Switzerland under respective interconnection agreements. We

rely on these third-party network carriers to provide call termination and origination services, the provision and
management of telephone numbers, and local number portability for our customers.

We source Internet upstream termination services mainly from Core Backbone, GTT and noris network. We
have high speed Internet upstream connections with Deutsche Commercial Internet Exchange, a carrier and data
centre situated in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, and the London Internet Exchange and peerings (i.e.
interconnections of separate Internet networks for the purpose of exchanging data traffic) with British Telecom,
Telefónica Germany, Versatel and M-Net.
The session boarder controllers that we use are supplied by Oracle and Metaswitch.
Our Internet access services Nconnect are supplied by Versatel.

The data centres Munich and Nuremberg, in which our servers are located, are operated by noris network.
For our internal business support system, we rely on a software solution from Salesforce which we license from
Deutsche Telekom.

We also use third-party service providers to deliver certain optional features of our NFON Cloud Telephone
System and premium solutions. Our Nmonitoring Queues feature is sourced as a cloud based service from
Loway Switzerland. Our Ncontactcenter solution is based on "Call Center in a Box", a contact centre solution
which we subscribe from jtel as a cloud based service (see "—13.15 Material Contracts—13.15.7 Framework
purchase agreement with jtel"). The voice-recording solution Neorecording integrates the application of ASC
Technologies into the NFON Cloud Telephone System. The purchase framework agreement with ASC
Technologies provides for exclusivity for both parties with regard to certain compliant communications
recording services in the EEA until 31 December 2018 and has an initial minimum term until 31 December 2018
and extends automatically for consecutive twelve months, unless it is terminated with a three months' notice
period to the end of a calendar year (see "—13.15 Material Contracts—13.15.6 Framework purchase agreement
with ASC Technologie"). For our alerting platform Ndaks Eco 100 we utilise an application of tetronik GmbH.
Our Nhospitality premium solution is supplied by Eurofluxo Cloud Solutions.
Technical Platform and Operating Infrastructure
Software components

To ensure short reaction times and high quality in both development and services, almost all of our solutions and
processes were developed in-house.
Voice System

Our voice system as such is based mainly on open source software. The main benefits of using open source
software are avoiding costs for proprietary software, flexible customisation and modification options and not
being locked into using a particular system of one specific vendor. We use open source software such as Asterisk
and Freeswitch as central phone system components and OpenSIPs for highly flexible and performant SIP pro-
cessing. We have developed a dial-plan logic based on a self-developed concept. We have the complete owner-
ship of all features of the phone system and do not depend on external soft switches. The voice system is config-
ured in a way allowing almost limitless horizontal scalability.
Administration

We have developed the web-based software administration platform for the central management of the NFON
Cloud Telephone System, and Ncontrol, our seat self-care portal, ourselves. As a result, we and our customers
benefit from the fact that we can quickly modify the configurations of the system as needed. We have also de-
veloped the call data record ("CDR") portal and the zero-touch provisioning software solutions ourselves. In this
context, we hold a patent (EP 2 100 438 B1) titled "hosted PBX servers with telephony device allocation, routing
and configuration information controlled by central database" (see "—13.11 Intellectual Property").
Business Support System

Our business support system allows contract and customer management, billing and invoicing. It is based on
Salesforce software which is complemented by a self-written rating and billing application (i.e. an application
determining the applicable tariffs and combining them with call data for billing purposes) and an application
programming interface ("API") for the integration of our wholesale business with carriers. The business support
system also supports our dealer, distributor and wholesale partner management, for example, by automatically
calculating the commissions payable to dealers or distributors.
Infrastructure

Except for the end-customers of our Swiss wholesale partner, Sunrise, whom we serve from data centres of
Sunrise in Switzerland, we currently serve our customers out of two data centre co-location facilities in Munich
and Nuremberg, Germany, which are operated by noris network. We rent the necessary space for our own
servers and, the racks the servers are placed in, as well as power supply, fire-prevention, air-conditioning and
certain basic on-premises service support from the owner of the co-location data centre facilities. In addition, we
source certain basic on-site service support from the operator of the co-location data centre facilities. Both data
centres are ISO certified and provide multi-layer security zones preventing physical access as well as flood and
fire prevention and measures against power or air-conditioning outages. They also fulfil the highest EN 50600
standards.

As part of our current disaster recovery arrangements, both data centres have virtually the same setup and can
each handle the customer load and customer functionality of all our customers. The data centres are operated in a
so-called "active/active" mode meaning that 50 % of the customer load is handled by each data centre. The
server and network capacity in each data centre is constantly expanded so that during normal operations the
capacity utilisation of one data centre does not exceed 50 %. As a result, even in the event of a loss of all servers
and network connectivity in one data centre we should have enough spare capacity in the remaining data centre
to handle the load. In case of such a loss, the servers in the other data centre can take over the tasks performed by
way of an automated takeover process.

Should the servers in one data centre break down in whole or in part, automated monitoring systems will detect
the failure and in most cases automatically direct the traffic to the remaining servers (both in the same and, if
necessary, in the other data centre). All components are constantly supervised by our internal monitoring
systems. Our monitoring systems, in turn, are monitored by an external monitoring system making sure that
failures do not remain undetected due to a failure of the internal monitoring systems.

We use several different automatic system failover mechanisms. Where applicable, systems are operated using
standard (Linux based) cluster mechanisms with parts of the cluster being located in each data centre. If the
cluster systems detect the outage of one of the cluster nodes they automatically start the corresponding service on
one of the remaining nodes. Moreover, all incoming traffic is automatically redirected/routed to the other node.
The NFON operated network allows for these traffic migrations to happen within few seconds and across data
centre boundaries.

Horizontally scaled components (for example, our central core PBX layer) are not operated using traditional
cluster mechanisms. Self-developed monitoring systems constantly monitor the functionality of each of the
components and in case of a failure immediately take the faulty component out of the production system,
migrating all customers handled by this component to the remaining working components in the process (both
within the same data centre and if necessary across data centre boundaries). The setup allows us to warrant
99.9 % availability of our NFON Cloud Telephone System on an annual basis to our customers.

All major components of our operational platform scale horizontally meaning that if the growth of the business
requires additional processing power in one area of the platform we can simply purchase and install additional
components in this area. The various components in different areas of the NFON operational platform scale
differently with regards to the operational key performance indicators.

Our two data centres offer enough space for our intended business growth. Moreover, we can increase our
capacity by adding data centres in other geographical locations.

We operate our own routing and switching infrastructure and as such are not dependent on network services of
the data centre provider. In order to provide redundant and high quality Internet connectivity we operate our own
autonomous system with a provider independent IP range and several high speed Internet upstreams (i.e.
connections with Internet carriers such as Deutsche Telekom and GTT). Moreover, we operate dedicated
connections to Deutsche Commercial Internet Exchange, a carrier and data centre-neutral internet exchange
point situated in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, and the London Internet Exchange. In addition to these high
speed Internet upstream connections and public peerings (i.e. interconnections of separate Internet networks for
the purpose of exchanging traffic), we also peer directly with important business partners such as British
Telecom, Telefónica Germany, Versatel and M-Net. Every upstream Internet connection is operated with full
routing tables (BGP) allowing for maximum flexibility on inbound and outbound traffic. Due to the amount of
high bandwidth upstream Internet connections with different carriers in all data centres, operating with full
routing tables and the usage of automatic BGP based routing protocols our connection to the internet is highly
redundant and flexible. Loss of connectivity to individual upstream Internet connections is detected and
mitigated automatically. Our total current upstream bandwidth as of 31 March 2018 was 60 GBit/s, out of which
only 1.5 GBit/s was used in peaks. The bandwidth of our upstream Internet connections can easily be increased.

Since the NFON system is operated in an active/active mode out of two data centres and since all individual
components can be operated in each data centre we need highly redundant and fast connectivity between the two
data centres. The data centres are interconnected by three connection lines with a maximum transmission
capacity of 10 Gbit/s each. Our current setup uses one active connection line while the second remains on
standby. As an additional security layer, the second passive connection line is physically redundant
(active/passive switching on the optical layer) with one connection line being directly between Munich and
Nuremberg, while the other one is going from Munich to Frankfurt to Nuremberg to mitigate the risk that
foreseeable natural disasters or accidents could destroy the interconnectivity between our two data centres.

foreseeable natural disasters or accidents could destroy the interconnectivity between our two data centres.
While the data flowing within one data centre is assumed to be safe due to the security measures in the data
centres, the connections between the two data centres are insecure. Hence, we fully encrypt the data transmitted
through the connection lines. Our future network concept provides for multiple connection lines to be operated in
an active/active setup giving us a maximum transmission capacity of more than 10 Gbit/s.

13.12   Research Development and Operations

Our research and development departments are located in Munich, Mainz and Berlin, Germany. We make sub-
stantial investments in the design and development of new products and services, as well as the development of
enhancements and features to our existing products and services, and make these enhancements available to our
customers frequently.

The in-house development is conducted using agile software development and includes user experience design
and quality management. We heavily rely on the usage of open source software such as Linux. However, the
functions building on such open source software are completely self-developed (including VoIP registration,
security, administration, dial plan, call router logic, rating of calls, billing, reporting and device provisioning).

Our R&D activities currently focus on developing a first version of the new end-user client. As a next develop-
ment step, we also intend to supplement the new client with additional UCaaS solutions such as video conferenc-
ing and collaboration features such as screen sharing or chat functions. We believe that the integration of addi-
tional UCaaS solutions is a necessary step to meet the need for more comprehensive communication solutions in
a quickly changing work environment.

Our operations team consists of technical consultants that mainly assist our customers with the customisation and
deployment of the NFON Cloud Telephone System and premium solutions, assist in bidding processes and sup-
port our channel partners in connection with projects, such as the implementation of our premium solutions
Ncontactcenter or Nhospitality.

As at 31 December 2017, our R&D team, including operations, consisted of 55 software architects, engineers
and developers and other IT specialists.

Exit Retention Programme for Key Employees of the Company

According to agreements concluded by the Company with eleven selected key employees of the Company, de-
fined as key top performers and business critical employees, the respective key employees are entitled to an exit
bonus payment in case of an initial listing of the Shares on the regulated market segment (Regulierter Markt) of
the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and, simultaneously, on the sub-segment thereof
with additional post-admission obligations (Prime Standard) provided that a capital increase takes place in con-
nection with such a listing and the Company receives proceeds of at least EUR 30 million from such a capital
increase by 31 December 2018 (the "Exit"). The exit bonus payment consists of a bonus which should reward
the individual performance of the respective key employee if the Exit takes place within a predefined date (the
"Exit Target Bonus") and a retention bonus which is conditional upon the key employee remaining in a non-
terminated employment relationship with the Company until a predefined future date (the "Retention Bonus").
The Exit Target Bonus is an one-off payment and ranges from EUR 25 thousand to EUR 50 thousand depending
on the individual agreement of each key employee. The Retention Bonus consists of two bonus payments rang-
ing from EUR 25 thousand to EUR 75 thousand. The first payment will become due if the key employee is still
in a non-terminated employment relationship with the Company twelve months after the Exit and the second
payment after a period of another twelve months. The key employees are entitled to the payment of the Exit
Target Bonus and the Retention Bonus if the Exit takes place prior to 31 December 2018. The maximum total
obligations of the Company from the Exit Target Bonus and the Retention Bonus payable to selected key em-
ployees amount to approximately EUR 1,550 thousand plus social securities contributions (Sozialabgaben).
13.14   Property and Leases

Our headquarters are located in Munich, Germany, where we occupy an approximately 2,500 square-meter facil-
ity, under a lease expiring on 31 December 2023. We have further offices in Berlin, Greven, Madrid, Mainz, St.
Pölten and Uxbridge.
13.15   Material Contracts

The following section provides an overview of contracts that are material to our business or profitability. Apart
from the agreements summarised below there are no other industrial, commercial or financial contracts which
are material to our business.
Agreements with dealers

We entered into agreements with our dealers based on our respective standard terms and conditions (for a de-
scription of the dealers network see "—13.8 Distribution, Marketing and Customer Care—13.8.1 Distribution").
Under these agreements, dealers agree to market our products and services to end customers. In return, dealers
are entitled to use the official name 'NFON Partner' and may use our designations, logos, and trademarks, to
promote our products and services.

Pursuant to the standard terms and conditions, dealers are in particular obliged to draw the attention of end cus-
tomers to our offer, to assume consulting services (e.g. determination of the desired configuration and implemen-
tation assistance) and to provide first-level support towards end customers during implementation and operation
of the services. For this purpose, we train employees of our dealers in technical and sales aspects and support
dealers in initiating the business in particular by providing telephone advice.

If a customer has been acquired, we directly enter into an agreement with the end customer. As compensation,
we pay one-time and monthly commissions to the dealers. The amount of the respective commission is generally
based on the revenue we generate with the end customer. The dealer receives a commission on the activation
fees paid by the end customer (one-off) as well as a certain percentage of the monthly recurring revenue (without
call charges). Additionally, the amount of the payable commission varies depending on the status of a dealer
(Standard Partner, Approved Partner, Qualified Partner or Premium Partner), which in turn depends on the num-
ber of the marketed PBX seats in the previous contract period.

With regard to hardware (e.g. telephone sets), dealers are entitled to buy hardware from us at dealer conditions
and resell it to end customers. In such cases, invoicing to the end customer is carried out by our dealers. Alterna-
tively, a direct marketing of hardware by us to the end customer is also permitted.

The standard agreement with dealers is non-exclusive. It has a minimum duration of twelve months and extends
automatically for successive periods of twelve months unless terminated with a four weeks' notice period.
Agreements with distributors

We entered into agreements with our distributors based on our respective standard terms and conditions (for a
description of the distributors network see "—13.8 Distribution, Marketing and Customer Care—13.8.1 Distri-
bution). Under these agreements, distributors agree to market our products and services to end customers as well
as to build up "own" networks of sub-distribution partners. In return, distributors are entitled to use the official
name "NFON distributions partner" and may use our designations, logos, and trademarks to promote our prod-
ucts and services.

With regard to the marketing of our products to end customers, the contractual arrangements between us and the
distributors are identical to those governing the relationships with our dealers. Moreover, distributors undertake
to acquire and procure dealers that are interested in marketing our products as sub-distribution partners. In the
event of a successful acquisition of a sub-distribution partner, the respective sub-distribution partner concludes
its own dealer agreement with us. Nevertheless, the distributor is the first point of contact for its sub-distribution
partners with respect to all technical and sales questions.

As compensation for the acquisition and support of sub-distribution partners, we pay commissions to distributors
depending on the turnover generated by the dealers managed by the distributor. The distributor receives one-time
and monthly commissions per each PBX seat marketed by dealers managed by the distributor. The amount of the
one-time commission depends on the achievement of individual agreed sales targets. The amount of the monthly
commission is based on the respective revenue and call charges received by us.

The standard agreement is non-exclusive. It has a minimum duration of twelve months and extends automatical-
ly for successive periods of twelve months unless terminated with a four weeks' notice period.
Framework agreement with a wholesale partner

The Company entered into a framework agreement with a wholesale partner regarding the white-label reselling
of our NFON Cloud Telephone System services and certain hardware (e.g. telephone sets) and software to
wholesale partner's end customers. Under the agreement, the Company guarantees an annual availability of our
PBX platform of 99.9 % and the availability of the relevant service, user and customer portals of 98 % per
month. The Company is obliged to pay contractual penalties if it fails to meet these availabilities and is responsi-
ble for such default. As compensation, the Company receives a fee for the initial installation of our services and
additionally receives monthly fees for each active seat and hardware and other services we provide (e.g. tech-
nical support). The agreement is non-exclusive. It has a minimum duration of 24 months from the legal ac-
ceptance of the relevant technical platform by the wholesale partner. The agreement extends automatically for
successive periods of twelve months unless terminated by the wholesale partner with 30 days' notice or by us
with three months' notice, in each case to the end of the calendar year.
Material service and sales agreements with our customers

We provide our services to our end customers on the basis of our standard order forms, our service level agree-
ments for the respective products and our general terms and conditions.
General Terms and Conditions

The provisions set up in our general terms and conditions apply unless otherwise stipulated in the Standard Order
Forms or in the Service Level Agreements ("SLA"). Agreements are in general entered into for an unlimited
period of time. In cases where a certain (minimum) term has been agreed between us and the customer, the
agreement shall be automatically extended by an agreed period of time if it is not terminated with a notice period
of four weeks prior to the respective expiry. A contractual relationship concluded for an indefinite period of time
can be terminated by us and our customers without cause with a notice period of 30 days to the end of the month.
Additionally, we may terminate the agreement for good cause, if the customer is more than 20 calendar days in
arrears with the payment of the fees.
Service Level Agreements

Under the Service Level Agreement for Business, we provide our customers with a centralised, virtual, VoIP
based telephone system. Such services include among others the establishing of connections to the worldwide
telephone network PSTN, the provision and porting of certain telephone numbers, connections to premium ser-
vice telephone numbers as well as voicemail, fax, phonebook, call centre monitoring and call encryption ser-
vices. With regard to the services described in the Business SLA, we guarantee an average annual availability of
99.9 % (excluded from the respective calculation are periods in which notified maintenance is carried out, the
systems cannot be reached due to force majeure, the security of network operation, the maintenance of network
integrity, the software or stored data requires a service interruption as well as time losses that are not our fault).
Also guaranteed within the Business SLA are response times in the case of fault reports of two, six and nine
hours, depending on the effects for the customer.

Under the Service Level Agreement for Nconnect, we provide our customers with Internet access products with
an average annual availability of 98 %. The relevant services provide for bandwidths between 16 and 100 Mbit/s
downstream and 0.8 to 40 Mbit/s upstream. The minimum term of the relevant agreement is 24 months and is
automatically extended for successive twelve months unless terminated with three months' notice prior to the end
of a renewal period.

Under the Service Level Agreement for Ncontactcenter, we provide a web-oriented Automatic Call Center
solution based on browser technology for the operation and display of call center data. The minimum contract
term for Ncontactcenter is twelve months with an automatic renewal of one month. With respect to Ncon-
tactcenter services, we guarantee an average annual availability of 99.0 %. Additionally, the SLAs for Business
also applies to Ncontactcenter.

Under the Service Level Agreement for Ndaks-Eco 100, we provide our customers with an on-site alarm server
which can be integrated into building technology. The minimum contract term for Ndaks-Eco 100 is 24 months
with an automatic renewal of one month. The availability level and the SLAs for Business also apply to Ndaks-
Eco 100 (in particular the average annual availability of 99.9 %).

Under the Service Level Agreement for Nhospitality, we provide a specific cloud based communication solution
for the hotel industry. The availability level and the Service Level Agreements for Business also apply to Nhos-
pitality (in particular the average annual availability of 99.9 %). The relevant SLA does not provide for a mini-
mum contract term.

Under the Service Level Agreement for Neorecording, we provide various recording features out of the cloud.
The availability level and the SLAs of Business also apply to Neorecording (in particular the average annual
availability of 99.9 %). The relevant SLA does not provide for a minimum contract term.

Where we guarantee certain service levels and/or availabilities to our customers under the described SLAs, the
customer is entitled to reduce the invoice amount in the case of a default. Such reduction amounts to half of the
fee for the respective service for the month in which the default occurred. If several defaults occur in one month
regarding the same service, the customer is entitled to a reduction only once.
VoIP Termination Agreement with network carriers

We entered into various agreements with network carriers regarding the termination of VoIP telephone and tele-
fax traffic from our customers via the network carriers' networks. Under these agreements the network carriers
typically also provide us with geographical telephone numbers for use by our end customers. As a compensation,
we pay a fee for each telephone number provided or ported by the network carriers to our customers. We also
pay a fee for each second of traffic handed over by us to the network carrier.

pay a fee for each second of traffic handed over by us to the network carrier.
The agreements are non-exclusive. They typically have an initial minimum duration. Following the expiry of the
initial minimum term, the agreements usually extend for an indefinite time and may be terminated by either party
with a notice period between three month to the end of each month to six month to the end of each contractual
year.
Framework purchase agreement with ASC Technologies

In July 2016, the Company entered into a framework purchase agreement with our supplier ASC Technologies.
Under this agreement, the Company is entitled, but not obliged, to order multi-client capable managed services
for recording, storing and managing voice communication (including clients for end users). ASC Technologies is
obliged to provide such services as well as to provide software support, further development and incident and
problem management. First and second level support for the ordered services is provided by us.

At the peering point ASC Technologies guarantees 99.9 % availability of the recording platform on a monthly
average (excluding scheduled maintenance). Invoicing is carried out on the basis of monthly usage fees (exclud-
ing setup services, which are billed upon completion of the respective setup). The agreement stipulates various
discount levels depending on the achievement of agreed sales targets.

The agreement has an initial minimum term until 31 December 2018 and extends automatically for consecutive
twelve months, unless it is terminated with a three months' notice period to the end of a calendar year. The
agreement is exclusive for both parties with regard to certain compliant communications recording services in
the EEA until 31 December 2018. The exclusivity does not apply if the end customer explicitly requests another
supplier in writing.
Framework purchase agreement with jtel

In January 2017, the Company entered into a framework purchase agreement with our supplier jtel. Under this
agreement, jtel contractually undertook to render cloud-based contact centre solutions to us. With regard to the
ordered services, jtel committed to provide maintenance as well as the second and third level support (e.g. trou-
bleshooting and updates).

The agreement is non-exclusive. It has a minimum duration of twelve months and extends automatically for
successive periods of twelve months unless terminated with a three months' notice period to the end of the calen-
dar year.
Loan Agreement and Acquisition loan with UniCredit Bank AG

On 19 January 2017, the Company entered into a current-account credit facility (Kontokorrentkredit) with
UniCredit Bank AG of up to EUR 8 million with a variable interest rate. Amounts drawn under the current-
account credit facility may be applied towards corporate purposes.

On 2 March 2018, the Company has entered into an acquisition loan agreement (Akquisitionskredit) with
UniCredit Bank AG in the amount of EUR 0.8 million, with a fixed interest rate. The purpose of this loan was to
finance the payment of the part of the purchase price for the acquisition of the shares in the Company's Austrian
subsidiary, nfon GmbH, held by a joint-venture partner in Austria payable immediately upon signing. The loan
has a term until 31 December 2020.

On 2 March 2018, the Company has further entered into a current-account credit facility (Kontokorrentkredit)
with UniCredit Bank AG in the amount of EUR 2.3 million, with a variable interest rate. The purpose of this

facility is to secure the forthcoming financial obligations in the acquisition of the shares in nfon GmbH. The
facility is available until 31 December 2018. Amounts outstanding by then shall be converted into a redeemable
loan (Tilgungsdarlehen) with a term until 31 December 2020.

Upon entering into the acquisition loan agreement (Akquisitionskredit) and the current-account credit facility
(Kontokorrentkredit), the current-account credit facility (Kontokorrentkredit) dated 19 January 2017 was re-
duced by a new current-account credit facility (Kontokorrentkredit) dated 2 March 2018 to EUR 4 million. The
current-account credit facility (Kontokorrentkredit) is provided for general corporate purposes.
Acquisition of 49.8 % of the shares in nfon GmbH

On 30 October 2017, the Company's 100 % subsidiary, fairfon Telefonsysteme GmbH, entered into a share pur-
chase agreement (as purchaser) with our former joint-venture partner, ipefon GmbH (as seller). Subject of the
purchase were 49.8 % of the shares in our Austrian subsidiary, nfon GmbH, held by ipefon GmbH. The agreed
base purchase price was EUR 3.1 million plus interest thereon at a variable interest rate of which EUR 775 thou-
sand was payable immediately upon signing of the agreement and the remainder immediately payable after the
occurrence of an exit event, such as the consummation of the Offering. fairfon Telefonsysteme GmbH pledged
the purchased shares to ipefon GmbH to secure the payment of the outstanding portion of the purchase price. The
share purchase agreement contains customary representations and warranties. The Company granted a guarantee
for the performance of all obligations of fairfon Telefonsysteme GmbH under this share purchase agreement.
Coexistence Agreement with FON Wireless

On 16 March 2015, we entered into a coexistence agreement with FON Wireless, inter alia, on our use of the
trademark "NFON" for goods and services in certain trademark classes, including trademark class 9, 35 and 38.
Trademark class 38 relates to telecommunications services which covers the services we currently market.

In this coexistence agreement we undertook to use and register the NFON trademark for services in trademark
classes 9, 35 and 38 only with "NFON" in capital letters and always together with the term "The Cloud Tele-

phone System" or a translation of this term into other languages and together with the Symbol "  ". In case we
must or would like to use a term and/or logo different from the agreed form, we have to inform FON Wireless
and ask for their written consent which FON Wireless may not withhold, if such term or logo is not confusingly
similar to a term and/or logo already registered by FON Wireless. Our obligations do not apply to the use and
registration of the company name NFON and domain names consisting of or containing nfon and do further not
apply to the use of NFON in plain text.

We are exposed from time to time to legal proceedings in the normal course of our business. We are currently

13.17   Insurance

Our insurance policies include a customary directors and officers insurance (D&O-Versicherung) for the
members of our Management and Supervisory Board with an insurance coverage of up to a maximum amount of
EUR 20 million, per claim and for maximum two claims per insurance year, which is a professional liability
insurance covering companies and individuals against claims made by clients for professional negligence. The
D&O insurance contract provides for a deductible for all members of the Company's Management Board in line
with the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz).

Further insurance coverage comprises legal expenses insurance in case of criminal law expenses and expenses
from D&O claims up to a maximum amount of EUR 2 million and legal expenses in other civil law cases up to a
maximum amount of EUR 4 million.

Furthermore, we maintain third party liability insurance with an insurance coverage of up to a maximum amount
of EUR 10 million. The insurance policies contain market-standard exclusions and deductibles.

However, we cannot provide any assurance that losses will not be incurred or that claims will not be filed against
us, which are not covered by an insurance policy.

15.GENERAL INFORMATION ON
NFON AKTIENGESELLSCHAFT AND THE NFON GROUP
15.1   History and Development of the Group

The Company was founded in March 2007 in Munich, Germany. At that time, the Company was called nfon
AG, which was changed to the spelling NFON AG in February 2014. A partial profit transfer agreement with
BayBG Bayerische Beteiligungsgesellschaft mbH was in place from 12 May 2009 to 31 December 2014.
Registered office, Financial Year, Term Corporate Purpose

The Company was incorporated as a stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) under German law pursuant to an
incorporation deed dated 16 March 2007 and was registered with the Commercial Register on 22 May 2007. The
Company is registered with the Commercial Register (Handelsregister) maintained by the local court
(Amtsgericht) of Munich, Germany, under the number HRB 168022. The Company's registered office is
Machtlfinger Str. 7, 81379 Munich (Tel. +49 89 453 00 0, Company's website: www.nfon.com). The Company
is the main operational entity of the Group, as well as the Groups' holding company. The Company and its
subsidiaries primarily operate under the commercial name "NFON".

The Company's Articles of Association have last been amended by the resolution of the general shareholders'
meeting on 9 April 2018. Pursuant to Section 29 of the Articles of Association, the Company's accounting year is
the calendar year.

In accordance with Section 2 of the Articles of Association, the corporate purpose of the Company is the
development, marketing and operation of innovative communication solutions and applications for business-
critical enterprise use (Applikationen für den geschäftskritischen Unternehmenseinsatz). In accordance with
Section 2 para. 1 of the Articles of Association, the Company does not engage in any transactions which are
subject to regulatory authorisation. The Company is entitled to all transactions and measures which appear
necessary or useful for achieving the aforementioned company purpose, in particular to establish branches, to
participate in other companies, to conclude intercompany agreements or confine itself to the management of its
participations.
The Company provides cloud-operated, high-end telephone systems especially for corporate customers.
Auditor

KPMG AG Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Ganghoferstraße 29, 80339 Munich, Germany, was appointed as
the auditor of (i) our annual financial statements prepared in accordance with the German generally accepted
accounting principles of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch) as of and for the financial years
ended 31 December 2017 and (ii) our English language consolidated financial statements prepared in accordance

16.DESCRIPTION OF SHARE CAPITAL
    AND RELATED INFORMATION
Provisions Relating to the Share Capital
Current Share Capital and Shares

As of the date of this Prospectus, the share capital of the Company amounts to EUR 9,640,150.00. The share
capital is divided into 9,640,150 bearer shares (Inhaberaktien) with no par value (Stückaktien). The Shares were
created pursuant to German law. The share capital of the Company has been fully paid in.

Each Share carries one vote at the Company's general shareholders' meeting. There are no restrictions on voting
rights.

The Management Board determines the form of the share certificates as well as the dividend coupons with the
consent of the Supervisory Board. Global certificates may be issued. Pursuant to Section 6 para. 2 of the Articles
of Association, shareholders are not entitled to receive definitive share certificates (Aktienurkunden) for their
Shares insofar as permitted by law and unless a certification is necessary according to the rules of a stock
exchange at which the Shares are admitted to trading.

The Company's share capital will be represented by one global share certificate without dividend coupons, which
will be deposited with Clearstream (see "3. The Offering—3.4 Information on the Shares—3.4.2 Certification of
the Shares"). An additional global share certificate without dividend coupons will be issued for the New Shares
and will likewise be deposited with Clearstream.
Development of the Share Capital

The Company was incorporated in the form of a German stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) with an initial
registered share capital of EUR 50,000.00. Thereafter, the Company's share capital has been increased in several
stages to the current amount of EUR 9,640,150.00.

On 19/20 May 2008, the general shareholders' meeting of the Company resolved to increase its share capital
from EUR 50,000.00 by EUR 8,825.00 to EUR 58,825.00, which was registered in the Commercial Register
(Handelsregister) on 19 June 2008. On 7 January 2009, the general shareholders' meeting resolved to increase
the share capital from EUR 58.825,00 by EUR 19,608.00 to EUR 78,433.00, which was registered in the Com-
mercial Register (Handelsregister) on 23 February 2009. On 11 May 2009, the Management Board, with ap-
proval of the Supervisory Board, resolved on the increase of the share capital from EUR 78,433.00 by
EUR 3,459 to EUR 81,892 out of conditional capital 2008/I, which was registered in the Commercial Register
(Handelsregister) on 9 July 2009. On 12 May 2009, the general shareholders' meeting resolved to increase the
share capital from EUR 81,892.00 by EUR 3,268.00 to EUR 85,160.00, which was registered in the Commercial
Register (Handelsregister) on 9 July 2009. On 19 August 2008, the Management Board, with approval of the
Supervisory Board, resolved on the increase of the share capital from EUR 85,160.00 by EUR 3,518.00 to
EUR 88,678.00 out of conditional capital 2008/I, which was registered in the Commercial Register (Han-
delsregister) on 8 September 2009. Furthermore, on 20 August 2009, the general shareholders' meeting resolved
to increase the share capital from EUR 88,678.00 by EUR 19,109.00 to EUR 107,787.00 and to further increase
the share capital from EUR 107,787.00 by EUR 22,778.00 to EUR 130,565.00, which was registered in the
Commercial Register (Handelsregister) on 17 September 2009 and on 6 October 2009, respectively. On

EUR 130,565.00 by EUR 11,390.00 to EUR 141,955.00, which was registered in the Commercial Register
(Handelsregister) on 8 April 2010. Two further share capital increases were resolved upon by the general share-
holders' meeting in 2010: By resolution dated 29 July 2010 the share capital was increased from

from EUR 153,343.00 by EUR 22,224.00 to EUR 175,567.00, which was registered in the Commercial Register

Stock Option Plan 2018

On the basis of the authorisation of the general shareholders' meeting dated 9 April 2018, the Company is enti-
tled to grant to members of its Management Board and its employees as well as to members of the management
boards and employees of affiliated companies rights to purchase Shares in the Company (the "Stock Options").
The Company's Supervisory Board is responsible for deciding on the issuance of Stock Options to members of
the Management Board and the further details of the issuance. A maximum amount of 964,015 Stock Options

mences on the day of the issuance of Stock Options and ends after ten years. Stock Options may only be exer-

cise of Stock Options is conditional upon the fulfilment of certain performance targets based on the development
of the revenue of NFON in the year the Stock Options were granted compared to the preceding year, such per-
formance targets requiring an increase in revenue of NFON of 20 % per year. The exercise price for Stock Op-
tions will be the arithmetic average of the closing prices of the Shares in Xetra trading (or a comparable succes-
sor system) on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange within the ten trading days prior to the issuance. Each Stock Option
entitles its holder to purchase one share in the Company from the conditional capital created for this purpose
against payment of the exercise price.
Authorisation to issue Convertible Bonds and Other Instruments

On the basis of the resolution of the general shareholders' meeting dated 9 April 2018, the Management Board is
authorised, with the approval of the Supervisory Board, to issue until 8 April 2023, once or repeatedly, wholly or
partly or simultaneously in different tranches, convertible bonds, bonds with warrants, profit participation rights,
and/or participating bonds or combinations of these instruments (collectively, the "Bonds") having a total par
value of up to EUR 115,681,800.00 with or without term restrictions and to grant the holders or creditors (collec-
tively, the "Holders") option rights or obligations or conversion rights or obligations to Shares with a maximum
proportion of the share capital of EUR 3,856,060.00. The Bonds may also be issued against contributions in
kind. All partial bonds of an issued tranche have to provide for equal-ranking rights and obligations.

Bonds may be issued both in euro and any other national currency of a member country of the Organisation for
Economic Co-operation and Development, as long as the corresponding euro equivalent is not exceeded.

The Bonds may also be issued by a group company. In this case, the Management Board is authorised, with the
approval of the Supervisory Board, to assume the guarantee for such Bonds for the Company and to grant option
rights or conversion rights to the holders or creditors of such Bonds.

In the event of convertible bonds being issued, the Holders of the Bonds are entitled to convert their Bonds into
Shares in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Bonds.

The Bonds may also be mandatorily convertible at the end of the term (or earlier) or provide for the right of the
Company to grant the holders of Bonds Shares in lieu of repayment of the Bonds.
The terms and conditions of the Bonds may also provide that, in the event of an option being exercised or of a
conversion, the Company may at its discretion also grant treasury Shares.
The terms and conditions of the Bonds may also provide for the right of the Company not to grant Shares, but
rather to pay the equivalent value in cash.

The option or conversion price for a Share shall amount to at least 80 % of the average closing price of the Share
in the Xetra trading system of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (or a comparable
subsequent system) on the last ten trading days before the date on which the resolution on the issue of the Bonds
is adopted by the Management Board, or in the event of subscription rights trading, on the days of the subscrip-
tion rights trading period with the exception of the last two trading days of the subscription rights trading period.
In case of Bonds with conversion obligations or a right of the Company to grant the holders of Bonds Shares in
lieu of repayment of the Bonds, the conversion price may in accordance with the terms and conditions of the
Bonds either amount to at least the aforementioned minimum price or the volume-weighted average price of the
Share in the Xetra trading system of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (or a compa-
rable subsequent system) on the last three trading days before the determination of the conversion price, even if
such average price is below the aforementioned minimum price. Section 9 para. 1 as well as Section 199 para. 2
of the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz) remain unaffected.

The terms and conditions of the Bonds may also provide for certain anti-dilution mechanisms pursuant to which
the option or conversion rights and obligations may be adjusted to retain value, if during the term of the Bonds
the financial value of the existing option or conversion rights and obligations is diluted, in particular as a conse-
quence of share capital increases or the sale of treasury Shares, and no subscription rights are granted as com-
pensation.

The shareholders have in principle subscription rights to the Bonds. The Bonds may also be acquired by one or
several banks pursuant to Section 186 para. 5 sentence 1 of the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz)
subject to the obligation to offer them to shareholders for subscription.

The Management Board may with the consent of the Supervisory Board exclude subscription rights to the Bonds
in certain cases and under certain conditions, including:

   if the Bonds are issued for cash payment, provided that the issue price is not significantly lower than the
    theoretical market price in accordance with recognised financial methods and that the Bonds carry option
    or conversion rights and/or option or conversion obligations to Shares with a proportionate amount of the
    share capital which must not exceed 10 % of the Company's share capital at the time said authorisation
    comes to effect or—in case such amount is lower—the authorisation is exercised,
   if the Bonds are issued against contributions in kind, in particular in the context of mergers or in order to
    acquire companies, parts of companies, shareholdings in companies or other assets, or claims including
    claims, against the Company or its group companies,
   to grant subscription rights to Holders of option or conversion rights or option or conversion obligations
    to the extent they would be entitled to subscription rights after exercising the option or conversion right,
   for fractional amounts, or
   to the extent that profit participation rights or participating bonds are issued that do not carry option or
    conversion rights and/or option or conversion obligations, if these profit participation rights or participat-
    ing bonds are structured in the same way as bonds, i.e., do not constitute any membership rights in the
    Company, do not grant any participation in liquidation proceeds and the amount of interest is not calcu-
    lated on the basis of the amount of net income, unappropriated net income, or the dividend. In addition, in
    this case, the interest and the issue price of the profit participation rights or participating bonds shall also
    correspond to comparable borrowings under current market conditions on the issue date.

The Management Board is authorised, with the approval of the Supervisory Board, to stipulate further particu-
lars and terms of the Bonds in accordance with the parameters of the authorisation.
Authorisation to acquire and sell Treasury Shares
The Company currently holds no treasury Shares.

On the basis of the resolution of the general shareholders' meeting dated 9 April 2018, the Company is author-
ised during the period ending on 8 April 2023 to acquire treasury no-par-value Shares representing a total of up

ny.

The authorisation may not be used for trading in own Shares. The authorisation may be exercised in whole or in
part and on one or several occasions by the Company or by its group companies or third parties, which act on
behalf of the Company or any group company.

Treasury Shares may, at the discretion of the Management Board, be acquired over the stock exchange or by way

   In the event of purchase via the stock exchange, the purchase price per Share (excluding ancillary acquisi-

tendered Shares per shareholder may be stipulated.
